**THE WELL**

I read that if you go deep enough into a hole, you can see the stars when it is clear. I asked you to help me with my idea. You watched me as I pulled up the well bucket. I steadied it on the wall and then climbed in. I told you to let me down. I did not think about how heavy the bucket was or that you might not be strong enough. You held the handle while I pushed the bucket off the wall. I fell into the well. I hit my head. 

At first, I saw strange lights. Later, I thought about how cartoon characters see stars when they hit their heads. I felt confused, scared, and then angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what my mother would say. You called down to me, asking if I was okay. I wanted to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice. I lay still and watched you through my eyelashes. You went to get help. 

I waited a moment, then climbed back up and pulled myself out of the well. I could hear loud voices from the castle. I ran away to hide in the shadows. My mother and father came with you and old Arthur. My mother was screaming. My father told Arthur to pull the winch handle. You looked pale and shocked. I was hidden in the shadows. 

I felt a rush of excitement. Then I saw the drops of water I left from the well to where I stood. I looked in horror at the dark spots on the ground. My clothes were wet, and there was a little pool of water at my feet. I looked back at my father shining a flashlight into the well. I could not believe no one saw the drops. My mother was screaming loudly. I felt scared. 

I had played a trick on you, but now it was serious. I thought I would get in trouble. I wished I had thought more about my plan. I decided to come out of hiding. I cried out softly, then yelled louder when no one heard me. I fell down on the ground. I sat up, feeling comforted in my mother’s arms. I said I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and crawled through it to get out. 

I thought I was almost safe until my father came to me. He wanted me to tell my story again. I did, but I hesitated. He looked at me closely. I said the secret passage fell in after me, and it was dangerous. I looked into my father's eyes, and it felt like he was seeing me for the first time. 

He said, "Don't be ridiculous, boy," and walked away. Arthur looked at me with a sad face. He knew I was lying. He worried about me because I was not honest. This made me feel even worse.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Susan is a widow. Her children are now grown up. She is leaving her family home. A big van is outside. It says "Removers of Distinction." The workers are taking everything from the house. They are wrapping things in newspaper and putting them in boxes. Fred is the main worker. He is very careful with the breakable things. 

Susan is sad to leave her lovely house. It is a big house with four floors and a view of a small harbour. She remembers the years she spent there with her children. When they bought the house, her son Robert, who was five years old, asked, "Mum, how do you get the house home?" 

Now, Robert is here to help. He is making sure Susan does not forget about the piano. Francesca, their daughter, is also helping. She is very bossy and wants to take care of the piano because it is special. 

Fred, the worker, says, "She doesn't look like she's going to cry." Susan asks, "Do people cry?" Fred replies, "Yes, they do. They are happy while we work, but when they see the empty house, they cry." Susan understands this feeling. 

The piano is in the best room of the house. They will take it last. Susan remembers when they first brought the piano into the house. It got stuck on the stairs. The workers tried for a long time to get it in. Robert watched, and Francesca cried, "We can't live without a piano!" 

Finally, Peter, Susan's late husband, found a way to get the piano inside. They took out a window and used a crane to lift the piano in. The children were very happy. 

Now, Susan thinks about how her children are busy and do not come home much. She feels tired going up the stairs. She worries about the piano. Fred asks if she is okay. She feels a little panicked. 

Robert and Francesca come to watch. Fred says, "No tears then?" Susan feels like crying. Moving things makes her feel sad. 

Then, the piano comes down the stairs. Fred is careful with it. They take it outside to the van. Robert laughs, and soon everyone is laughing. They are happy it is over. 

As they walk down the path for the last time, Susan only sheds tears of laughter.

**Online Book Reviews for Everyone**

Anyone can write book reviews on the Internet. This idea started when the Internet became popular. At first, it was hard for many people to publish their thoughts online. But then, Amazon.com, a big online bookstore, made it easy for everyone to write reviews about books.

On Amazon, anyone can say what they think about a book and give it up to five stars. Each book has its own page, and when someone writes a review, it shows up right away. This helps other readers see what people think about the book, not just what the publisher says.

Amazon is very popular, so many people write reviews. But because there are so many reviews, it is hard for Amazon to check all of them. They have some rules. For example, you cannot write just one word or say bad things about the author. If a review breaks the rules, Amazon will try to remove it.

Sometimes, authors write good reviews for their own books without saying who they are. One author, Lev Grossman, was upset about bad reviews for his book. He wrote good reviews for his own book but later told everyone he did it. Amazon took away his fake reviews.

Authors can also write messages about their books on Amazon. They can ask people to read and enjoy their books. Some authors even give their email addresses so readers can talk to them. But Amazon does not always check if the message is really from the author.

Readers can also write reviews about books. When a book called "We've Got Spirit" came out, some people were angry about it and wrote bad reviews. Many of these reviews were removed quickly. But Amazon liked that so many people were writing reviews because it was good for business.

Most reviews on Amazon are serious. They help other readers decide if a book is good to buy. A famous writer, George Orwell, once said that writing too many reviews can be hard. But now, many people can share their thoughts about books, and that is a good thing.

**Art in Modern Times**

In the last two hundred years, people often think that artists must be different from others. We say that art should be unique and surprising. We like to admire artists whose work was not appreciated in the past. But when we see new art today, we sometimes think it is too strange and not real art. The media often say this for us, and we agree because we expect art to be new and confusing. We forget that today’s art has old ideas and methods too.

In the past, people asked artists to make art for special reasons. Art was part of everyday life. Now, artists work alone, and we can get upset if they try to connect with us.

**A Situation to Think About**

I want to tell you a story and ask a question. An artist picks a text from an art book. The text says there are many kinds of pictures. Then, the artist asks someone to make a canvas and write the text on it in simple letters. My question is: Is this a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

In London, there is a gallery where artists show their work. Many artists stick to one style because it sells well. People expect them to keep making the same kind of art. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, try new things and are successful. Eric Rimmington is another artist who is trying something different. He is painting pictures of the London Underground instead of his usual still lifes. He has made 40 paintings and drawings that show the interesting world below the ground.

**A Story from an Island**

I have come to a quiet island with some books. The villagers joke that only a sick person would come here. I am alone, except for an old woman who comes to clean my house. I feel neither happy nor sad. I think about memories. I said art is not useful, but it can help us feel better. Art lets us see the world in a new way. It helps us understand our feelings and experiences. Artists use their imagination to deal with life, not to escape from it.

**Family Business**

"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car going back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from my school. I had won two prizes at school. My father talked to my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked. I knew my father was thinking about something important. He usually talked a lot, but now he was quiet. "You can't fool me. You will do what you want now," he said. "I heard you will get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I replied. "Mightn't that be useful?" 

He continued, "I also heard you want to be a barrister." My father knew a lot about barristers and the law. "I just said that," I said. "I didn't know what else to say!"

He said, "You have the right personality. You can understand things quickly, you talk well, and you like to perform." 

"I don't know about that," I said. "I only see it on TV."

"Anyway," he said, "I think you will not want to join the family business. You will go to Oxford, and after that, I don't think you will like it." 

I felt trapped by what my family wanted. I wanted to explore other jobs, but I didn't want to upset my father. I was not as scared of him as Maurice was, but I still found him strong.

"It's too soon to know," I said quietly. 

"You will not want to join us," my father said. "It's a pity because you have the skills." 

"There's still Maurice," I said sadly. My father laughed. We both knew Maurice did not like the business. 

"Anyway," I said, "you could use me as a consultant." My mother had died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. I took care of Maurice because he was younger. I loved him. 

Because the business was successful, we lived well. We had a big house, nice schools, and good clothes. My father knew many important people, and our house was always busy with interesting talks.

"You can help us during the holidays until you leave Oxford," my father said. "Then if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some money and help me." 

"OK," I said, happy to avoid making a big decision now. This was how my father controlled us. 

So, I helped during my last term at school and during university breaks. I became a smart student with my own small house, a nice car, and good clothes. 

In my last term, my father came to see me. He took me to a village for a meal. My teacher said I would get a First Class degree in Law. I felt ready and confident.

Then my father told me he needed me to do one last important job for the family business. "But Dad," I said, "I have my final exams soon. I need to focus on that. It's very important!" 

I could see my father did not understand. He would think I was being unkind if I said no. As he talked about the job, I saw how focused and strong he was. He was very good at his work, and I admired him. 

In that moment, my own plans felt less important. "All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello bought a house in Pembroke Square with his wife, Lois. After a year, he thought it was a mistake. They needed to save money, but at first, buying the house seemed like a good idea. Simon had many successful cases at work, and Lois returned to her job after having twins. She earned a good salary, and she wanted to move to a bigger place because their flat was too small for their family.

Lois wanted to live in a nice area, not in a less popular part of London. She thought it was important for them to have a good address. To save money, Lois decided that Simon should take public transport to work. His journey was long and crowded, and he often felt unhappy during this time. He remembered his grandfather's house, where he felt safe and cared for as a child.

Lois wanted her career to be as important as Simon's. They needed both of their salaries to pay for the house and their lifestyle. But now, Simon was worried about a colleague named Venetia. She was upset and angry when she came to their office. Venetia accused Simon of wrongdoing in a past case. She said that a man he defended had bribed jurors, and she wanted to know if it was true. Simon denied it, but he felt guilty and scared.

He wished he had said something different to Venetia. He felt her anger and disbelief. He wondered why she was so angry and if she had the right to judge him. He was afraid that if people heard these rumors, it could ruin his career.

I chose this place to live because I thought I could be alone. I thought people would not care about the broken houses and messy gardens. But I was wrong. People in the shops see me and start to know me. The flowers from next door remind me that gardens can be beautiful. I usually stay inside, but tonight I am watching the birds fly. I cut some plants to make space for a chair. My hands have scratches from the plants. 

I have a small garden in London. It is hard for plants to grow here. My neighbor, Jaz, leans out of her window. She is a writer. I sometimes help her with her writing. She asks me how her work is going. Jaz says she wishes she could have holidays like me. She comes down to my garden. I do not want her here because my garden looks messy. 

Jaz sits in my chair and asks about my plans for the holidays. I feel worried about having nothing to do. I tell her I am going to visit my friend Ruby. I ask Jaz to feed my cats while I am away. She agrees. I say I will stay with Ruby, but I am not sure if I will. 

Jaz asks about her story, which I have not read much. I tell her I like the title. I think it is sad that red vans bring gifts to other people but not to her. I give Jaz some advice. I tell her to write about nice people. She gets upset and tells me to get a life. I say I have a life. I work and sometimes go out. 

When we go inside, I feel calm in my kitchen. Then I remember my old teacher, Miss Tarrantine. She used to say, "I've had my moments." We all laughed.

**Heritage**

Heritage means the things we get from our past. It helps us feel connected to our history. We often know about our grandparents and their stories. Learning about our past helps us understand our future. Heritage is important because it gives us a sense of belonging. Just like we inherit our genes, we also inherit our culture from our families. Some parts of our culture may not be good, but they are still a part of us. Heritage teaches us many things and is important for our happiness. It includes our customs and the things we make. 

In the past, we learned about our history through stories from our ancestors. But now, many of these stories are lost. We can find clues about our past in old buildings and places. It is very important to take care of these places to remember our ancestors.

**The Fens**

I wrote a book called *Waterland*. In this book, I wrote about a place in England called the Fens. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and quiet. But when I learned more, I found out that the Fens are interesting and different. Many people in England think the Fens are strange, even though they are part of England. The Fens are both empty and full, both farmed and wild. 

I have not visited some places in the Fens, but I like to imagine what they are like. The Fens are not just a place; they are also a way of thinking.

**Museums**

Museums should make their collections easy to see and understand. In the past, they just put things in glass cases with long labels. Now, museums should be more interesting. They can use fun displays to catch people's attention. Museums should also help many different people. For example, they can give boxes of objects to teachers or help elderly people who forget things.

Museums show real items from history. This is their strength. They are different from theme parks or books. Museums that make their displays exciting will attract more visitors who want to see real history.

**Architecture and Environment**

Wanting to keep things safe is not new. But now, changes in our towns happen very fast. This makes some people want to protect old things. People who lived through big events, like wars, often want to keep things stable. If we need to preserve our history, planners should think about this. Change can be good if we learn to manage it. Changes in our towns show changes in our society, like how many people live there and what they need.

**Einstein**

If you ask people on the street to name a scientist, many will say Albert Einstein. His picture is used to sell things like computers and books. Most people do not know much about what Einstein did. They know he made theories called "relativity." These theories are famous but hard to understand. Einstein helped change how we think about science in the 20th century. Scientists wanted to understand the universe better by looking at how things like matter and nature work together. Einstein looked at basic ideas like time, space, matter, and energy. Before him, Isaac Newton said that stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein said that time and space are not fixed; they can change.

**Young Readers**

When we were kids, my sister Lydia and I did not like books that won prizes. We thought they were boring. Our mother did not like this and would say so. But our father would give us money for each chapter we read to make us read better books. He also gave us some special books for Christmas and birthdays, saying, "This Book is NOT Literature." We thought many of his books were for boys, but he did help us read some good stories and poems.

**Language**

Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851 that the start of human language is a secret and amazing thing. Many people have strange ideas about how language began. Charles Caller said in 1928 that early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. This sound is sad. Early humans made sounds when they were in danger, and some words today still show this, like "malaria" meaning "fever" and "mors" in Latin meaning "death." Many people thought these ideas were silly, but now, studying how language started is important. Language likely began in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. At first, people used speech to be friendly and to help in fights. Sharing information was not the main reason for language, which is different from what philosopher John Locke said.

**Writing Reviews**

Frank Kermode talks about writing reviews. Most reviews are short and do not last long. They have deadlines and must be a certain length. When they are published, they are only in the newspaper for a short time, like a day or a week.

People think that writing reviews is not very important. Many writers do it because they need money or because they cannot spend all their time on a big book. But writing reviews is a skill. It is different to write a short review of 600 or 800 words than to write a longer one of 6,000 or 8,000 words. 

A reviewer must think about who will read the review. Some readers just want a quick look, while others want to read a serious article. A good reviewer needs to know a lot about different topics and write in a way that is easy to understand.

Many reviewers also write other things. For example, the American writer John Updike writes novels and also writes reviews. He collects his reviews in books, even if they are short.

Some people think that less famous writers should accept that their reviews are not very important. But if they believe their best writing is in reviews, they should be proud of it. 

I have mostly worked in schools and written academic books. In English-speaking countries, it is common for the same people to write reviews and study literature. 

In the past, some academics did not like professors who wrote reviews. But now, it is more accepted. There are many reviews today, so many people can write them. 

I think this is good for readers because they can trust that the reviewer knows what they are talking about. It is also good for professors because it helps them remember to write clearly for everyone, not just for other professors. 

In the end, writing reviews is important, but it is usually a side job. You can only write good reviews if you are also doing something else well.

Ralph opened the door to his flat. It was dark and quiet. He felt a little happy to be home. Even after three years, he sometimes felt this way when he came back alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he was always excited to come home. He wondered what the flat had been doing while he was away. The flat felt like a safe place for him.

He thought he should worry about things like break-ins or leaks, but his flat was always waiting for him. It looked either clean or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as part of himself. He wanted to change it, but it stayed the same. Sometimes, letters piled up by the door, and the answering machine blinked when he got home. He was glad nothing was broken or damaged.

Ralph worked in a small office and looked forward to his quiet evenings at home. After a long day at work, he wanted to be alone. But when he got home, he often felt lonely. He wanted to feel like himself again, but he felt empty instead. He thought that his job was changing him and making him feel lost. 

At night, he would read or listen to music, but he started to wonder why he did these things. He felt confused and lost. He remembered a time when he felt stronger and more sure of himself. After university, he wanted to improve his life, but he just wanted to get by. He applied for jobs that his friends talked about, but he didn’t think he could find a job that would make him happy.

He went to one job interview and was happy to talk with Neil, his future boss. Neil offered him the job right away. Ralph was surprised to learn he was the only graduate who applied. He took this as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**

I went to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There were many people, ice-cream vans, and food stalls. The music was loud. Everyone was going to the racecourse. I pushed through the crowd to find a good place to watch. 

They made a special area for the race. It was not like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides of the ground where the goats would run. They tried to keep the goats in order. This was not easy because goats like to eat everything!

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I felt scared about the night. The canoe was wet, and we could not sleep in it. There were no places to stop, and we had not seen any villages since morning. In the dark, we used a flashlight to see the cliffs. But the flashlight batteries were low, and when we changed them, they did not work. 

We could not find a place to camp. After a while, Lesley saw a light far away, and we felt hopeful. But the light was just the moon shining on the water. Soon, we heard loud water, but we could not see it. We kept moving on.

**How to Be Presentation Perfect**

I am not good at making presentations, but I have to do it for my job. I want to be better and feel more confident. 

You are not alone. Making a presentation is different from running a company. Many people in charge need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you say. Show your passion and enthusiasm. 

You need to prepare well. Think about what you want to say and ask your colleagues what questions the audience might have. Start with something everyone can relate to, and then lead to your main point.

Some activities take time. You cannot hurry them. If you are late for a meeting, you can rush. But if you are too quick with mayonnaise, it will not be good. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, it will get worse. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things happen very fast, but others take a long time. 

We can get better at some things, like solving puzzles. But some things cannot be rushed. If you try to hurry them, they will not work well. For example, you cannot sleep well in a short time. 

We learn and think in different ways. Some ways are fast, and some are slow. There are three speeds of thinking. The first speed is very fast. Sometimes, we need to react quickly. For example, if you fall off a bike, your body knows what to do before you think about it. 

The second speed is thinking. This is when we solve problems and make decisions. A mechanic fixing a car or a student doing homework uses this kind of thinking. We call this 'intellect'. 

The third speed is slow. This is when we think in a relaxed way. We can think about things while we are resting or daydreaming. This slow thinking is also important. It helps us understand complicated problems. 

Sometimes, we need to take our time to think. If we are not sure about something, like where to go on holiday or how to manage a group of people, it is better to sit and think slowly. This kind of thinking is connected to creativity and wisdom. 

Scientists are now studying how our minds work slowly. They find that this slow thinking can help us understand things better. It can solve problems that are too hard for fast thinking.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**

I have been welcomed nicely. It is a friendly place with many people. There are about forty people here, like scientists and students. We all help each other. My French is okay for talking, but I cannot have fun conversations. I miss some words, and my phrasebook does not help me at breakfast. This is not a big problem, but at first, I felt shy. I was nervous at mealtimes. I did not know which table to sit at, and I felt scared when I spoke. I still smile a lot or feel nervous when people talk to me. I think I feel a little sad because I am not as confident as I was before.

**Elliot**

When I first met Elliot, I was a young writer. He did not pay much attention to me. He remembered faces, and when I saw him, he would shake my hand but did not want to be friends. If I saw him at the opera with important people, he would not see me. But then I became a successful playwright, and Elliot started to be nicer to me. One day, he invited me to lunch. I thought he wanted to get to know me better. After my success, I saw him more often.

**Alfred Hitchcock**

Alfred Hitchcock was a famous film director. He said he did not care about the story or the acting in his films. He cared about the pictures and the music. He believed that good films make people feel strong emotions, no matter where they are from. If a film is made well, people in Japan and India should react the same way. Hitchcock was very smart and knew a lot about making films. He wanted to make people scream with excitement. He focused on the film itself and how it can affect the audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**

Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. Thirty years ago, there were not many charts and books about astronomy. Telescopes were not very good. Now, we have many types of telescopes and equipment. Computers help us make charts and analyze observations. This is a great time for amateur astronomy. 

But, some things are not as good. Now, you may need to travel 80 km to find a dark sky. In the past, it was easier to see stars in cities. During the day, we see many airplane trails in the sky. These trails can last a long time and make it hard to see the sun and stars at night.

**Too Much Choice**

Today, we have too many choices. There are many things to do and many products to buy. People want the newest things all the time. Technology makes this faster. New products come out all the time, and it can be overwhelming. 

Having too many choices can make us stressed and tired. We want to find simple things that make us happy in a complicated world. But it is hard to simplify our lives when there are so many options. There are many brands of soap and cereal, and it is hard to keep track of everything.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, my family goes to McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This is a tradition from my grandmother. It is very important to us. We do not want anything to change this tradition. 

The people who stay at McAndrews Hotel are special. Some may think we are old-fashioned. I do not like the rude behavior of some shop workers today. I prefer polite service. I know many guests at the hotel because we have been coming here since we were children. When I see them, we only say hello. We respect each other's privacy, which is hard to find in hotels today.

**Othello**  
There is a play called Othello by Shakespeare. It is now in London. I wrote a bad review of it last spring. I said the actor Ray Fearon was too young for the role of Othello. I was wrong about his acting. He did a great job. The whole cast is great too. There are many memorable scenes. One scene is when Cassio plays games with other young officers, and it gets out of control. Another scene is when Iago starts to lose control. There is also a very sad scene when Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed. The play is exciting and full of tension. You should see it!

**Lake Vostok**  
In Antarctica, there is a place called Lake Vostok. It is under 4 kilometers of ice. This lake has been there for 25 million years without air or sunlight. Scientists want to explore this lake to find out what lives in it. They are very excited to learn about the secrets of Lake Vostok. 

**Scientists**  
Last week, I heard something interesting on the radio. Some scientists are thinking about why they want to be scientists. They want to know why we want to learn about everything. They think it is important to know if what they do is right. Science is a tool, and we should decide how to use it.

**Food**  
Food is very important to us. Many people who like to cook buy cookbooks. Sometimes, we think cooking is only for special days or fancy meals. But that is not true! You can make a tasty soup by putting chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and some herbs in water. This soup is better than buying a packet or a tin. You can also make a yummy dessert in five minutes that both kids and adults will enjoy. Cooking is a way to show care and love. Sharing food is special. We celebrate important days like birthdays and anniversaries with food. No one wants to eat takeout at a wedding!

**In the Elevator**  
This morning, Alistair tried to clean his office, but it was still messy. Papers were everywhere. He had many tax forms and other papers to organize. He knew Mallory would come on time for their meeting. She was always on time and liked things neat. He worried about what she would think of his messy office. His cleaning lady, Mrs. Wilson, came while he was trying to clean. He smiled at her, hoping she would help. But she looked unhappy and went into her own space, leaving Alistair to deal with his mess.

**Karen**  
Karen wanted to be different from her mother. She made her own story about strength. One important moment was when she was twelve years old. Her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she would go blind. But the doctor said she was okay. She only needed a few stitches. When she saw her mother in the doctor's office, she felt grateful and knew she was saved for a reason.

**Miss Fogerty**  
Miss Fogerty was walking quickly on the village green. She felt both happy and sad. She was excited to know something important in her small town, but she was also sad about Dr. Bailey's health. He had been her doctor for many years and always cared for her. She remembered how he helped her with her throat problems. Dr. Bailey made her feel like he had time to listen to her worries. This made him very loved in the village. He always gave his time, knowledge, and humor to others. Because of this, people were very loyal and cared for him.

**Joanna's Lessons**

Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. She plays music for many people. She also writes books for young children who want to learn the piano. 

At one concert for kids, a small boy asked her, "Can you play Match of the Day?" This surprised her. She thought it was funny. She played it, and the boy was happy. 

Joanna cares a lot about how children learn music. She has written a book called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World" for beginners. She is very busy with concerts and other projects, but she thinks teaching kids is important. 

Joanna believes that everyone should be able to learn the piano, just like swimming or speaking a little French. Some kids learn quickly, but others take more time. Some kids stop learning because they feel too much pressure from their parents. 

Joanna wants music to be fun. She thinks it is important for kids to enjoy playing. Her books have stories and music to make learning exciting. She wants children to play freely and try new things on the piano. 

She knows that practice is very important. Joanna practiced a lot when she was younger. Now, she loves to practice every day. She understands that some kids find it hard to practice, and she wants to help them. 

Joanna believes that learning music should be enjoyable, no matter how long you practice.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**

Dr. Johnson said that if writing is easy, people do not enjoy reading it. Good writing takes time and effort. When I look at my old school essays, I see that I did not make many mistakes. Now, I would change them many times. Writing by hand was hard, so I wrote carefully. When we use computers, it is easy to make mistakes. Many writers spend a lot of time fixing their work on the computer, just like they would with handwritten text. 

Emails are different from handwritten letters. Many people now write love letters by email. This is good because at least they are writing. But words on a screen can be boring. People often do not think carefully about what they write. They can make their words too strong or unclear. Writing quickly on a computer can lose the care that handwriting has.

**The CD**

I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not nice, but the shiny disc inside looked interesting. Mr. Warriston came back and said, "These are wonderful, aren't they?" I agreed and gave him the disc. He said, "It is amazing that they can fit seventy minutes of music on one." He turned on the music player, and lights came on. He opened a little drawer, put the disc inside, and closed it again. 

"Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. He looked surprised and said, "No, you only play one side." I asked why, and he thought for a moment. "I don't know," he said.
