I would love to visit Springs Hydro every month!

**NATURAL TALENTS**

Humans and chimpanzees are very similar. We share more than 98% of our genes. This means that the differences between us and animals are small and new. 

Many studies show that animals can do things we thought only humans could do. For example, chimpanzees use sticks to eat and to fight. Sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple sounds to warn each other about danger, like "leopard" or "snake." 

Art is one thing that seems special to humans. But it is strange that our ancestors did not make art for almost 7 million years. The first art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we cannot find these old things. The first clear art we have is from the Cro-Magnons, about 35,000 years ago. They made cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.

Some people say human art is different from animal art in three ways: 

1. Human art is not for survival. It does not help us live or have babies. Most animal behavior helps them survive. For example, birds sing to protect their homes or attract mates.

2. Human art is made for beauty. We do not know if birds enjoy their songs, but they sing mostly when they want to mate. This suggests they do not sing just for fun.

3. Human art is learned. Each group of people has its own art style. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from songs in Paris. People can learn from each other. But some birds are born knowing their songs. They sing the right song even if they have never heard it.

Human art changes quickly. For example, people can tell when a painting was made just by looking at it. But chimpanzees, like Congo and Betsy, also made paintings. Congo made many paintings in one day and was happy to do it. Their paintings were shown in a gallery in London in 1957, and many sold. 

So, the art of chimpanzees and humans is similar in some ways. Both are made for enjoyment, not for survival. Some people might say human art is different because it is meant to communicate. But sometimes, famous human art was made just for the artist's own pleasure.

**A Big Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is a very big and dangerous place. Charles Blackmore crossed this desert and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left in the world. In the past, stories were about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and narrow eyes looking into the distance. Now, we do not see these heroes in stories or in real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.

Charles Blackmore led a group to cross the Taklamakan Desert. The name means "once you enter, you never come out," but people also call it the Desert of Death. He talked about the dangers and excitement of this journey at his home. His team had four British people, one American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous.

They started to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating story about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He wanted to have fun and find out who he really was. His wife, Tina, was worried he would not come back because no one had done this journey before. It took them 59 days to cross the desert, and they were lucky.

In his story, Charles talks about how hard it was. They had stomach problems, very hot and cold weather, and they were very thirsty. They lost some of their water. But when they were very tired and the camels had no water for seven days, they found some. They did not have the big sandstorms or the freezing cold that could have stopped them. But they still had many problems. The sand got into their wounds, and climbing the high dunes was very hard for them and the camels.

Charles said, "What pushed me to keep going was the need to survive." They had no backup plan. No planes flew over them. Once they were in the sand, they were alone. He was scared about his strength to finish the trip. On the first day, it was so hot that he could hardly breathe. He thought, "We have to do this now!" He was very scared.

At the end of the journey, they felt different. After walking 1,000 kilometers, they could not stop. They were very thin but strong. Charles felt proud of his body. He could walk over anything.

In the middle of his story, Charles described lying in the desert and looking at the full moon, thinking about his family. He felt he was trying to find peace inside himself. When he has doubts now, he remembers the desert and feels proud of what they did. But he thinks about his family and the happiness they share. To him, that is more important than the desert.

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? He said, "I want the challenge and the open spaces. We felt good about our purpose. Now, it is hard for me to be part of normal life."

**Simplified Text:**

Susan Harr is tired of using too many gadgets. She decides to unplug them and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it makes life easier. But Susan thinks that we depend too much on it. 

One day, her computer broke. It cost a lot of money to fix it. This made her think that gadgets are not always worth it. She wonders if technology really gives us more time. Sometimes, it seems like we just buy more gadgets to do more things.

When her computer made strange noises, she put it outside. Now, she can take her time doing things without a noisy machine. She feels safer sewing by hand instead of using a fast sewing machine. 

Susan also learned that living without some gadgets can be nice. For example, she returned her color TV and now uses a small black-and-white TV. This helps her spend more time walking her dog, reading, and talking with family. 

She used to think sewing by hand was hard and boring. But now, she enjoys it. She can listen to the radio or talk to friends while she sews. It feels good to sit by the fire with a cup of tea and sew. 

Susan is now looking around her house and asking if she really needs all her gadgets. She thinks about saving money by not using things like the freezer or microwave. She is happy to do things by hand and enjoy life more.

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker. He makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he shakes my hand quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" He seems busy. The workshop has many pieces of furniture and wood in different colors. 

Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years. Many people know him and want his furniture. He does not advertise, but people say he is very good. If you want a nice cupboard, table, or bookcase, you should ask Hurst.

It is not hard to find a furniture-maker, but it is hard to find one like Hurst. He wants to make furniture that looks nice and is well-made. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now." He is not happy with some furniture that is made today. He thinks some furniture is not good and people should want better.

Hurst is very confident in his work. He says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned by asking questions and practicing. Most of his work is for private people, not companies. Some clients come back to him many times. He likes it when clients know what they want.

Hurst is also nice about other people. He says, "There are people far better than me." He does not like when some craftsmen take a long time to make one piece of furniture. He thinks furniture should be useful, not just for show. 

Hurst is confident, but he is also humble. He says, "After all, I am only making furniture," as I leave.

**Three Theories About Sleep**

People sleep for about one-third of their lives. Sleep is very important, but we do not know exactly why. Scientists have three main ideas about why we sleep.

The first idea says that sleep helps our bodies stay healthy. When we sleep, our bodies fix any damage from the day and help us feel better.

The second idea is about learning. This idea says that sleep helps us remember things we learned during the day. Without sleep, it is hard to learn new things.

The third idea is about energy. This idea says we need sleep to recharge our energy. When we sleep, we get ready for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us think, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits. For example, some people like to enter contests in newspapers, collect beer mats, or write letters to newspapers about many topics.

Being eccentric shows our individuality. Inside us, there are two forces. One is called individualism, which means being yourself. The other is conformity, which means following the crowd. Most people want to fit in and be liked. This desire is often stronger than the wish to be different.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find each other. They create clubs and meet to talk about what they like or their problems. They want to be with others who understand them, even if others think they are strange.

We all feel a struggle between wanting to be ourselves and wanting to fit in. Sometimes, we want to show our individuality. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think." Or a new person might say, "You must take me as I am." 

Anyone can choose to be more individual. Some people become very successful by being themselves. Bob Dylan, a famous American singer, said, "When you feel what you are doing, go for it and don’t give up. You will surprise many people." 

However, being different just to get attention is not true eccentricity. If a singer wears strange clothes just to be noticed, that is not eccentric. But if they keep being different for a long time, they may become eccentric. 

True eccentrics are not trying to be odd; they just are. They do not care much about what others think. They act based on who they are. This makes them different from people who want to impress others or escape from society. Eccentrics live their lives happily, no matter what others think.

**Natural Books**

We asked four nature experts to tell us about their favorite wildlife books.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy to choose the author. I am an environmental journalist, and I have met many important people in this field. One of them is Barbara Ward. She is a small, weak woman, but she is very important for environmental issues in Europe. She has combined her experiences into her own ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand many things. Choosing her book was harder. I could have chosen "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I think her most important book is "The Home of Man." It talks about the fast growth of cities and important themes in her life. It is a strong call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books, but none are as good as this one.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of seagulls and remember the smell of the sun. This book explains animal communication very well with words and pictures. If you read it and then watch a group of seagulls, you will see how they work together. Niko Tinbergen was a great scientist who wanted to share his ideas with everyone. He worked with a talented artist, Eric Ennion, to make this book interesting for all nature lovers. Eric's paintings show how birds act, like when one bird is aggressive and another is calm. This is the work of a true naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell has changed my life the most. It helped me find a wonderful husband and a great job in conservation. This book made me love the natural world. I was in Madagascar studying animal sounds when I first read it. I was feeling sad because of many problems, but when I read the book, I felt happy again. It shows animals and people together in a beautiful world. Some people think humans are bad for nature, but I remember Gerald as a boy, seeing all living things as a family. We need to understand this idea.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library when it was first published in 1966. I loved it right away, especially the beautiful pictures of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and learned to identify birds during my holidays. But "The Shell Bird Book" had so much more. It had amazing paintings, stories about bird migration, and even a chapter about birds in music and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature in many ways. It showed me that my feelings about nature are just as important as scientific facts. Since I was better at art than math, I saw a new path for myself.

**Do Reviews Help Sell Books?**

We asked five British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They look at reviews first in the newspaper. A study showed that many people buy a book because of reviews, more than because of ads or displays in shops. Authors feel sad when there are no reviews. Publishers also feel bad about bad reviews, but they think any review is good because it gets people talking about the book. Publishers like reviews that match their own feelings about a book.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both want good book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want to see their books reviewed well. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews to help readers find their books. Good reviews from trusted people can help sell more books.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. Many of the books we publish are not by famous authors, so we need reviews to help sell them. Good reviews are better than ads because they show the book is good without being paid for. Publishers say they want big reviews, but it is hard to know how much reviews help sales. Good reviews can help a book become popular, but they need help from other things like word-of-mouth and good marketing.

**Publisher D**  
I am not sure how publishing and reviewing work together in Britain. In the United States, one review can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops do not always pay attention to reviews. Sometimes it takes a long time for people to notice a good writer. Some books that get bad reviews still sell very well. It is hard to predict what will happen. Non-fiction books let reviewers talk more about the subject than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want great reviews. But do they help sell books? I published a biography with great reviews, but it did not sell well because people thought they could just read the reviews. The name of the reviewer can matter. Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people would buy it. Now, sometimes a surprising reviewer or a clever review can make people want to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**

Making weathervanes is an old skill. It started in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith makes weathervanes in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who makes them by hand. 

Graham creates special designs for his customers. He says, "This way, I can make a unique gift." Many of his customers are women. They want special gifts for their husbands that show their interests.

Most weathervanes have a cockerel design. But the first weathervane Graham made was a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make more. Graham saw that he could make many different designs.

Graham used to work as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed jobs. Liz went to work, and Graham stayed home to take care of the children and build his business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He enjoys the creative work of making weathervanes.

Graham has made over 100 original designs. He pays attention to detail and asks customers for their approval before he starts cutting. He also keeps some traditional designs because people like them too. 

Graham believes people like handmade things. They want something different. He does not want to make his business bigger. He wants to keep it a small craft. He enjoys seeing a simple shape turn into something beautiful.

For many years, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather. Now, more people are moving to the countryside. They want to add special touches to their homes. This helps crafts like Graham's business.

Graham is busy making weathervanes for customers all over the world. People from America and Denmark are interested in his work. The price of a weathervane depends on how detailed the design is. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was a very popular book. It is the first book by British writer Nicholas Evans. He earned a lot of money from it. Here, he talks about his ideas and success.

At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans had a hard time. He was a screenwriter and wanted to be a director. His film project, *Life and Limb*, did not work out. He was sad and worried because he had not made money for two years. He needed money to pay the bank.

A smart person would have found a job. Nicholas could have gone back to television. But he did something different. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months. He had an idea for the story from a farrier he met in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. The owners were very worried until they found a gypsy who could talk to the horse and change it back. These people are called "horse whisperers." 

Nicholas was very interested. He wanted to write a movie about it. But after his film project failed, he decided to write a book instead. He traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses. He felt alone and worried about his life. He had tried for ten years to be a filmmaker, but now he was in debt and worried about his family.

By the end of August, he had written half of the book. The bank was pressing him for money, and he needed to know if he should keep going. He showed the book to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Nicholas could get $30,000 for it. Nicholas needed more money to pay his debts. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and needed two more months to finish it.

In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the book to seven publishers in the UK. Soon, his agent called to say they had turned down an offer of $75,000. Nicholas was surprised. The agent felt something good was going to happen.

A week later, the book was sold for $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. This was a record for a first novel. Nicholas and his team were shocked. They had not sent the book to New York, but soon major movie studios wanted it too. 

Nicholas was offered $3 million for the movie rights. He was amazed. Four famous filmmakers called him to ask for the chance to make the movie. Nicholas decided not to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. He felt it was a fairy tale and did not want to spoil it. He wanted to write another novel instead.

**Bobby Fischer and Chess**

Bobby Fischer is a famous chess player. He is trying to come back to chess after being away for 20 years. Chess is now a game for younger players. Bobby is 49 years old. He played his old rival, Boris Spassky, and won the first game. But Bobby is not the same player he was in 1972. He is older and not as fit.

Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Now, many players are younger. Most of the top ten players in the world are under 30 years old. The game is also played differently now. Players prepare a lot before matches. They use computers to study many chess games. This helps them find ways to win.

A chess game can last a long time, sometimes up to eight hours. Players must stay focused. If they make a mistake, they can lose. There is a chess clock that makes the game more exciting. Players have to make their moves quickly, or they will lose.

Winning a game is very important. It feels great to win, but players must be ready to play again the next day. Chess tournaments can last for many days. Bobby Fischer loves chess. He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." If he is back for the money, he will earn a lot. But if he wants to prove he is the best, it could be very hard for him.

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, like poets and pop stars, who are becoming famous.

**A** Nick Grosso is a man in his 30s. He has written three plays that people like. Now, he is making one play, called Peaches, into a movie. He says, "It is low budget, but I don’t know how low. It will not be over £30 million, but it could be £30." Nick is very talented. Before he wrote Peaches, he had never been to a play or read one. He says, "When I wrote the play, I did not think it would be shown." The play is about people in a car. He left school at 16 but went back a year later. After finishing A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He wanted to write for actors. He liked being with people who thought like him. He enjoyed learning there.

**B** Simon Pegg is 28 years old. He studied drama at Bristol University. Now, he is writing a comedy show for TV. He just finished a long tour with comedian Steve Coogan. Simon worked hard from the start. He performed in comedy clubs while at university. He says, "University was very theoretical. I learned I did not want to be a serious actor. I like comedy more." He thinks comedy is not the hardest job. If you have courage and good ideas, it is great to make people laugh.

**C** Ciaran McMenamin is 24 years old. He became famous when he acted in a show called The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. People liked his performance. Now, he can choose what jobs he wants to do. He started acting in school and then joined the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. He jokes, "I used acting to avoid homework." He decided to take acting seriously because he liked it. Now, he waits for good things to happen. He says, "When you are 18, you think fame is great, but you learn it is not why you act. You act for respect."

**D** Neil Taylor is 25 years old. He is the lead singer of a pop band called Matrix. They just signed a deal to make three albums. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, hope their song, Chimera, will be a hit. Neil says, "The record company wants big sales, but I just want two people to buy it." He worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to get into music for eight years. He almost gave up when he met Rick, who helped him start Matrix. He had some hard times but hopes it will all be worth it.

**E** Stephen Richards is 27 years old. He is a poet and writer. He has won many awards. He is well-known in the poetry world and has been reading his poems for six years. His first novel, Hidden, will come out in March. It is about obsessive love. Stephen loved creative writing in school but did not like school later. He did not go to university at first but changed his mind after working in a theatre. He published his first book for children in 1992. His parents thought he would just read books, not write them. Now, he is brave to write novels. He wants to make sure his work is good and not just write a lot.

A. Isabel is a 31-year-old art student. She thinks she looks good in jeans, but she does not wear them often. She wants to find the right man but worries that her knees are not nice. Isabel is hopeful, and this helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a fun and lively way, with chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired."

B. This story is about a local radio station in America. A smart boy named Francis works at WLT Radio. The station was started by two men to promote their sandwich shop. Soon, the station plays music and has different people talking. The author uses humor to show life in a small town and takes readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time with old cars and radios.

C. In this story, a man named Richard talks to his wife’s ex-husband. Richard loves a Russian poet, but her poetry is not good. She wants Richard to help her brother, who is in jail. The author tells this story in a funny and clever way, making it enjoyable to read.

D. In London during the 1960s, two sets of best friends meet. One friend, James, is starting a newspaper, and his friend Richard is the editor. They both loved a woman who died years ago. The story has murder, love, and jealousy. It is a long book where you can really get to know the characters.

E. This story is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something. To make up for it, he takes care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is becoming a strange bachelor. The story shows Ian's loving relationship with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and funny book.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Some writers talk about international volunteer work. 

A. It is hard to say that volunteer work helps a lot. Volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot of money to do this work. If they gave this money to the local community, it could pay for more help than one volunteer can give. This is true for young people who take gap years. They often do not have special skills or experience. Many studies ask if young people volunteer to help others or to help themselves in their careers. But these projects can help people learn to be kind and help others in the future.

B. Volunteering can help people understand each other better. It can help solve problems and create connections between people from different countries. When this happens, both the volunteers and the local communities can benefit. But if only rich people can volunteer, it helps them more than the communities that need help. The volunteers will gain experience, but the local people may not get much help.

C. Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as a way for rich people to feel good about themselves. It can also be a way to give real help to communities. At its best, volunteering can help both the volunteers and the communities. It can also help people understand the problems of poverty and unfairness in the world.

D. Volunteer tourism is part of a trend where people want to help others. This can seem good, especially when people do not trust big governments or businesses. But it can also ignore the need for real change in poor communities. Volunteering can be a good thing, but when it is only seen as a way to help without understanding the bigger problems, it can miss the point. It is important to understand the real issues of poverty and inequality in the world.

**Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports

Many people listen to the radio in the morning. We often need an alarm to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one?

I tested five clock radios with Tom Granger, an inventor, and Paul Bridges, a broadcaster. One clock radio has a 'dual alarm function.' This means you can set two different wake-up times. One for work days and one for weekends. But who needs two alarms? 

This clock radio costs about the same as another one we tested. It has a cassette player, so you can listen to your own music. The radio quality is very good, but the clock radio is big, like a rugby ball. Paul said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also likes to book a wake-up call, just in case the alarm does not work.

This clock radio was voted the best. Paul said he loved it, but the clock sometimes got stuck at 4:00 PM. I liked the digital display with nice grey numbers on a green background. The snooze button is big, so you can press it easily when you are sleepy. 

The clock has a backup battery, so it still works if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. However, it was hard to set up. But when we finished, we felt cool and smart. 

Tom did not like one model with a built-in lamp. He said it was hard to use. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work. The light was not good for reading; it only shines on the clock. Paul thought the lamp idea was funny, but he said the radio was hard to tune.

Another model is very popular. It is bright and colorful. Tom and I liked it because it stands out. It was easy to set up without reading the instructions. But the alarm can go off 10 minutes early or late, which is silly. Paul thought this model was hard to use and not good.

The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom because it was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which is easier to set up. We all agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs

A hedgehog is a small animal. It has sharp spines on its body. You can find hedgehogs in many places in the world, but not in America or Australia. When a hedgehog is in danger, it can roll into a tight ball. The spines stick out to protect it.

Some hedgehogs live in the desert. They have fewer spines and may run away from danger instead of rolling up. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night. They sleep during the day under bushes or in holes in the ground.

Hedgehogs can hibernate, which means they sleep for a long time in winter. But not all hedgehogs hibernate. Some stay awake all year.

**Great Sportswomen Winning**

It is hard to be good at sports. Women have to work even harder than men. They train a lot and have little time for normal life. They make sacrifices. But they are winning and breaking records. Here are some amazing British sportswomen.

A. **Jill, 27, Skier**  
"I love to ski. It feels great to jump and land well, but it can be scary. Sometimes I feel sick or it is windy, but I keep going. I train for ten months each year, so I miss time with friends. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete together and are treated the same."

B. **Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else! I earn good money as a professional cyclist. I train for at least four hours every day. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."

C. **Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because few schools have rowing teams. Most girls start late, at 19 or 20. This makes it hard to be successful. But I love rowing and being fit. It is also fun to be with friends."

D. **Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I wanted to walk around the world. I didn’t know how big it was! Walking across Australia was very hard. I walked 50 miles a day with little sleep. I got the record! Some people think women are less likely to succeed, so they do not want to sponsor us."

E. **Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men think they are better drivers. When I do well, they ignore me. Being a woman in racing is hard. Men want to beat me, and I have had many accidents. It is tough to earn money, and I spend what I make on racing. More women are racing now, which is great!"

F. **Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 AM three days a week to swim. I need to sleep on other mornings. In the evening, I cycle or run. Sometimes I feel tired at work! I push myself hard when I race. Men and women usually compete together, but the news talks more about men. The prize money for women is less, but we are working to change that."

**Text: Meeting Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers a special day when he met the famous artist, Picasso. He was 78 years old and eating lunch in a restaurant in Cannes. Even from far away, you could see it was Picasso.

At that time, I was 18 years old. I was traveling in a van around Europe and Morocco. I had no money, so I found a job painting boats. But I loved to draw, and I had my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.

Picasso usually stayed at home and worked. So, I was very surprised to see him at a table with his wife and friends. My friend told me to ask for his signature. I was nervous, but I went over and introduced myself. To my surprise, he signed my sketchbook and even drew a fun line on the page.

I was very happy and thanked him. We started to talk, but Picasso did not speak much English, and my French was not good. An American woman at the table helped us talk. She called him "the Maestro." I told Picasso that I loved art and admired his work.

After a while, I went back to my boat to show my friend what I got. But my friend said, "Is that all? Go back and talk to him more!" So, I took my sketchbook and went back to Picasso.

I did not ask him if I could draw his portrait because I was afraid he would say no. Instead, I just stood there and started to draw. When Picasso saw me, he made funny faces to make it hard for me to draw. He acted like a clown, and I wanted to stop, but I kept going.

Finally, he sat still for me. I looked at him closely. He looked strong and young for his age. His eyes were bright and full of life. Even though he was with friends, he seemed alone and quiet.

The American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing. I felt shy and said it was not good enough. But Picasso wanted to see it. When I showed him, he smiled and nodded. Then he took my crayon and quickly drew a face on my paper. It was very different from my drawing!

I thanked Picasso and asked him to sign my drawing. The American lady said he said I already had his signature. I felt lucky to meet him and to have his attention. It was a wonderful day for me.

**Shopping Tricks**

Have you ever gone to a store and bought more than you planned? Stores use tricks to make you spend more money. 

A. **Fresh Food**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They put fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They may also have a bakery that makes the smell of fresh bread fill the store. The color green is often used because it makes people think of fresh food.

B. **Product Placement**  
Where products are in the store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to find out where people like to shop. They put popular items at eye level so people can see them easily. They also have special bins with discounts to attract shoppers.

C. **Moving Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place cheap items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by other tempting items. Stores may also put popular products far away, hoping customers will look for them and see other things to buy.

D. **Less is More**  
Some stores, like Next, show their clothes in a nice way. They do not put many items on the shelves. This makes the clothes look special, even if they are made in large amounts.

E. **Total Price**  
Shoppers often care more about the total price of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items to attract customers. They may sell some items at a loss to bring people in.

F. **Price Tags**  
In chain stores, shoppers notice prices more. For example, a blouse priced at £14.99 seems cheaper than one at £15. This also helps reduce theft because workers must ring up sales to give change.

G. **Lighting**  
Stores think a lot about lighting. Chain stores use lights that look like natural sunlight so customers can see colors well. Supermarkets use special lights to make fresh fruits and vegetables look better.

H. **Store Layout**  
Many stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the way to walk, and another shows where to buy things. Some stores use nice carpets to make shoppers feel welcome in sales areas.

I. **In-Store Ads**  
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of delicious food. In some places, shopping carts have screens that show ads for products while you shop. This is to catch the attention of shoppers and make them buy more.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington is a famous mountaineer. He climbed Mount Everest in 1985. He has also climbed in Britain and the Alps. He wrote many books, like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way."

Robin Knox-Johnston started his career at sea. In 1968-1969, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his boat, Sunhaili. He also set a record for sailing from New York to England in 10 days.

Chris and Robin went to Greenland to sail and climb. They wrote a book about their trip called "Sea, Ice and Rock." In 1979, Chris called Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to sail with him. Chris could teach Robin climbing, and Robin could teach Chris sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht.

They sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat. Chris and Robin went to the shore to practice climbing. The climb was hard, but Robin did well. Chris asked Robin if he had climbed before. Robin said no, so Chris showed him how to climb down. Robin wanted to use his arms like on the boat, but Chris wanted him to use his legs. Robin climbed down safely.

During this trip, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they go to Greenland together. Robin was a good leader. He asked everyone for their ideas before making decisions. Chris found sailing boring. He liked being on land more than being at sea. Robin liked sailing and fixing things on the boat.

When they reached Greenland, Chris had to lead the climbing. He worried about Robin's safety. Climbing the highest mountain in Greenland, called the Cathedral, was very hard. They climbed for 24 hours. On the way down, they were very tired. Robin trusted Chris and followed him. When it was too hard, they turned back. Robin was also worried about their boat.

On the way home, there was a small problem. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am for his turn to watch the boat, but Robin did not wake him. Chris felt Robin did not trust him. Robin quickly said that was not true. 

They enjoyed their trip to Skye, but they really got to know each other in Greenland. Chris found out that Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A Simple History of Apples**

Apples have been around for a very long time. They come in many colors, shapes, and sizes. But today, we might lose some of the old types of apples.

**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
People have eaten apples since ancient times. In Britain, they threw away apple seeds. Long ago, people found apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. They even saved apple halves for winter. These apples were small and wild, very different from the apples we eat today.

**Learning from the Romans (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. Some apples, like the dessert apple called Decio, came from the Romans. But many Roman apples did not grow well in Britain. British monks started to grow new types of apples.

**Popular Apples in the Middle Ages (1200)**  
In the 1200s, many apples became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a favorite dessert apple. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in markets. But bad times came with droughts and diseases, and fewer apples were grown. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent a man to France to learn more about apples. This man brought back many new apple types.

**Apples in New Lands (1750)**  
By the 1600s, apples were very popular in Britain. When people moved to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand, they took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. A man named Johnny Appleseed planted many apple trees in North America.

**New Apples (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree. He named the apple 'Delicious' because a judge said it was very tasty. Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She found a small tree and grew green apples that became very popular.

**Many Apples Today (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world. But most apples come from just a few types. Many of these apples look good but do not taste very good. Some old apple types are still grown by gardeners in the UK, but many have been lost in the US. People want to see more types of apples again. We should care about keeping different kinds of apples for everyone.

Join us for an adventure that you will never forget!

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the best 10,000-metre runners. He visits a training camp in Kenya. This camp is in the mountains, ten miles south of the equator. The camp is near Mount Kenya, which is the highest mountain in Kenya. Richard has trained in Kenya for three years, but he has never trained with Kenyan runners before.

On his fourth trip to Kenya, Richard decided to train with the Kenyan runners. He ran in his first race in Kenya. He was invited to the training camp by the Kenyan national team coach after he finished fifth in a big race. This was a great chance for him.

Training in the mountains helps runners because it makes their bodies better at using oxygen. Many Kenyan runners are very successful because of this training. Richard's first race in Africa was special because it was the first international cross-country race in Africa. In this race, many runners finished ahead of him, and most of them were Kenyan.

Kenyan runners are known for their simple way of training. They run easily, eat simple food, and enjoy competing. Richard learned how they train at the national team camp. The camp is at St Mark's College, high up on Mount Kenya. The athletes live in simple rooms with other students. 

Every day, they have three training sessions: a morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the afternoon. They start their day early, at six in the morning. The total distance they run each day is about 40 kilometres, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometres.

Life at the camp is simple. They wash their faces and brush their teeth before breakfast. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar, with ugali (a maize dish), stew, and vegetables. After running, they go to a stream to wash.

By the end of his stay, Richard understood more about why Kenyan runners are so successful. It is not just because of their genes or the high mountains. It is also about their simple life, hard work, and love for running. These things help them become great runners.

**Simplified Text:**

Advertising is not doing well. This problem started in 1989, before the economy got bad. Advertising is not keeping up with changes in the economy. Advertisers think about big groups of people, but now there are many different groups. Even big brands should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not.

Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands. You may only buy a few well-known brands. In a year, you probably buy about 400 different brands. But there are many more brands advertised, about 32,500. Most people only buy a small number of these brands.

When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy. Most people find that they only buy from 1 out of 16 ads. This means that many ads are not useful for them. Many people think they are different and do not pay attention to ads, but this is not true. Most people do not buy the brands they see in ads.

Advertising can be wasteful. Not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. However, advertising can still be effective. It can reach many people, and some will respond. Advertisers cannot know who will buy their products, so they need to reach a lot of people.

If an advertiser knows who will buy, they can talk to them directly. For example, if an ad can get one million new customers, that is very good. A successful ad campaign can reach a small part of the population. To be successful again, advertising needs to focus more on specific groups of people.

**Simplified Text:**

Charles Clover visits a very green home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This place has two interesting things. First, it has Southwell Minster, a little-known old cathedral with special carvings of 'green' men. Second, it has the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. 

The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking. They recycle waste into compost for their garden. They also heat their home using heat from their appliances and their bodies, plus the heat from their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. 

The house looks traditional with a clay roof and is near the Minster. It is very quiet inside because it has special windows that keep out noise. When you enter, you must take off your shoes. Inside, it is calm and warm. The windows are closed, and the conservatory helps warm the air. 

Robert opens windows to let fresh air in. The house is designed to keep out drafts. The Vales care about the environment and wrote a book about green homes in the 1970s. They wanted to build a house that does not harm the environment. They do not use city water and have special toilets that use compost. They also have tanks for rainwater and filters for drinking water. 

The Vales do not pay for water. Last winter, they used very little electricity, much less than a normal four-bedroom house. Soon, they will add solar panels to make even more electricity. They will still use some electricity from the city for cooking. 

In winter, they only use a small wood stove to stay warm. One night in February, Robert said it was too warm to use the stove. The temperature was 18C, which is comfortable for them. The house is designed to keep the heat in, so it feels warm even when it is cooler outside. 

The house is simple and easy to build. It cost the same as low-cost homes. Many building companies do not want to build homes like this.

Text: 'The Camera Can Lie

Arthur Conan Doyle made the Sherlock Holmes stories. He thought he was a smart man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw pictures of fairies in a garden. He believed these pictures were proof that fairies are real. He wrote an article and shared the pictures, saying fairies are wonderful.

But in 1939, the two women who took the pictures said they were fake. They cut out fairy pictures from a book and put them in flowers. The pictures are very pretty. But this simple trick shows that photography can lie. 

Today, we can change pictures with computers. It is not true that photography was always honest. From the start, cameras changed what we see.'

**Blacksmiths**

For a long time, people have been interested in iron. Blacksmiths are the workers who shape iron. In the past, blacksmiths were very important. They made weapons, armor, and tools for farming. People thought they were as important as doctors. 

In the 1700s, blacksmiths made beautiful ironwork for buildings like St Paul's Cathedral. But by the late 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths left in Britain. Big factories did not need them anymore. Many new buildings did not use nice ironwork.

In the last 10 years, blacksmithing has become popular again. People like decorative buildings and new designs. However, some of the new work looks old-fashioned. Many shops sell items that look like they are from the past.

There are events to help blacksmiths. One event is an exhibition of ironwork by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA). It opened last week in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says this could be a new time for blacksmiths. They can now use power tools, which make their work easier. 

About 250 pieces of ironwork are in the show. They include bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most money will go to the blacksmiths, but some will help the Association.

Alan Dawson has made a big gate and a lamp. He says working with hot steel is like drawing with metal. Many artists love working with iron. It is soft when hot but hard when it cools down. 

Ann Catrin Evans makes door knockers and handles. Some of her designs look like things from scary movies. She likes that steel feels cold and strong. 

Iron is a special metal. It can be used for beautiful things for many years to come. But let’s hope we don’t see any more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Stopped Smoking**

I stopped smoking, and I thought my friends would be happy. But one friend was very angry. She asked, "What do you mean? If it was easy, why didn’t you stop before?" I could not explain how I stopped. It was strange for me too. 

I went to a stop-smoking class two months and three weeks ago. I did not plan to stop smoking. I did not really want to stop. I felt pressure from people who do not like smoking, and I still feel that way. My family is healthy, and I did not feel sick. I thought I was fine.

That Thursday, I went to the class to write about it. I said, "I will not stop smoking. I am here to write, not to stop." I liked smoking. It made me happy. The teacher looked at me like she knew something. We could smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was full of smoke. 

When I was told to smoke, I did not want to. The messages about stopping smoking made sense to me. I started to think that stopping could be good. I felt strong. 

Stopping was not hard. The need for cigarettes went away after a few days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it was easy. The hardest part was being at home on weekends. I realized that smoking helped me not feel bored. 

I miss smoking a little, but not too much. Now, I have to think about what to do in new situations, like eating out or waiting for a plane. Before, I would smoke in these moments.

Dorothy Hodgkin is a very important British woman scientist. She won the Nobel Prize, but many people do not know her name. For four years, I have asked my friends if they know about her. If they do, I am happy. 

Dorothy Hodgkin is special because she is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize. She died in 1994. She studied crystals and had a very interesting life. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like better education for women and the growth of science around the world.

When I started to learn more about her, I wanted to read about other scientists. I looked for a book about Linus Pauling, who was a friend of Dorothy. He was also a famous scientist and won Nobel Prizes. But I could not find any books about him in the bookshop. I was surprised because he was very important.

Some people think that stories about scientists are boring. A famous scientist, Peter Medawar, said that the lives of scientists are not interesting. This makes it hard for people to see scientists as interesting people. 

But now, more scientists are showing their personalities. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives prizes on TV, and Steve Jones advertises cars. This helps people see scientists as real people.

Books about scientists are also changing. They used to be very serious and not fun to read. But now, books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?" are funny and interesting. Famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Marie Curie are now shown with their personal lives too.

Dorothy Hodgkin worked very hard. She found out how penicillin and vitamin B12 are made, which won her the Nobel Prize in 1964. She also helped find out how insulin is made. She had three children and a husband who was often away. Her personal life is important, and we can learn from how she balanced everything.

Understanding science can be hard, but it is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language. It just takes time and effort. It is sad that many educated people do not know about great scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

**Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers need her help because their wells are dry. Margaret and her husband have a business that drills wells. They use machines, but Margaret only needs her stick to find water. She is very good at it, with a success rate of over 90%.

This skill is called dowsing. Some people think it is a special ability. There are many ideas about how it works. One idea is that everything vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers say they can feel or smell water.

In recent years, many farmers have asked for Margaret's help. She usually sees each customer only once because wells last a long time. Some of her customers have holiday homes far away and do not want to pay for long water pipes. Others are building golf courses.

Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She must be careful to avoid waste getting into the water. The water she finds is clean, but she must watch for minerals like iron.

To find water, Margaret first looks at a map. She uses a pendulum, which swings over areas with water. Then, she walks with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels something strange. She uses the stick to find the best place to drill. If the stick rises, it means water is below.

Margaret and her husband check the same area. If they do not agree on where to drill, they keep looking until they do. 

Margaret's skill is interesting to many people. She calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment." This means she has a special way of understanding where water is. Thanks to her skill, she and her family can keep their well-drilling business going year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**

Have you ever wanted to live someone else's life for a day? Four people did this! Here are their stories.

**Amanda's Story**  
Amanda is 23 years old and has two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy restaurant in London. Amanda went to the restaurant and was surprised. It was dark, loud, and full of people. It was very different from her quiet home. 

Amanda had to learn how to carry drinks on a tray. It was hard! She dropped the drinks, and they spilled everywhere. Everyone laughed, and Amanda felt embarrassed. When the restaurant opened, there was a long line of customers. Amanda was nervous but happy that the orders were easy to remember because they were on a computer. 

After a few hours, her feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to handle. She had to ask customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift, she was very tired. She realized that being a waitress is not easy. She was glad to go back to her children because being a mom felt easier after that day!

**Cindy's Story**  
Cindy is 30 years old and was nervous about being a mom for a day. She had to take care of Amanda's two daughters. First, she dressed them and took them to school. She thought she would have some quiet time, but she was wrong! 

Cindy had to clean the house and do laundry. After picking up the girls, they played and made a mess. They were very loud! Cindy tried to relax, but the girls had too much energy. It was hard to get them to bed. They kept asking for water so they could come downstairs to watch TV. 

Cindy learned that taking care of children is very tiring. She enjoyed the day but felt very responsible for the girls.

**Rosemary's Story**  
Rosemary is 42 years old and runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, who is 30 and a teacher. Rosemary got to sleep in a little longer, which was nice! At school, she felt nervous in front of many students. 

She helped the children with their work and even did a fun nature project. But she was tired by lunchtime. Teachers have very little time to eat. After lunch, she had to help with sports and teach a French lesson. Speaking in front of the class was hard for her. 

Rosemary decided she liked farming better than teaching.

**Hilary's Story**  
Hilary is 30 years old and went to Rosemary's farm early in the morning. She found out that Rosemary had been working for hours already! The farm has many animals, and Hilary helped in the ice-cream shop. 

She bottled milk and made ice cream. At lunchtime, she checked the sheep and helped feed the calves. Milking the cows took a long time, and Hilary felt lonely without children around. 

Hilary learned that farming is hard work. It is not as easy as it seems, and farmers have to work every day. 

These four people learned a lot by swapping lives for a day!

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. Many musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a special trumpet player from southern Sweden. He is 30 years old and is known all over the world. He plays old music and new music. When you see him, he looks young and happy, just like the sound of his trumpet.

When Hakan was eight years old, his father gave him a trumpet for Christmas. His father liked Louis Armstrong's music, so he bought a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved the trumpet and played it all the time. His mother found a trumpet teacher for him. The teacher, Bo Nilsson, saw that Hakan had talent. Hakan is thankful for having such a good teacher.

Hardenberger says that the trumpet is not a perfect instrument. Every trumpet has some mistakes. He learned to understand these mistakes and work with them. Even when he was a boy, people could recognize his special sound.

Unlike another famous trumpet player, John Wallace, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired a French trumpet player named Maurice Andre and wanted to be like him. Hakan's parents supported his dream to play the trumpet.

At 15, Hakan needed to choose where to study. He could not go to America, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra was not for him. Hakan knew he played better than many other young players. 

When he was 17, he entered a competition in Paris. He only prepared some pieces but made it to the second round. In the final round, he faced a hard piece. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed playing. He realized that people listened to him, even if he thought he played badly.

Hardenberger is honest about his music. He does not want to explain his special talent because he believes it might change it. He thinks music has the power to move people.

**New In Paperback**

A. The book is about a man named Tristan Smith. He lives in a made-up country called Efica. The story talks about power, history, and humor. The author has made a special world with its own history and customs. The book is funny and shows how people think and feel. It is a little hard to read, but it is worth it.

B. Harriet is a woman with a good job and a husband who is an architect. She meets Sheila, a woman who takes care of her old father and her grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo hurts Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys do not want to talk about what happened. Leo was a good student and never fought before. He does not say why he did it. Joe gets better but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son and takes care of him all the time. Sheila feels very guilty and wants to meet Harriet. This meeting helps them become friends. The author shows how people react when bad things happen in their lives.

C. This book is about a small island in Scotland and its people. It tells the story of a boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He disappears for a while and comes back after the Second World War. He learns to appreciate the simple life of his ancestors.

D. The author has written a new book after a big success. It is about a woman named Aurora Greenway. Fifteen years after her daughter died, she is now almost seventy. Aurora is still charming and a little vain. Her friend Rosie helps her with life and relationships. By the end of the book, Aurora sees that time has passed and new people are coming into her life. The author shows the sadness that can be under normal life.

E. Six different people go on a boat trip in the South Pacific with a rich man named Logan Urquhart. The author writes beautifully about their journeys of self-discovery. Each person learns something new about themselves while sailing on the ocean. The author uses strong images to show ideas about memory and awareness. These images can be strange but also enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs. They share what they like, what they don’t like, and what they do every day.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am. I go to the gym at 7:00 am. I get to work by 8:00 am and start surgery at 8:30 am. I do surgery on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes, I work for ten hours without eating or going to the bathroom. It can be stressful to decide when to operate. I feel okay when I am operating, but I worry about the next day. Brain surgery is very important for patients. When it works, it is great, but sometimes it does not work. From 10:00 am to 1:00 pm, I talk to patients about their operations. I like this part of my job. I leave work between 6:00 pm and 8:00 pm. Sometimes, I have to work at night or on weekends. I think about my patients even when I am on holiday."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am and leave home by 8:20 am. I take the train to work and arrive at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to talk about our work. I work with a team of people. I spend three to four weeks designing projects. After that, I show my ideas to the client. If they like my ideas, we make plans and start working with photographers and illustrators. I have to talk to many people and make sure everything is done on time. I eat lunch at 1:00 pm. I usually get home at 7:30 pm or later. It is hard for me to relax after work."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:00 am most days. Some days, I wake up very early to meet flights. I like to ride my bike or swim in the morning. I eat a big breakfast and have snacks during the day. I need to know good restaurants and shops for my passengers. Some passengers are rude, but most are nice. I work seven days a week and up to fifteen hours a day. I try to go to bed by 11:00 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:00 am and leave home at 7:30 am. I work in gardens that I designed. I spend about an hour and a half at each garden. At 11:00 am, I go to a café for breakfast. In summer, I work until 10:00 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I listen to messages when I get home. I help people design their gardens in the evening. I use old materials to make gardens look nice. It is hard to relax at night because I hear my work phone."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at work by 8:30 am. I help build bridges and walls. I check that the workers are doing their jobs safely. I talk to the workers and solve problems. I usually have lunch from 2:00 pm to 2:30 pm, but I often eat while I work. I leave work at about 6:00 pm, and I am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Work Day**

A. **Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and go to work by 7:30 am. I help customers who use our credit cards. I talk to card users and try to get new ones. I also work with other companies. I spend the first 45 minutes planning my day and then I check my emails. I have many meetings during the day. I also travel to different places in Europe to meet with customers. I finish work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

B. **Record Company Executive**  
I start work at 10:00 am. I check the mail and listen to music tapes from new artists. I have meetings to talk about music projects. I help choose songs and work with the band to make their first album. I also manage money for the projects. I leave work at 7:00 pm and often go to concerts at night. I sometimes get home very late, around 1:00 am.

C. **Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work to arrive at 9:30 am. I check the mail and see if we have clients visiting. I enjoy showing furniture to customers and selling it. We sell old furniture that we buy from different places. I also talk to people who fix the furniture. I read a magazine about antiques while I drink coffee. I do the accounts once a month and go home at 5:30 pm.

D. **Air Traffic Controller**  
I leave home at 6:00 am for my early shift. I start work at 7:00 am and control airplane movements. I work in a team with other controllers. In winter, we manage about 1,000 flights a day. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read during that time. This job is stressful, and I want to be a manager one day.

E. **Shop Manager**  
If I work early, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start the cash register and help customers find books. I enjoy helping them, but sometimes it can be hard. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, I meet with book publishers to talk about new books. I finish my early shift at 5:45 pm. Sometimes I work late and close the shop.

F. **Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then I get up and take a taxi to work by 8:45 am. I talk to reporters to learn about news in my area. I help companies understand financial risks. I write reports and send them to my editor. I travel to Africa a few times a year for work. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Be a Good Leader**

A. What is a good leader? A good leader is someone who inspires others. They help people and show them the way. Being a leader is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about work, says that a leader makes things happen with the help of enthusiastic people. A good leader speaks clearly and confidently. They say "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. John van Maurik, who teaches about leadership, says that many people can be good leaders. We all have the ability to lead; we just need the right situation to grow. It is easy to see great leaders like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, but it can be hard to see leadership in our own jobs. However, being a good leader is very important for good management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. Both may have done their jobs well, but how did they do it? The best boss motivated you and helped you. The worst boss made you feel small and blamed you when things went wrong. The first boss led well; the second boss did not.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within rules. Leaders create new ideas. A good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a sad company into a happy one.

E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can be a better leader. Here are some tips:
- Leadership is best when you want to do it. Find what you care about and use that energy to lead.
- Think of yourself as a leader. You have the power to lead.
- Sometimes you need to lead strongly. Try different ways of leading. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try making decisions yourself. See how this changes things.
- Set goals and try to reach them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you.

F. Leadership does not just happen. You need to take the lead, take risks, and learn from mistakes. Learn to share tasks, motivate others, and give praise. 
- Don’t think everyone will like your way of leading right away. Keep working on how you communicate. You don’t have to be liked, but your ideas should be good.
- Be present and available for important people. 
- Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when you can help others become leaders.

**Films on Video**

**Film critic Nick James reviews some recent movies.**

**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron made a movie called Abyss. It is a tense story about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The characters are brave and funny, reminding us of heroes in other movies. The special effects are very good, but the dialogue and characters are not great. The story feels like a simple B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This movie is based on a book about the battle for Guadalcanal. It is directed by Andrew Marton. This version is different from another film by Terrence Malick. Marton’s movie is more like a traditional war film. It focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. Malick’s film is more artistic, but Marton’s version has some good moments, like when the soldier dreams of his wife.

**C. On Guard**  
This movie is based on a book from 1875. It is a fun swashbuckler story about musketeers. The villain is played by Fabrice Luchini, who is a bad politician. Vincent Perez is the hero, and Daniel Auteuil plays a swordsman. The film is funny and entertaining, even with some old clichés.

**D. Character**  
This movie is set in Rotterdam a long time ago. The costumes and details make it look very old-fashioned. Jan Decleir plays a cruel bailiff named Dreverhaven. He has a bad relationship with his son. The film focuses on this relationship, but it spends too much time on the details.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This movie is being re-released. It shows the director Leone's skills very well. The sound is great, and you can hear everything clearly. The story is harsh, and the characters, played by Clint Eastwood, Lee van Cleef, and Ell Wallach, are all not very good people. They are all bad in their own way.

**F. The Longest Day**  
This is a long war movie with many famous actors. It has four directors and many extras. The beginning of the movie is slow, as soldiers wait for news about an invasion. It is impressive in some ways, but it is better to watch on a big screen. Watching it on video is not as good.

Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He left his job to go backpacking. He wants to travel in South East Asia for a year. Tim feels nervous about this decision. He has traveled before, after university, he went backpacking in North and South America. After that, he got a job, fell in love, and bought a flat. He felt he was losing his happiness for his job. When he quit his job, he felt free again.

Many of Tim's friends are married and have children. They do not want to change places with him, but they wish they had his freedom. Tim is not in a relationship and does not have big career goals. He feels he should enjoy his freedom for his friends.

Tim is nervous because he has to make plans. He worries about renting his flat and where to go. He is also behind on his plans. He thinks about staying in England for the summer and watching football.

Tim knows many people in their late twenties and thirties want to travel. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says more people are realizing they can travel if they want. They just need to be brave and organized.

Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny is ready to give up job security for this trip. He knows he might return to the same job, but he thinks it is worth the risk.

Matt, who just left the Army, traveled for a year to change his life. He wanted to learn to live differently. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says more people work on short-term contracts now. If a contract ends, they have nothing to lose.

Dan Hiscocks from Travellerseye says many people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. If they are not happy, they want to change. Travel helps them think about what they want.

Jennifer Cox believes this is not a sign of not wanting to grow up. It shows that people want a balanced life. Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher, is going to Central America for a year. He wants to find things for himself, but he is also worried about leaving his routine.

Tim feels the same way. He is not sure he would travel if he had not had a bad experience at work. Jennifer Cox says many people travel after a big change in their lives, like a breakup or losing a job. 

Tim is excited about the next 12 months. He wants to enjoy life and make the most of his adventure.
