Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job as a journalist. She felt lost because of new technology. She wanted to change her home into a good place to work.

Last Christmas, Georgina turned 37. She thought she needed to start her journalism career again. She looked at her resume and saw it was old-fashioned. She used to type on a typewriter, and now computers were everywhere. She felt scared to use a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads asked for skills in desktop publishing, but she did not have these skills. She thought it would be easier to learn about nuclear physics than to use a computer.

Georgina thought it would be hard to leave home to work. But then, she won a computer in a local newspaper contest. Her family got a laptop for her husband and a personal computer for everyone. They started to learn about the Internet and how to chat with people online. The children stopped watching TV and helped Georgina set up a small office in the kitchen. She had a phone, a fax machine, and a modem to connect to the Internet. This helped her work from home and take the kids to school.

The children were good with computers, but Georgina was nervous. She thought she would lose her work if she pressed the wrong button. But she learned the basic skills. It was easier than she thought. She started writing articles for a magazine and felt happy to work from home.

The computer helped Georgina stay organized. Before, her desk was messy, and she lost important papers. Now, she uses spreadsheets to keep track of money and saves time with ready-made invoices. The Internet helps her find information for her stories and talk to other journalists.

However, working from home has some problems. Georgina sometimes feels lonely. There are also distractions at home, like chores and the kids wanting to use the computer. Many people in her neighborhood are also using computers for work, so they do not have to travel to the city every day.

A report says that many home workers are educated and own personal computers. Georgina feels she is doing well. One day, she hopes to send her articles to a newspaper in Australia or even start her own magazine. She believes the possibilities are endless.

**The Tartan Museum**

The Tartan Museum is in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has a modern design with big, yellow stone walls and a tall tower. Many people have different opinions about the building. Some think it is beautiful, while others do not like it.

The museum has many interesting things to see. It tells stories about Scotland's history. There are important items, like jewels from Mary Queen of Scots. The museum wants to show the truth about the past, not just what people imagine.

Dr. David Clarke is in charge of the exhibitions. He wants everyone to enjoy their visit, even if they do not know much about history. The museum has many displays with explanations and pictures. There are also computers to help visitors learn more.

Inside the museum, there are many different rooms. Each room is a different size and shape. The walls look like big stones, and there is a lot of light coming in from the windows. Visitors can take their time to look at everything.

There is a special area for children called the Discovery Centre. A group of kids helped create this space. They wanted to have fun and learn at the same time. The top floor has a gallery that changes every three years. It shows items that are important to Scottish people, like electric guitars and toys.

Dr. Clarke believes that objects can tell stories about the past better than anything else. The museum is beautiful inside, but some people wonder if it is in the right place.

Text: 'The end of print may take some time. Change can be scary for some people. But change also means moving from one place to another. For newspapers, this change is going online. This is not easy. Many people think it will happen, but it is not clear how. 

Print newspaper sales are going down. More people are visiting newspaper websites. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen sales drop by 8% to 10%. But their websites are getting more visitors. 

A survey shows that last year, the number of newspapers sold around the world went up by 1.1%. In the West, sales went down, but in Asia, they went up. Some magazines also did well, with a 5.4% increase in sales. 

E-readers like Kindle are very popular now. But when bookstores looked at their sales of physical books, they found that sales only went down by 0.4%. This means people still buy both types of books. 

Many young people still read newspapers. In fact, nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 read the main newspapers in the UK. Different countries have different stories. In Britain, sales dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, it was only 7%. In France, it was 3.1%. 

In the past, people thought online ads would help newspapers. But now, online ads are going down. Many US newspapers have started charging for online access. The best way to get readers is to offer both print and online access together. 

Print newspapers are still important for selling online subscriptions. They make much more money from print ads than from online ads. But it is hard for newspapers to keep both print and online versions. They need to work hard to be seen online.'

**Taking Pictures of People**

People are very interesting to photograph. A picture with a person is usually better than one without. But taking good pictures of people can be hard. You need to think about how they move, their faces, and their feelings. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.

**A. Grouping People**  
When taking pictures of a group, do not make them stand in a straight line. Ask them to stand at different angles and heights. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all their faces.

**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by finding a comfortable position. You can suggest they put their hands in their pockets or fold them.

**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, but they might feel shy. You may need to help them feel comfortable.

**D. Eye Contact**  
A picture looks better if the person looks at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They do not have to smile. If they look away, remind them to look at the camera again. You can also say something funny to get a real smile.

**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking at the camera, the person can look at something else in the picture. This can make the picture feel more natural. Candid shots can show real feelings.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
The way a person looks and moves tells us a lot about them. A happy child can make us smile, while a sad face can make us feel sad. Look for different expressions like smiles, frowns, or thumbs-up.

**G. Situation Interest**  
The background of a picture can add more meaning. Make sure the background does not take attention away from the person. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person look bigger than the background.

**H. Interaction**  
Good pictures can happen when people are talking, laughing, or working together. Look for moments when people connect, like a handshake or a smile.

**I. People and Places**  
Many pictures of people are taken on trips. To show both the person and the place, step back to get everything in the frame. Make sure the people are close to the camera but not blocking the background.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Think about why you want to take the picture. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose nicely. But for family pictures, candid shots of fun moments are often better than stiff poses. A spontaneous picture can bring back good memories later.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is an artist. She makes special paintings called trompe-l'oeil. These paintings look real, but they are not. Joanna Watt interviews her.

Sarah does not like to sign her paintings. She thinks the painting is more important than the artist. She says, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is shy and does not like to talk about herself. When Joanna asks to take her picture, Sarah covers her face.

After a while, Sarah feels better. The interview becomes fun and interesting. Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She learned to draw at art school and worked at a publishing house. But she wanted to do something different. She worked with a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to make one trompe-l'oeil painting, and she loved it. She started her own work, not knowing what would happen, but she felt good about it.

Sarah is very good at observing details. She says, "People ask me where to learn trompe-l'oeil, but no one can teach you. It's all about observation." She is still learning and says, "If you think you know everything, you should stop."

Sarah is honest about her mistakes. She says, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete." Once, she had to measure a big ceiling for a castle. She got confused and thought, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?"

Sarah often talks about herself in a funny way. She says, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'" Her trompe-l'oeil paintings are very special. Many people want her work in their homes and businesses.

Some of her paintings are inspired by buildings. For example, she made a trompe-l'oeil dining room that looks like a beautiful Italian building. She also painted a hallway that looks like it has two more rooms.

Sarah knows that trompe-l'oeil must do two things. First, it must trick you. Second, it must keep your attention and make you think. She believes that her work should also be personal for her clients. She enjoys talking to them and getting their ideas. Many of her clients become her friends.

Sarah is thankful for her clients. She says, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They are happy with her work, and that is why she is always busy. She does not like to talk about herself too much. She says, "I really don't like to shout about myself." 

Sarah's work is quiet and beautiful. You can never get bored with her or her paintings. They deserve to be known by more people.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman talks about important skills for success at work.

A. The rules for work are changing. Now, we are not only judged by how smart we are or what we know. We are also judged by how we manage ourselves and how we work with others. This is important when companies decide who to hire or promote. These new rules help show who will do well at work and who may not. They focus on skills that are important for getting jobs in the future. Doing well in school is not enough anymore. We need to have good social skills and personal qualities, like being friendly and understanding others. This is called emotional intelligence.

B. Today, many jobs do not offer security. Instead of having one job, we need to have skills we can use in different jobs. Personal qualities are very important at work. Emotional intelligence means being aware of our own feelings and the feelings of others. It helps us think and act better. It includes being aware of ourselves, controlling our feelings, being motivated, understanding others, and having good social skills. Some people think emotional intelligence just means being nice. But sometimes, it means being honest, even if it is hard. It is not about showing all our feelings. It is about managing our feelings so we can work well with others.

C. More companies are realizing that emotional intelligence is very important for good management. In jobs that are not simple, emotional intelligence is even more important. If someone lacks these skills, it can make it hard for them to use their knowledge. Many people have succeeded without strong emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex, companies that work well together have an advantage. In today’s work environment, where teamwork and good customer service are important, emotional intelligence is essential for success in every job.

D. Unlike IQ, which does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from our experiences. Studies show that most people get better at managing their feelings and understanding others over time. This growth is called maturity. We can learn emotional intelligence and use these skills to help us in our jobs. This is important now, as jobs are less stable. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies, but if we ignore it, other things may not work well.

**Ancient Chinese Medicine: Acupuncture**

Acupuncture is a type of medicine from China. It is over 2,000 years old. Acupuncture is part of traditional Chinese medicine. This medicine also includes herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Many doctors in the West use acupuncture to help with pain.

**What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?**

In traditional Chinese medicine, health means that the mind, body, and spirit are balanced. There is energy in the body called Qi (pronounced "chee"). This energy moves along lines called meridians. There are twelve main meridians connected to organs in the body. If the Qi is blocked or weak, a person can feel sick or weak.

When you visit an acupuncturist, they will check your pulse, look at your tongue, and ask about your health. They will use very thin needles to help the Qi flow better. Sometimes, they use heat from herbs or pressure on certain points.

**Acupuncture Points**

There are over 300 points on the meridians where acupuncturists can place needles. These points may not be close to where you feel pain. People often feel a gentle ache or tingling when the needle is used. This means the needle is working.

**How Does Acupuncture Work?**

Doctors in the West believe acupuncture can help with pain. They think it can block pain signals to the brain or release natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body.

**What Pain Can Acupuncture Help?**

Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture. It can help with back pain, headaches, arthritis, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say it can help with menstrual pain and pain from serious illnesses.

**Using Acupuncture in Surgery**

Acupuncture has been used in China for a long time, but using it during surgery started in the 1950s. In China, acupuncture is used in many types of surgery. Some people say it helps reduce pain without side effects from regular anesthesia.

**Is Acupuncture Effective?**

Studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find acupuncture helps with chronic pain. It may take six to seven visits to feel better, but some people feel improvement after two or three visits.

**A Different Way to Treat Pain**

Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the pain. They ask many questions to understand the pain better. They want to know if the pain feels sharp or dull and if it gets worse in different weather. This helps them decide how to treat the pain.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some doctors have training in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific methods. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist. They should refer you to a doctor if you need more help.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her real name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She looks calm and strong, but she is shy. She writes detective stories with many surprises. Her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, is like her. He likes to solve crimes alone, just like she does. 

P.D. James has written 12 detective novels. Many people around the world read her books. She likes to read books by women writers, but she also enjoys books by some men. 

P.D. James started writing later in life. She was 42 when her first book, Cover Her Face, was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband there. 

Her life was not always easy. Her husband was sick after the war, and she had to work hard to take care of him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped take care of the girls. 

P.D. James worked for the National Health Service and then for the Home Office. She learned a lot about crime while working there. She always wanted to be a writer and loved reading detective stories. 

She believes that writing detective stories helps to make sense of life. Solving a crime shows that life is important, even if it is not perfect.

**Simplified Text:**

The pen is stronger than the doctor. People are studying handwriting to learn about a person's character. In some countries, if you want a job, you may need to show your handwriting. This handwriting can help decide if you are right for the job.

Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Some researchers say it can help find certain health problems, like heart disease and cancer. It can also show how a person feels. Many companies now use handwriting analysis to help choose workers.

However, many doctors do not believe in graphology. Patricia Marne is a graphologist who has worked for over 20 years. She thinks handwriting can show important things about a person, like their social class and intelligence. She says it can help understand if someone is good at art or science and if they are honest or not.

Ms. Marne believes handwriting can also help find out if someone might commit a crime. She says that criminals often have bad handwriting. This can show they have problems in their life. 

She can tell if someone is honest or not just by looking at their handwriting. For example, young male offenders often have tall letters, which means they dream a lot. Handwriting can also show if someone is very stressed or has mental health issues.

Ms. Marne says that handwriting can change when someone is upset. If a person's signature changes over time, it might mean something serious is happening in their life.

She also says that different handwriting styles can show different traits. For example, if letters are connected like threads, the person might be clever but not honest. If someone writes mostly in capital letters, they may be hiding their true self. Light pressure in writing can mean the person is sensitive.

Ms. Marne believes it takes a long time to learn how to analyze handwriting well. She thinks more studies are needed to prove graphology is a real science. She believes it can be more accurate than asking people questions because it shows their true feelings without them lying.

But many doctors do not agree. They say handwriting is just about how a person was taught to write and does not mean anything else.

**Is Your Office Good?**

A new survey says fresh air and good chairs are important for happy workers. We looked at four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. We had three experts with us: a building health consultant, an ergonomist, and an occupational psychologist. Here is what they said.

**Office A: Advertising Agency**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very simple. It has no heating and no fans. The windows open to the street. The workers are happy and work well together. They change the temperature by opening doors or using heaters, like at home.
  
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture does not match. Some chairs are old and broken. But the workers have different tasks, like meeting clients and making presentations. This helps them not feel tired or bored.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The workers like the variety of their tasks. They say the office is "just the right size." It is small enough to know each other but big enough to work alone. The office is fun and creative.

**Office B: News Service**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is not very exciting, but it is comfortable. The air is good because there is no smoking.

- **Ergonomist:** The chairs and lights are good. The space is okay, but the walls are plain and grey.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls have only a few things on them. Most workers have been there for a long time and get along well. The office could be better if the desks helped people share information.

**Office C: Bank**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office feels like a glass box. The air is okay, even with smokers around.

- **Ergonomist:** The desks are not very good. Some chairs are not right for working on computers. The computer screens are too low.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The workers help each other and use technology well. The office is busy, but the colors are dark.

**Office D: Newspaper**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is not good. The air conditioning does not work well, and it is very dusty. There is not enough space for everyone.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is old and not good for working. Many chairs do not help people who are shorter.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office is dirty and needs cleaning. Workers seem stressed and do not talk much. The company should help workers work together better.

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular in America. People chew 12 million sticks of gum every day. It is a small food with less than ten calories. The American Food and Drug Administration makes rules for it.

Today, most gum is made with chemicals. It has added ingredients to keep the taste and make it soft. Long ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a natural gum from a tree called the mastic tree. Women in Greece used it to clean their teeth and make their breath fresh.

In America, colonists learned to chew gum from the Native Americans. They chewed a resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people sold spruce gum in the eastern United States. This was the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with a substance called chicle. Chicle comes from the sapodilla tree in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother and better to chew. This created a big business. However, it is hard to find chicle now. 

Today, many gum makers use synthetic materials instead of chicle. The few people who still gather chicle, called chicleros, have a tough life. They walk for miles in hot and humid weather to collect the sap. They face dangers like snakes and insects. Chicleros climb trees to collect the sap and carry it back to camp. At camp, they boil the sap to make it sticky and form it into bricks.

Life at the camp is hard. Chicleros eat a simple diet and drink local alcohol. Even though their work is difficult, chicleros worry about their jobs. In the past, the United States imported a lot of chicle, but now there is much less.

As gum sales have increased, companies use synthetic materials to save money. Gum makers also find new ways to sell their products. They say gum can help you relax and reduce tooth decay. Chewing gum can help your mouth produce more saliva, which is good for your teeth.

Gum makers are always looking for new flavors and textures. They use glycerine and vegetable oils to make gum. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still use natural ingredients. In America, a large area is used to grow mint for the most popular chewing gums.

**Climbing the Seven Summits**

Doug Scott is a mountaineer. He climbed the highest mountains on each continent. This is called the Seven Summits. He started this journey later in life. Here are his climbs:

A. **Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his friend Dougal were in a snow cave. They were very close to the top. Dougal talked about sleeping bags, which was strange because they were alone. Doug felt cold and worried about his feet. He thought about other climbers who lost fingers and toes to frostbite. But he felt calm because Dougal was with him. Doug found a good way to climb and reached the top.

B. **Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
This mountain is very dangerous. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal went to the Kahiltna Glacier. They carried food and equipment for four days. They realized the climb was hard. They followed a path but then chose a new way to the top. They carried everything on their backs. After three days, they were very tired but finally reached the summit and felt happy.

C. **Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul flew to Nairobi. They wanted to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up climbing Kilimanjaro. They got lost in the jungle and had trouble finding water. On the second day, they found a rock pool and felt relieved. They tried to climb a steep wall but decided to take a safer route to the top.

D. **Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife Sharu went to Aconcagua. They met a guide named Phil who invited them to climb a different route. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they started climbing. The wind was strong, but they reached the top and camped outside. They met other climbers who wanted to do the Seven Summits too.

E. **Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that he could climb Vinson Massif by guiding others. In November 1992, he and his team traveled to the South Pole. The sun was always shining. On December 7, they climbed to the top in very cold and windy weather. They were happy but could not see much because of the storm.

F. **Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team met in St Petersburg. They took a cable car up Elbrus. After two days, they climbed in strong winds. They thought they reached the top but found there was more to climb. They returned to their camp and then went down the mountain.

G. **Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On this climb, Doug wanted to spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about dangers but still started their journey. On May 12, they climbed and the weather got better. Doug and his team reached the top by 11 am. Doug felt proud to complete his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Artist Susan Shepherd and Her Garden**

Susan Shepherd is an artist. She is famous for her flower paintings. Her garden is very big and has many flowers. She loves tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. 

There are two long flower beds along a path in the garden. The colors and shapes of the flowers are very nice. The people who lived in the house before Susan were good gardeners. They left many plants that Susan likes. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. She says, "It was really his garden." At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She does not paint the whole garden at once. She takes a flower to her studio and paints it. This can take a few days. Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. 

Spring and early summer are her busy times. This is when the tulips and poppies bloom. Susan loves to see how flowers change. For example, when she puts tulips in water, they change shape and look beautiful. At first, they may seem boring, but they become interesting.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She liked wild flowers that grew in tough places, like rocks and cliffs.

Now, her garden has many plants from different countries. They grow well in her garden. Susan is relaxed about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play. 

She is busy preparing for two art shows, so she has hired another gardener. Even though she needs to paint, she knows it is important to work in the garden too. She says, "You have to get your hands dirty."

**Title: The Storm**

In March, strong storms hit the Brackham area. Many trees fell down, including two big lime trees in the town square. This made some people in the town unhappy. One of these people was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, who was the head of the local police. But during the storm, he was very sick with bronchitis. 

His wife, Molly, wanted him to see a doctor, but he did not want to go. He thought the police needed him. He tried to work, but he felt worse. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. After that, he got medicine and went home to rest.

On Thursday morning, Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen during the storm. He was too sick to understand. Later, when he felt better, he saw that the living room looked different without the walnut tree. 

Their house was big and had a nice garden. The garden made them feel private. Before, the walnut tree blocked the view of the tall house next door. Now, the tall house was visible, and it did not look nice. It had purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.

Pelham said to Molly, "Doesn't it look terrible?" But Molly was happy. She said, "I told you we need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

**Living in the Valley**

We lived in our valley for sixteen months. One day, we saw that the hills around us could be dangerous. It was a year when storms came early, before winter. Until then, we felt safe in our valley. 

Then, snow began to fall. In one day, there was 15 centimeters of snow. It blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery. In the hills, the snow was deeper and stayed longer. The wind was very strong up there. In our valley, we felt only some wind. The trees moved, but they did not break. 

We were worried about the river, the Ryburn. It usually flowed gently, but now it was dangerous. Many years ago, people built dams to control the water from the hills. 

Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we saw dark clouds over the hills. The clouds looked scary and warned us of trouble. We watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder. The rain was coming down, and the reservoir in the hills was filling up. 

Then, the reservoir overflowed for the first time in years. Water rushed over the dam like a waterfall. The river became wild and deep near our home. For three days, we hoped the river would not flood. Luckily, the dam held, and the water went down. 

In the past, the river had flooded nearby villages. Now, the dam keeps the river safe. Most of the time, we do not worry. We can enjoy the clouds and the power of the river. Thanks to the dam, we feel safe in our valley home.

Mark Adams is a film critic. He has worked for a newspaper called The Front Page for ten years. Writing about films for this newspaper was his first real job. Before this, he wrote about books for other newspapers and films for a magazine. He also did some work for the radio. 

He met Tom Seaton, who was the first arts editor of The Front Page. Tom hired Mark. Tom was not a journalist, so he did not choose his team carefully. He wanted a group of critics to write about books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have lunch together each week to talk about what to write. Mark felt very happy to be part of a new newspaper. He thought it was amazing that a new paper could start in a busy market. 

The first time Mark saw someone reading his review in the newspaper, he felt shy. Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out. They did not meet as planned, so they talked by phone instead. People liked to read reviews from critics who focused on one subject. Mark chose to write about films. 

Now, he writes a long piece each week about one film. He likes this way of working. He does not want to write about every film that comes out. That would make him tired of his job. He enjoys having space to write his thoughts. 

Mark thinks people choose films based on stars, ads, or the director. He believes that a film review is not just a guide for buying tickets. He does not feel he must always be right about a movie. He does not think there should be a set number of good or bad films each year. His job is to share his opinion, not to judge films.

Melanie has tried shorter triathlons, but she wants to do even harder events. She says, "I have no one my age to train with."

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy talks about collecting things and why many people like this hobby. Many adults enjoy collecting. It is a fun and exciting world. But if you want to collect something, remember: you should love the item. 

People have collected things for a long time. Long ago, early humans collected pebbles and wore them. They liked the shapes and colors of the pebbles. Today, children still collect stones and seashells because they are beautiful.

I have collected things all my life. I started with stones from my parents' garden when I was six years old. I went to a school in a cold place in England. When my parents visited, they took me to a museum. The museum had many interesting objects collected by people long ago. I loved looking at them.

Many adults also like to collect. Some people collect because it is something they can control. For me, I just enjoy it. 

One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" with many strange and beautiful things. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, had more than 4,000 paintings. But you do not need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember when I got a special tulip from another collector. I planted it, but one year it disappeared. Someone stole it!

I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I looked all over the USA for them. Sadly, my collection was lost in a fire. The next day, I saw the burned remains of my dolls and furniture. I felt very sad.

I am interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king is very valuable. When small items become popular, their prices go up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, especially if you kept the original boxes. I threw mine away!

**My Work**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Organiser at the Science Museum**  
I make exhibitions at the museum. I plan and design them. I read about the topic and talk to important people to find out what to show. I want the public to understand the exhibition. I plan fun activities like workshops and shows. I also work with engineers to make sure everything is safe. Before the exhibition opens, I help make brochures to tell people about it.

**Janet - Teacher for London Taxi Drivers**  
I start my day at 7:30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps we need for the taxi-driver test. By noon, about 50 students are in class, learning the best routes to take. I help when they disagree about directions. Before their test, I give them a simple route, but I tell them they must take a different way because the road is closed. This helps them think of new routes.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls, make educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to the main office, but I mostly work by the coast. I work with schools and teach people about the sea. I take them on a boat to show them the life under the water. This helps them understand better. I love my job because I care about conservation, but I work for a charity, so I always need to find more money to do everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is different every day. I make sure we have enough books and that they are good quality. We get many letters from readers about maps, and I need to answer them carefully. I talk about new projects and sales with my team. I enjoy working with my team, but I have a lot of paperwork to do, which takes time away from more fun tasks like designing new products.

**Title: Our Trip to Ireland**

Every June, we go to Ireland. The four of us always stay at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim for two weeks. It is a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, the Malseeds, own the house. They made it bigger, but it still looks nice.

Strafe found Glencorn Lodge for us. He saw an ad when the Malseeds were looking for guests. Last summer, we went to a hotel that friends told us about, but we did not like it because the food was bad. 

The four of us are good friends. My name is Dorothy Milson, but my friends call me Milly. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe were school friends. We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. 

Mrs. Malseed always welcomes us with a smile. She seems to know when we arrive. She waits in the hall that smells like flowers. She tells the porter, Arthur, to take our bags to our rooms. Our rooms are named after flowers: Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of numbers. In winter, she takes care of small things, while Mr. Malseed fixes and paints the house.

Mr. Malseed greets us with a big smile and says, "A hundred thousand welcomes!" We feel happy to be back. Kitty from the dining room also greets us and says we look younger every year, which makes everyone laugh.

After dinner, we play cards, but we are tired from our trip. In the lounge, there is a man alone and a French couple. Many people are at dinner because Glencorn Lodge is full in June. From our window, we see some guests walking on the lawn and others going to the beach.

In the morning, we will walk on the sand to Ardbeag and have coffee at a hotel there. We will be back for lunch. In the afternoon, we will drive somewhere. We love this place and its beautiful landscape.

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex, England. Sarah works in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.

This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She finished her studies in French and History of Art last summer. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a long-term job, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two. She meets many interesting people.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. The guests eat porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.

After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She does not like cleaning the rooms. By 11 a.m., she goes skiing. On good days, she skis until 4:30 p.m.

Sarah comes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. She does not like a messy kitchen in the morning. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but sometimes they want to be alone.

Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at about 11 p.m. They usually go to a place called Bananas and then to G Jay's or Dick's T-Bar. But on Saturday nights, she goes home early because Sunday is her busiest day.

On Sunday, Sarah wakes up early. She makes breakfast for guests who are leaving at 7 a.m. After they leave, she cleans the chalet quickly. If she did not shop for food on Saturday, she does it now. 

At about 3 p.m., Sarah prepares tea for the new guests who arrive at 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests are confused and have many questions. 

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis. Then she goes back to the chalet. After dinner, she might have a drink, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen is a small girl. She looks younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she says she is six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore big shoes and overalls, and her hair was messy but pretty. It was hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research about leather in New Jersey for her Master's degree.

Sometimes, students call or write to Seymour to visit his factory. He helps them by answering questions or giving a short tour if they seem serious. Rita was very small, like the children from Marie's class who visited the factory years ago. Seymour showed them how to make gloves. He remembered how Marie loved the "pancake hands," which were hot and shiny brass hands used to shape the gloves.

Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked more questions. He liked that she was interested. He explained that the leather comes to the tannery, where they make it ready to use. Seymour's family worked in the tannery, and he worked there for six months too. 

Rita said she had never been to a tannery. Seymour told her she should go if she wants to write about leather. He offered to help her visit one. He said it was hard work but very interesting. He mentioned that the leather industry is very old, with some tools found in Turkey that are 6,000 years old.

Seymour said his father knows a lot about leather. If you talk to him about gloves, he can talk for two days. He asked Rita if she had ever seen anything being made. She said she saw her mother make a cake when she was a child. Seymour laughed because she was eager to learn.

Rita reminded him of Marie, who was much taller but had the same bright spirit. Seymour decided to show Rita how to make gloves. He said, "We will make you a pair of gloves. What size do you wear?"

**Is It a Hard Job?**

Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as good as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi. She cannot meet tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. Raquel is a personal assistant to a pop star. She loves her job but has one problem: she does not like flying. "On a long trip to California, I take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde. "It felt very small with tiny windows." When she is not flying, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does paperwork, organizes schedules, and attends meetings. Raquel did not apply for this job. She met a pop group manager by chance and took a secretarial course at night. Five years later, she became a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy. He likes being a caddy more because he loves golf. But there are some problems. He earns a small fee and a part of the winnings. He makes between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You do more than carry bags. You give advice and read the course," he says. Now, he works for European Tour Productions. He collects and analyzes golf statistics from caddies. Many people want this information, including TV commentators and golfers.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easy tasks is to try food in nice restaurants. He thinks expensive restaurants are okay for people who can pay. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave," he says. He started writing a food column because a friend asked him. At that time, he worked in advertising. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant less money, but it was a chance to do what I love," he says. He still cooks at home and rides his bike to stay fit.

**D. Dick Prince**  
Dick Prince is a popular children's writer. "I started writing stories for kids 20 years ago," he says. Before that, he liked words but mostly wrote poems. He got an idea for a story about chickens and a fox. This story, called The Fox Busters, was his first published children's book. Where do his ideas come from? "It is not easy. I work hard on them," he says. He writes in the morning and types in the afternoon on an old typewriter. He gets many letters each week and enjoys answering them. Now, he has some help with this.

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old two-story building. Outside, there were big piles of soft sawdust. One afternoon, Michael and his friends went to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge and looked at the lake. 

Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down!" He jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust. He laughed and said, "I dare you all! You're all cowards!" His friends looked scared but then one by one, they jumped down too. They all laughed and lay on the sawdust, telling jokes.

After a while, one friend said, "Let’s go back up and jump again." They were not very excited, but they went back to the roof. They jumped down, but Michael stayed on the roof. His friends called, "Come on, Mike! What’s wrong?" 

Michael wanted to jump, but he felt scared. He tried to count to ten and take a deep breath, but he could not jump. His friends laughed at him and said, "You’re a coward! We can’t wait all night!" When he did not jump, they started to leave.

Michael felt sad and alone. He looked at the ground for a long time. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped down into the sawdust. He lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet because the workers had gone home. 

When he got up, he felt ashamed and walked home slowly. He was late for dinner. His stepmother said, "You should be home on time. If you can’t come home, maybe you should stay out tonight." She looked serious, but Michael did not really hear her. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job? Do you want to change it but don’t know how? Kitty Doherty has some good advice for you. Many people who want a new job go to a careers adviser. 

First, you will write a short history about yourself. Then, you will take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you will get a summary of the results. The adviser will suggest different jobs for you and tell you if you need more training.

I tried Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. Taking the test felt like being in a school exam. I was with about ten other people, and we had to answer questions quickly. I had to remember that it was not about passing or failing. The tests were hard. They included finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. 

After the tests, I talked with an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of what he said, but I was sad to learn that I did not do well in the science and technical tests. I am glad I did not become a nurse! But it was good to hear that I made the right choice in journalism.

Changing your career does not always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to go to Career Analysts for help. She said, "Losing my job was a good chance to think about my career. I wanted to look at my skills and interests." Some results surprised her. She did not know she was good at design. But she had to think about the cost of training for design.

Donna also got other ideas, like taking a year off to work in the Far East. In the end, she decided to use her skills and work in a job that suited her better. Now, she is a Public Relations officer. She thinks she could have found this job without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she wanted to do. She has sent many friends there, and they are all happy.

Some people really need help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services after working at a bank for six years. She said, "My job was boring, and I wanted a new challenge. I did not know what to do, so I went to the adviser with an open mind." The tests showed she liked sciences. She had four meetings with an adviser. The third meeting was recorded, which helped her remember what she said. After the last meeting, she decided to study geology. She thinks the advice was worth the money. Now, she is happier.

But not everyone finds careers advice helpful. Amanda Margetts, 24, was a sales representative. She said, "I did not know where to go in my career. I thought a careers adviser could help me. I got many new ideas, but I did not like them because they needed a big pay cut or a lot of training. I did not learn anything new about myself." She felt that if she had told a friend her problems, they would have given her the same advice.

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you go to W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a nice blue couch. Patients sit on the couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Many people only go to the dentist when they are in pain. They are scared." To help with this, he wants to make people feel safe and happy. He does not wear a white coat because many people think white coats mean pain. He believes dental visits should be relaxing and fun.

Jerome uses new ideas to help people relax. One idea is virtual-reality headsets. His office was the first in Britain to use them. Patients wear the headsets during their check-up. They can watch a movie about underwater animals while Jerome looks at their teeth. Then, the headset shows them a video of their mouth. Many patients like this part of their visit.

The office smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today it smells like orange. Jerome wants people to feel that this is not a normal dentist's office. The smell of a dentist can make people scared. I thought the nice smell in the office was very good.

Jerome is known as a stylish dentist, but he takes his work seriously. The ways to help people relax are important, but good treatment is the most important. For example, he uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a little strange, but it is not painful if people are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn new dental techniques. He found that when you make it easier for the patient, it is easier for the dentist too. He wants to change the way dentists work in Britain to be less formal.

One day, a patient comes in. Jerome quickly goes to him, offers him tea, and asks what video he wants to watch. He leads the patient to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a nice beauty salon than a regular dentist's office.

**Chocolate and Its History**

Chocolate comes from South America. Now, it is a big business around the world. In Britain, people spend a lot of money on chocolate, especially at Easter. They buy more chocolate at Easter than at any other time, except Christmas.

A long time ago, the Aztecs, Toltecs, and Mayans grew cacao plants. These plants are found in warm places like Africa and South America. The cacao tree has big fruit with seeds inside. When the seeds are dried, they are called cacao beans. In English, they are often called cocoa beans. 

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money. They also made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water." This drink was special and used for ceremonies. The Spanish liked to add sugar and cinnamon to the drink. 

In the late 1600s, people in Europe started to drink chocolate in special places called chocolate houses. At first, people made the drink from solid chocolate. In 1826, a man named CJ van Houten made chocolate powder. This made it easier to make chocolate drinks.

In 1847, a company in Bristol made the first chocolate bar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate. 

In the late 1800s, French companies sold a lot of chocolate in Britain. But then, Cadbury made the Dairy Milk bar in 1905. This chocolate bar became very popular because it was linked to healthy milk.

Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. Chocolate companies are trying new ideas to sell more chocolate, like making chocolate ice cream or drinks.

However, cacao farmers have problems because the price of cocoa beans went down in the 1980s. Many small farmers had to stop working. So, when you eat chocolate, remember the farmers who grow cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke is 83 years old. He is very good at making art. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But for now, he is happy making beautiful things from shells. 

Peter shows me his work in his home. He asks, "Am I boring you?" He is not boring. He is interesting and his art is beautiful. He shows me some shell decorations above his fireplace. He says, "I don’t mind if people don’t buy them. I love them." Peter never planned to sell his art. Five years ago, some friends told him to have an exhibition. They said, "People should see your work." They helped him talk to a gallery owner.

His first exhibition was in London. 70% of his art was sold. His second exhibition started yesterday. The prices for his art are high. Some pieces cost around £2,000. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition. The cheapest piece is £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he does not set the prices. He believes his work is special. The gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop making art, and everyone will want your pieces."

Peter wishes he had started making art earlier. He thinks he could have made even better things. Now, he feels a bit limited because he is older. But his work is very different from the common shell art you see in shops. He has a "miniature mind," which means he makes small and detailed art. He creates boxes with tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of beautiful flowers.

Peter uses different materials for his art. He uses cardboard from shirts for flower bases, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He has a clear idea of what he wants to make, and he works hard to make it happen. 

Peter travels to many places to find beautiful shells. He has been to France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He looks for shells on the beach. He only collects dead shells and does not take shells with living creatures. He believes that many people walk on the shells and break them. He thinks it is okay to collect shells that are already empty. 

Peter’s art is very beautiful, and he loves making it.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is 15 years old. She is a model. When she is not working, she studies for her school exams. 

One day, a reporter named Jane Laidlaw is waiting to meet Kira. The receptionist says Kira will be late. Jane feels worried. She thinks about bad things she has read about models. She wonders if Kira will come at all. 

But when Kira arrives, she is smiling and friendly. She is tall and pretty. Kira is not wearing fancy clothes. She has on a simple black dress and trainers. Kira's mother is with her. Kira explains that models under 16 must have an adult with them. 

Kira became a model by chance. Her older sister told her to join a model competition. Kira said no, but her sister sent in some photos. When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. She felt happy and confident. Kira won the competition and got a job with a model agency in London.

Now, Kira has two lives: school and modeling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her. But some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too much of herself. Kira feels sad about this. She says, "I am still the same person. I am just more confident."

Being a model is busy. The agency can call her anytime for a job. Kira cannot always make plans with her friends. But her friends understand. They do not complain about her work.

Kira has a bright future as a model. She is successful even before finishing school. When Jane asks Kira what she would do if she was not a model, Kira says, "I would like to do what you are doing."

Father and Son Search for Gold

Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son. They have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain has a lot of gold, maybe 10,000 ounces. After ten years of digging, they believe they are very close to finding gold worth five million dollars.

Terence, who is 68 years old and from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we find a lot of gold. We just need to dig a little more." They have worked hard to find gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold in an area called the "Dolgellau gold belt" near a town named Dolgellau. They looked at old mining books and chose a good place to dig.

They cleared the land, found some gold in the rocks, and spent ten years getting permission to work. They took samples of the earth and removed old cars and trash. They dug out a lot of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter deep hole. Now, they need more money. They spent their savings and need to find someone to give them £50,000 to dig deeper for the gold.

Chris said it is hard to find a backer, but they have some people to contact. Last week, news about their dig spread, and people in the area became interested in gold. Dolgellau needs tourists, and some residents are hopeful. Peter Woolven, who manages the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they find gold, it could bring more people here, but I hope many people do not come and damage the hillside."

The gold industry in Wales has become smaller since the late 1880s when many people worked in mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, closed a month ago. Now, more individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another gold seeker, wants to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. He is 70 years old and said, "Searching for gold is very exciting. It feels like an adventure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She studies the ocean. Rachel works at Southampton University. She teaches and does research about the sea. 

When she is not teaching, Rachel goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is like a small car. It goes deep into the Atlantic Ocean, three kilometres down. Rachel studies underwater volcanoes in this vehicle. 

Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move around. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rocks and water, and three hours to come back up. 

If there is a problem, Rachel can press a panic button. This button makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. Rachel says it might not be a nice trip.

The first time Rachel got into the vehicle, she was nervous. An instructor was with her. He told her what to do in an emergency. Now, Rachel has gone on six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place in the ocean with many underwater volcanoes. 

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office. She loves teaching, but she also wants to do research about "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. They release hot water that looks like black smoke. 

Once, Rachel was scared when she dived with American scientists. They were using equipment when there was a loud explosion. Rachel thought she would die. But they were safe, and she felt very relieved.

Diving to the bottom of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. She feels amazed when she sees the volcanoes. She studied them for three years. When she finally saw them, it was an incredible feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, and hungry after my trip. It was the end of my holiday in Europe. I felt tired and confused by all the different trains, money, and languages. I said, "Never again," when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year and the year after that.

I could buy a train ticket and travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month because I was under twenty-five years old. Sleeping on a train is different from sleeping in a bed. I carried my things in a big bag on my back. This made me travel simply and sometimes wastefully. I even burned my old socks and got rid of books I finished reading. 

But this way of traveling is fun. With a ticket in my hand, I felt free. My friends and I did not know how special this ticket was at first. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in France. But we wanted to see more countries. The extra travel did not cost us anything.

This was my first holiday without my parents. We made our own plans and only saw the things that were easy to find. I was proud that sometimes I only looked at the view from the train station. We just wanted to enjoy our time together. 

Traveling is exciting because you see places you only heard about before. When the train arrives, you see the city for the first time. You can understand Europe better by seeing it yourself. Other people's holiday photos can be boring because they do not show the real experience. The train trip may not show you new things in the world, but it is a special experience for you. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps you see this, even if it takes time to understand.

Text: 

It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your bags are not there. You may have to wear the same clothes for a long time until the airline finds your bags. Sometimes, you may be in a very different place and have to wear clothes that are not right for the weather.

Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers. Even good airlines can make mistakes. It is hard for any airline to promise that your checked bags will go on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.

Here is how it works: Airlines want you to arrive at the airport early. This is to give enough time for your bags to be checked and put on the plane. There is also a minimum time to change planes, which is longer than needed to help with bag transfers. Usually, this system works well. But sometimes, extra security checks and air traffic problems can cause delays. This can make it hard for bags to get to the right place. 

Human mistakes can also happen, like if the label on your bag comes off. Big airports, called 'hubs', can have more problems because they handle many bags. For example, last year, Heathrow airport in London had over 41 million passengers, and many were changing planes. British Airways had two million passengers changing planes there.

Even good airports like Amsterdam and Singapore can have bad days. Some airports, like Miami in the United States, are known for losing bags when passengers change planes quickly.

To avoid losing your bags, try to book direct flights if you can. Check in early. If you must change planes, try to use the same airline. Take an earlier flight to give yourself more time to change planes. Make sure to put your name and address on your bags, inside and outside. Also, write down your flight numbers.

If your bags are still missing, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a report before you leave the airport.

**The Kingfisher**

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer. He knows a lot about the kingfisher. The kingfisher is a small bird that is blue and green. It lives near rivers and streams and eats fish. 

The kingfisher is very fast. It moves quickly through the water. When it flies, it looks like a flash of light. You can see it for just a moment, but it is very beautiful. 

Charlie loved kingfishers when he was a child. He does not know why he loves them so much. There are many stories about kingfishers. One story says that a goddess turned into a kingfisher. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its body became blue like the sky. 

Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. They look blue because of how their feathers are made. The light makes them look blue or green. 

Many photographers love to take pictures of kingfishers. They are shy, but you can watch them from a hiding place. Charlie's first hiding place was an old blanket. He waited quietly, and the kingfisher came close to him. 

Charlie spent a lot of time by the stream to watch kingfishers. He missed some school because he wanted to be with the birds. At 16, he started working for a nature magazine. Later, he became a wildlife film cameraman. 

Now, Charlie wants to make a special film about kingfishers. He wants to show their beauty without talking. He loves to take pictures of their wings. 

Charlie feels a strong connection to kingfishers. His photos show some of his feelings, but there is much more to his love for these birds.

**Conductors and Their Work**

Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their jobs.

**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado's practice in Vienna. She ended up helping him because an assistant was not there. Later, she helped with another opera. "I had to lead the first rehearsal for Abbado. I was not nervous. I like standing in front of an orchestra," she says. Anne is from America. She works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries. She has helped Abbado on many projects.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine is 31 years old. He says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting good chances to work. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying two times before. He is happy it happened when it did. "If it had happened earlier, I would have been forgotten," he says. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work with a famous conductor. But he is worried about being known only for the competition. "If in three years people still think of me as a competition winner, I will be worried," he says. But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra are inviting him back.

**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She loves the long practice time for opera. "The music needs four weeks of work," she says. She began conducting in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional two years ago. Learning from Sian Edwards was important for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from bigger people," she says. She enjoys the complex nature of opera with its many arguments and different singers.

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles is 48 years old. He says conducting surprised him, but he finds it very interesting. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival. "It was easier than I thought. I knew the music well and tried my best," he says. People respect him as a musician. He learns from every experience and is open to trying new things.

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
Wayne Marshall is 32 years old. In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed him and told his agent about him. Wayne soon had to conduct a musical in London with little notice. It was a hard start. Some musicians were reading newspapers during the show. "I was strict with them. I always gave a clear beat," he says. He believes many musicians do not need advice from a conductor, but he is not afraid to say what he wants. He has not studied conducting formally, but people have helped him. He is determined and knows what he likes.

**Theme Parks in Britain**

If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many in Britain. Here are five families' experiences.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we went to a big theme park in the US. We thought Fun Island would be boring. But we were happy! The park is good for young children. Our three-year-old had fun. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special ride for little kids, and they liked it a lot. For older kids, there are scarier rides, like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, we were tired, but the kids wanted to stay. The park is clean and safe, but it could be more fun.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
We had never been to a theme park before, so we were excited. We thought Oscar was too young, but he loved it! He liked the Mountain Train and Little Land, where he could see small famous buildings. The older kids enjoyed the ferris wheel and driving toy cars. We stayed for six hours and found nice places to rest. The park is beautiful, and the staff are friendly. There is fun for everyone, even adults!

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still wanted to see more. The kids loved the Big Top Circus, which was very exciting. We tried the Terror Line, and the girls were scared but said it was fun. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is great for younger kids. The park is clean, and the staff are helpful. One staff member even helped me with one of the girls when I couldn’t sit with both.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We got to the park at one o'clock and were sad it closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger kids because the rides are not too scary. I am scared of rides, but I had fun. We loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn’t want to try the Big Leap, but it looked fun. The kids loved it because it was perfect for their age.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
The park says there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we agree! The Rocket, the tallest roller-coaster in Europe, is very exciting. Ben thought it was the scariest ride, but Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down, was worse! There are many rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. Some staff were nice to the younger kids, but not all. You need a whole day to enjoy Fantasy World. We couldn’t tell the kids we were going home early!

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women talk about their experiences starting a business in the countryside.

A. CHRISTINE HOGAN has a computer design business. She says, "My customers are friends." She moved from London to the countryside with her husband when their children were small. She wanted to work from home. She had worked with computers before, so her husband helped her start the business. At first, it was hard and she needed a lot of money. She was careful with her spending. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evening if she wants. Her business is small, and people come to pick up their work.

B. MAGGY SASANOW makes greeting cards. She enjoys being independent. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no jobs in the countryside. So, she started her own business and makes 50 types of greeting cards to sell to museums. She works in a big room upstairs. Sometimes, it is hard to work from home because there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She does not advertise; people hear about her work by word of mouth. She is cheaper than other artists. Working alone can be lonely, but she likes it.

C. DELIA TURNER makes curtains. She started her business eight years ago. At first, it was good, and her income grew a lot. She had six workers, but she had to let them go when business got bad. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and works with women who also work from home. She has to lower her prices sometimes and look for new opportunities.

D. TESSA STRICKLAND publishes children's books from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago because it is cheaper than London and she loves the country. She likes to work when she wants. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at different times. It is hard to close the office door and focus. She publishes books from different cultures and works with authors and artists. At first, she felt alone because she had worked in London before.

E. MEG RIVERS runs a cake business. She started ten years ago at home. She is interested in health, so she makes fruit cakes with good ingredients. Friends and family asked for her cakes, and soon she was sending them all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building to make the cakes. Now, she has a baker and an assistant. She does not bake anymore; she manages the business. Her biggest problem has been money because she did not have a lot to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is very special. They are all musicians. The sons write music and play instruments. Their dad makes the instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins are teachers in South Wales. They have a ten-year-old son named Paul. Paul wanted a cello, but it was too expensive. John thought, "I can make one!" He found a school to learn how to make instruments. He took classes for three years. 

After making some violins, John made his first cello for Paul. Paul liked it very much. John made another cello later, and Paul used it for many years. Now, John makes about twelve violins each year. He even sold one to a famous American musician!

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul began with the piano. He loved to play it as soon as he could reach the keys. Later, he wanted to play the cello because he thought the cellist in his dad's group was very cool. 

Huw says their parents were very supportive. They did not push them to play music. Huw is now 22 years old and is a pianist and composer. 

Paul became very successful. He won a big music competition and played in the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He played his dad's cello until last year. Now, he has a very old cello on loan from a music school. 

Paul will play on television soon, but he cannot watch it because he has a concert that night. Huw also has a concert that night. Their parents, John and Hetty, will be very busy trying to see both of their sons perform.

**Looking after the Countryside**

**The National Trust**

The National Trust is a group that wants to protect the countryside in Britain. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to a warden named Gareth Roberts. He works for the Trust to take care of the beautiful land.

Gareth says a National Trust Warden needs common sense. He also needs to be good with people. He talks to farmers, visitors, and other workers every day. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm. Many people wanted to be the warden, but Gareth got the job because he knows the area well and has farming experience.

Gareth still helps on his parents' farm. This helps him understand the farmers' problems. He can also do hard work like building fences and planting trees. Since he started working for the Trust, he has learned more about nature. When he was young, he liked to pick flowers and collect butterflies. Now, he sees that farming has changed the countryside. He believes it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following the government’s rules.

At first, farmers and conservationists did not get along. They both wanted different things. Now, they are talking and trying to understand each other. Gareth says they are close to working together.

Gareth's job is to help with conservation, allow people to visit the Trust's land, plant trees, and work with tenant farmers. He wants to finish jobs quickly and without problems. He enjoys seeing projects done, but he also spends a lot of time on reports and paperwork.

Gareth likes his job, but sometimes he finds it hard to deal with some visitors. Some people come in, ask for everything, and then leave without saying thank you. This can be annoying for him. But he believes that common sense is important.

If you have common sense and want to work outside, you might think about becoming a warden like Gareth. But remember, there may not be a job available in the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In this story about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slowinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra is getting ready for the World Championships next month. She teaches at a local school and then trains in a car park.

I asked Kendra if people look at her when she trains. She said, "I focus on my movements and my feet. I don’t see much else." Kendra is working hard to be her best for the Championships. She has a strict schedule to be fit.

This is Kendra's fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries playing. Kendra said, "We will have support from our home crowd, which is special." She wants to make netball better in England. There will be more pressure because people expect them to play well.

Their first game is against Barbados right after the opening ceremony. Kendra said, "We usually win against them, but they are good players." The England team is ranked fourth in the world. Kendra knows the Championships will be hard. "You must play well every day. There is no rest between games. You only have one chance to win," she said.

In the last fifteen years, netball has become faster and harder. Kendra said, "We train hard to win. But after the game, we are friends." Netball is also using more science to help players get fit. Kendra believes it is important to think and train like a top player. As captain, she wants to support her team.

Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition will be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. When she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

What can parents do for a child who is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents may not see their child's needs until the child gets upset or acts out. Most schools help children who are good at subjects like math or English, but children who are good at music need special help that regular schools may not provide. 

In Britain, there are five special music schools. These schools help children aged 7 to 18 who are very talented in music. At these schools, children can learn music from professional musicians. They spend a lot of time on music, like taking lessons, playing in groups, and practicing. They also study important subjects like English, math, and science, but less time is spent on these subjects compared to music.

The five music schools in Britain are independent, which means they are not run by the government. The classes are small, so teachers can give more attention to each student. Many children live at the school, which means they eat and sleep there. This helps them be with other children who love music too.

However, there are some problems. The schools are expensive, costing between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for children who live there. The schools try to help families with scholarships, which are financial aids. Also, not all parents want to send their young children to live at school. The school directors worry about admitting very young children because it can be a lot of pressure. They want to help children grow up happy and well-rounded.

Sometimes, being in a special music school can be stressful. A child’s musical talent may change as they grow up. The pressure to succeed can make them feel like they are failing. The schools watch each child closely and offer help when needed.
