Many students who leave music school feel they learned a lot, but some think it is not good to focus only on music and not enough on other subjects. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more in school. 

It might be better to wait until a child is older to decide if they should go to a special music school. Children who are good at both music and school can do well in regular schools that have good music programs. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges, but this may not be possible for families who live far away from big cities.

**Artist Susan Shepherd and Her Garden**

Susan Shepherd is an artist. She is famous for her flower paintings. Her garden is very big and has many flowers. She loves tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. 

The garden has two long flower areas next to a path. The path goes from one side to the other. The people who lived there before Susan took care of the garden. They left many plants that Susan likes. Susan also has a gardener named Danny. She says, "It was really his garden." At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas. But when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. She does not paint the whole garden at once. She takes a flower to her studio and paints it. This can take a few days. Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. 

Spring and early summer are her busy times. This is when the tulips and poppies bloom. Susan loves to see how flowers change. For example, when she puts tulips in water, they change shape and look beautiful. At first, they may seem boring, but they become interesting.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wild flowers. She did not like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She liked wild flowers that grew in hard places, like rocks.

Now, her garden has many plants from different countries. They grow well in her garden. Susan is relaxed about her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play. 

She has two art shows coming up, so she is very busy. She has another gardener to help her. But she knows that to paint flowers well, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex, England. Sarah works in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.

This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She finished university last summer. She studied French and History of Art. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a long-term job, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two. She meets many interesting people.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast first. Then she makes breakfast for the guests. They eat porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and sometimes makes afternoon tea for the guests. She does not like cleaning the rooms because it is hard work.

By 11 a.m., Sarah goes skiing. She loves to ski and can stay on the slopes until 4:30 p.m. After skiing, she goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is served at 8 p.m. and usually has three courses. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. She does not like to see a messy kitchen in the morning.

Sometimes Sarah talks with the guests, but sometimes they want to be alone. Good guests make her week better. Sarah lives in the chalet with her friends. They go out at night but come home early on Saturday because Sunday is a busy day.

On Sunday, Sarah starts work early. Breakfast for the guests is at 7 a.m. After breakfast, she cleans quickly. She prepares for new guests who arrive at 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests have many questions.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests get their ski boots and skis. After dinner, she may chat with friends, but if she is very tired, she goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "It was hard to choose my clothes because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. I went to a photo studio and then to meetings before lunch. The zoo is calm and quiet, but here I was busy. Some people in fashion looked stressed, but my job is not stressful. In the afternoon, I laughed because I usually clean animal cages. I like seeing how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo."

Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. "I wore my leather boots and dark blue pants. The zoo gave me a green shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. When I touched an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I was very dirty, but I had a great day. When I stop working in fashion, I might work with elephants in Africa."

Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She worked with the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh was nice. I liked being outside because I sometimes do not see the sun. It was hard work, but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I thought gardening would be easy, but it was hard work. I will keep my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock is a gardener on Ground Force. He worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out medicine. I thought I would feel sick, but I was okay. The nurses are friendly, and it felt nice compared to my usual job with men. I think my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not easy, but I felt good about helping."

Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I put on the uniform and felt different. People looked at me. Before the flight, our boss told us about safety. I knew some of it from my training. When the passengers got on the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone looked at me, and I felt shy. On the way back, we had 80 schoolchildren who were very noisy. I wished I was back in the gym with one adult."

Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer. "I was nervous because I do not exercise. I was surprised at how much attention trainers give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers many times a day. At lunch, I saw some trainers eat unhealthy food, but they drink a lot of water. I do not want to change jobs, but I want to join a gym and be healthier."

**On the Train**

Five famous people share their favorite memories of train journeys.

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I love the south of France. I go there when I can. There is a train from Cannes to Italy. The views are beautiful, no matter the weather. You can see nice houses and gardens. The people on the train are happy. There are tourists and locals, all enjoying the trip.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have taken many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to Kruger National Park. I was too young and had to stay with my aunt. When I moved to England, I saw my first big train station, London Waterloo. It was amazing!

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
One special train for me is the Blue Train. It took my husband and me on our honeymoon in France. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I still wear it. The journey was lovely, and we took a boat on the Nile after that. It was a perfect way to relax after our wedding.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
I worked on a project about traveling around the world. We had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not good, and we only knew the day to leave. When the train came, many people got on, even on the roof! At night, we saw beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people love trains from when they are kids, but I did not. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where there were few trains. I started to love trains as a teenager when I made a film in Yorkshire. We filmed on an old train line. I loved riding the steam trains. When I visited last year, everything was the same, even the gas lights at the station!

Text: 'Do you want to get your story published? Margaret Stubbs can help you. Many people ask, "I wrote a story/book. Who should I send it to?" First, you need to learn about publishers and practice your writing. To sell your writing, you must know the market. 

Read a lot! Go to your local library and bookshops. This will help you understand what publishers want. Remember, things change. New magazines and books come out all the time. 

If you want to write short love stories, find magazines that publish them. Get recent copies and read them. Know what kind of stories they like and who their readers are. 

Sometimes, new writers send their stories to me and ask, "I was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" I try to be honest but positive. Many new writers send their work too soon. If you only have one story, it is hard to get published. 

When you hear about someone’s success, they usually worked in writing for a long time before that. When you send your work out, keep writing more stories. Write ten or twenty more! Each story will be better, and you will feel more like a writer. 

Don’t give up! Improve your stories instead of throwing them away. At first, don’t show your work to others. Remember, many successful writers were rejected many times before they succeeded. 

Do everything you can to be a better writer. Look for a creative writing class or join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and feel more confident. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

**No Title**

On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station. I was waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were many more people than I thought. The station did not feel nice and clean like before. Older couples with matching bags sat on the benches, and many college kids had their bags on the floor.

A man with grey hair was walking around. He looked rich. He had nice clothes. He asked a woman sitting alone if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going north, but not to Philadelphia. She was going to New York. The man thanked her and walked to the next bench.

I was watching him. He asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going to Wilmington. He did not say anything and walked to a couple with matching bags. I moved closer to him. I was going to Philadelphia too. I thought he could have asked me, but he did not. He looked stressed.

He asked a woman reading a book if she was going to Philadelphia. She said yes. He asked her for a favour. I stood a little away and looked at my wrist, even though I did not have a watch. The woman looked worried. The man said, "It is not too difficult, I promise!"

They announced my train. People started to move to Gate E, pulling their bags behind them. The man was talking to the woman. He said his daughter was flying to study abroad from Philadelphia. He put her on a train and went home. When he got home, his wife was upset. She did not say "hello." His daughter forgot her passport and called from the station. She did not know what to do.

The woman felt sorry for him. I wanted to stay quiet and listen. The man said he told his daughter to stay at the station. He would get someone to bring her passport. I thought it was strange. Why did he not go himself if it was so important?

The woman asked, "Why don't you go yourself?" He said he could not leave his wife alone. She was in a wheelchair. I thought this was not a good excuse. It seemed like too much bad luck for one family.

I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a normal envelope. It was a padded envelope, like a small book. I thought, "Be careful, lady!"

**Gary and Me**

John Moore is the owner of a restaurant. He talks about his son, Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone has a chance in life. Gary had his chance with cooking, and John had his chance to run a restaurant.

When John found the restaurant, it was in bad shape, but he thought it was perfect. He remembered his childhood. His mother worked in a factory, and he felt sad when he was alone. John wanted to have time for family. His wife took care of the children and helped with the money, while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always had meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. They talked to customers from a young age.

Gary was a lively child. One time, he jumped into a bath and hurt himself. When he got older, he did small jobs for money. By age ten, he worked in the kitchen every weekend and had a lot of money at school. He was very disciplined and woke up early. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John liked seeing Gary work.

Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as good as the adult cooks and sometimes was in charge. He made over a hundred meals. John knew Gary would work in cooking. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Gary also started playing the drums and has his own band now. John told Gary to focus on one thing. He said, "If you want to succeed, do it by age 30." Gary went to cooking school at 17. On his first day, he finished his work very fast and helped others. 

Now, Gary has a successful TV cooking show, and John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary to work hard for what he wants because nothing is given for free. John thinks Gary listened to him because of the things Gary says and does.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin is very hard. It is like looking for gold. The best way to find a flat is to know someone. If you know a person who knows someone else, you might find a place. But Jo just came to Dublin. She did not know anyone. So, she had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat.

Jo felt scared and excited when she took the train to Dublin. She did not think about why she was going. Everyone at her school thought she would leave her small town. They wanted to go to big cities and have fun. Some of her friends went to other towns, but no one was going to Dublin. Jo was going alone.

Jo's mother thought it was good for her to stay in the hostel. It was run by nuns, so her mother thought she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because hostels can be cold. Jo's sisters worked in a hotel and thought it was crazy for her to stay in a hostel for a week. But Jo did not know they were talking about her.

Jo saw an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to her job at the post office. Jo hoped it would be nice and not too expensive. There were not many people looking at this flat. It was not just a flat for rent; they wanted a third girl to share.

Jo wondered if the flat was too fancy for her. The house looked normal, a red-brick house with two floors. The flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf came down the stairs. She looked unhappy. "This place is bad," she told Jo. "The girls are not nice."

Jo asked, "What happened?" The girl said, "She just acted like she was better than us." Jo kept going up the stairs. 

Another girl named Nessa was there. She was friendly and said they were having tea. She had three mugs: one with her name, one with Pauline's name, and one that said "Other." Nessa said, "We can put your name on a mug if you stay with us."

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We like to see them in the sea, in movies, and on TV. But dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds tells us about this problem.

Dolphins are very smart animals. They can feel human emotions and make us dream of freedom in the ocean. We see dolphins in shows like Flipper and Seaquest. But these happy shows do not show the real life of dolphins. The seas are dirty and there are not enough fish for them to eat.

In the North Sea, the number of harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has gone down a lot. There used to be many, but now there are many less. You might think that dolphins are protected by laws and live in safe places. This is not true. There are not enough plans to help them, and this could be a big problem for wildlife.

There are forty types of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, we can find striped dolphins, common dolphins, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the sea. We do not see them often. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen near the coasts of Europe. Bottlenose dolphins are friendly and were often seen in places like the Thames River in Britain. Now, we can only find them in a few places in Scotland and Wales. The dolphins that are still there have injuries, which show they are stressed.

It is hard to know why there are fewer dolphins. Overfishing is a big problem. When fishermen catch too many fish, dolphins cannot find food. They may not survive if they cannot find food quickly. Dolphins can also get caught in fishing nets. These nets can be hard to see. Many dolphins have died because they got caught in these nets.

Dolphins can also get sick from pollution in the sea. For example, pesticides can build up in their bodies. Female dolphins can pass these poisons to their babies through their milk. There is a case of a baby dolphin that died because of this.

Another problem for dolphins is noise from humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to communicate. But noise from ships and oil wells can disturb them. This noise travels better in water than in air, and it may affect dolphins in ways we do not understand yet.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your body and mind. It helps you feel good and stay healthy. Many people talk about fitness because it is really good for you. 

Here are some reasons to exercise:

- It makes your muscles stronger.
- It helps your body look better.
- It helps you sit and stand correctly.
- It can stop injuries.
- It makes your heart and lungs healthier.

Exercise can also help with feelings. It can make you feel less sad and tired. It helps you sleep better and can reduce stress. 

There are many types of exercise you can do, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. But be careful! If you exercise too hard, you can get hurt. Start slowly and ask your doctor if you are not sure what to do.

Good posture is very important. It helps you look and feel better. If you slouch, try to imagine a balloon pulling you up. This will help you stand tall and breathe better.

Stretching is also important. It helps your body move easily and prevents injuries. Try to stretch four or five times a week to be more flexible and fit. 

A good exercise routine should include:

1. A warm-up
2. Stretching
3. An energetic workout
4. A cool down

Remember, exercise is good for you!

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for a long time? They want to get the best pictures of animals. Amanda and Owen work in East Africa, in a place called the Ngorongoro Crater. It has rained a lot there for six months. This has caused some problems for them. Owen said they had to buy a special tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud.

Amanda and Owen make great wildlife films. One of their best films is about leopards. While people were watching this film, Amanda and Owen were already looking for another animal, the jackal. 

Film-makers travel all over the world to film animals. I talked to Owen when he was at a safari lodge with other people. He said, "We sometimes argue, but we make up quickly." They do not think one of them is the boss. They both see animals in the same way.

When they travel, they set up their tents every night. This time, they are staying in one place. They wake up at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before. They eat pre-packed meals that they heat up. Owen said, "We can be out for eight weeks, so cooking can be a little stressful."

It can be hard work, but they like being in quiet places. This helps them get close to the animals. Owen remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would go away and then come back to greet her family. She even greeted their car!

Owen first worked with Amanda in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. Now, they spend four months in one place to get enough material for each film. Before they start, they must show a script to get approval.

Owen said, "Amanda and I work well together because we have the same ideas. We want to make a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals. We want to touch people's hearts."

**The Netball Captain**

In this story about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met Kendra Slawinski, the captain of England's netball team. Kendra is very busy because the World Championships are next month. She teaches at a school and then trains in a car park.

Suzie asked Kendra if people look at her when she trains in the car park. Kendra said she does not notice them because she is focused on her training. She wants to be the best for the Championships. Kendra has a strict schedule to be fit.

This is Kendra's fourth World Championships. There will be 27 countries playing. Kendra is happy to have support from fans in England. She wants people to see netball as a good sport. There will be more pressure because they are playing at home. People want them to win their first game against Barbados.

The England team is ranked fourth in the world. Kendra says the Championships will be hard. There are no breaks between games, and they must be ready to play well. The game has become faster and tougher over the years. Kendra believes that all the training is important to win. But after the game, players are friends.

Netball is also using science to help players train better. Kendra thinks it is important to have a strong mind and to help her team. She has planned her netball career carefully. Kendra decided that this competition will be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future.

As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, Kendra might cry because she is happy. Her supporters will be with her all the time.

**In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemicals in the sea. She teaches at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.

When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is like a small car. It goes three kilometres down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots. They cannot stand up or move around. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.

If there is a problem, Rachel can press a panic button. This button makes a small escape vessel come out. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice trip.

The first time Rachel got into the vehicle, she was nervous. She was on a ship with an instructor. He told her what to do in an emergency. They wanted to see how she would feel in a small space. Now, Rachel has dived six times. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was leaving equipment to study a project that would make a hole in a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office. She loves teaching, but she also wants to do research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. They release water that looks like black smoke. This water comes out very fast and is very hot.

The only time Rachel was scared was when she dived with an American team. They were using a long rope when there was a big explosion. Rachel thought she would die. They waited in silence, but they were still alive. The relief was amazing!

Diving to the bottom of the ocean is an adventure. Every time Rachel looks out of the window, she sees the volcano chimneys. She feels wonder. She has studied black smokers for three years. When she saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. People often decide what they think about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, and how we talk.

Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard and graduated. She felt confident. She applied for a job at a primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. That morning, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she did not want to be late. She believed it was important to be on time. Mary did not get the job. A friend told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone does not care about their appearance at an interview, how can they be a good teacher?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says that people who look good at interviews are more likely to care about their jobs. Many people forget how important it is to look professional. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an assistant in a big company. When her boss retired, she wanted to be the new boss but did not get an interview. She asked why and was told she did not look like an office manager. They suggested she change her clothes before applying again. Janet was surprised because she thought she did a good job and that her clothes should not matter.

How we move and use our hands can also affect what the interviewer thinks. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message comes from the words we use. 38% comes from our voice, and 55% comes from our facial expressions. If our words and our face say different things, people will believe our face more. So, it is important that our words match our body language. Confusing messages can make the interviewer unsure.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, had a great interview and was offered the job right away. She was very happy but showed too much excitement. The boss saw how excited she was and offered her a lower salary than she wanted. She thinks she could have asked for more money if she had stayed calm.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us in an interview. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, says it is good to learn about the company before the interview. For example, reading the annual report can help you know what the company does. You can mention something that interests you during the interview. This shows you care about the company.

Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and using short sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in long sentences. Successful communicators use short sentences and key points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work in an office in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. He thought it was fun at first, but then it became boring. One day, he lost his job. He did not get a lot of money, but it was enough to start his farm. He met a chef from a hotel. He started selling meat to the hotel. Now, he also sells meat by mail. He is happy to be outside and not in an office, but he still works a lot of hours.

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby. He liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career counselor who helped him. Ron did not want to go back to his old job. He and his wife moved to the north of England. They did not know anyone there, but they still keep in touch with their friends. Many friends visit them now.

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her flat in London. She liked her job, but it was very busy. She did not want to work more hours, so she left. Some people thought she would get bored, but she did not. She has many deadlines to keep her busy. She feels happier now, but she misses talking to other people at work. She likes being in charge of her work. If she does a bad job, she knows it is her responsibility.

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur in London. He liked the excitement of his old job, but he did not find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he decided to travel for a year. During that year, he learned about health and gyms. He took courses in massage to change his career. Now, he works part-time at the Life Centre. He is happy and feels in control of his life.

**Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

A. **Darius (Runner)**  
I have always liked sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country and won a medal. Not many people heard about it, which was sad. I hoped to get some money for training, because it is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there, and I have to be very disciplined. If my friends ask me to go out the night before training, I have to say no. I want to go to the next Olympics - that would be amazing.

B. **Gabriel (Surfer)**  
In surfing, the community is small. I see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are early in the morning. So, I do not go to late-night parties. I do not mind, but I love to sleep in. I have to give that up too. But it is worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I like to celebrate, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning helped me get a job on TV, so now I am a bit famous.

C. **Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in a big way. Some people say we act like kids, but we do not look for media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I am away for eight months a year, so I like to come back and hang out with my friends. You cannot only think about sports all the time; it is not healthy. I am known in sailing, but not many people recognize me on the street. I do not want to be famous. I get nice letters from fans, and I reply to every one.

D. **Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to play in front of a crowd. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with many fans. I like being recognized by fans when I am out shopping. But my last girlfriend did not like it when I got attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in sports. I focus on my game now and will think about other things in life when I retire, which is early in this sport.

**Shopping with Kids**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "My kids want to buy everything they see. They want cereal, toys, and videos. I cannot buy all these things. If I say yes, I feel bad because I know it is not good for them. But if I say no, I feel bad too. I try not to take them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to choose things."

Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on ads for children, especially on TV. Children do not always understand why their parents say no to some things. Parents want to give their kids healthy food, but ads can make unhealthy food look very good.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their kids eat. They want to teach them about healthy food. But if kids only see ads, they get a one-sided view." Parents feel stressed because they have to say yes or no to their children's requests.

One mother says she talks to her son about ads and food. She tries to help him understand that not all ads are good. Now, he does not ask for things she does not want to buy. 

Parents sometimes feel confused about what to say. Mike, a father, says, "I tell my son not to buy sweets because they are bad for him, but I buy treats for myself. It is hard to be fair. If I feel happy, I might say yes more often."

Supermarkets can help parents by not putting sweets at the checkout or by having play areas for kids. If parents can shop without their kids asking for things, they might come to the store more often.

Text: 'The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has new technology to help the staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know the guests' names. The hotel uses a computer system to remember what guests like. This helps when guests come back. The system cost a lot of money, but it will help the hotel in the future.

Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system that lets guests change the temperature in their rooms. They can make it warmer or cooler. Each room can also be adjusted by the staff at the front desk.

The hotel has special technology for business guests. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and a video-conferencing system. The hotel is ready for new technology. They rent televisions so they can change them for new ones easily. 

The rooms are comfortable and welcoming. There is a swimming pool, a gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food is very good. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, runs the restaurant in the hotel. He has made a new kitchen and has better parking for guests. 

With good food, great staff, and new technology, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.'

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women how they get their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann** (Journalist and author): "I get energy from excitement. I like challenges and learning new things. Dancing gives me energy too. Right now, I am learning flamenco dancing. If I am bored, I feel tired. Doing something useful, even small things, gives me energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey** (Magazine editor): "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. I love my job. If you like what you do, you don’t feel sad, even if you are tired. I need sleep to feel good. When I sleep six hours, I feel a bit tired. Exercise gives me energy, but I need to find the time to do it! I go to a yoga class once a week and try to exercise at home. After I exercise, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it’s good to eat something then."

C. **Annie Nightingale** (Disc jockey): "I don’t eat healthy food for energy. I think being positive gives me energy. I don’t like negative people. I believe we should enjoy life. I love my job and the last two years have been exciting. I work with many young and lively people. I like taking photos, but I’m not sure if I’m good at it. I also write words for fun songs when I travel."

D. **Floella Benjamin** (Author and children's TV presenter): "I get energy from doing things I enjoy. I believe in my work and being positive helps. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Smiling at people can make you feel good. I try to eat healthy food and I don’t smoke or drink. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach** (Author and playwright): "I love making gardens from empty land. I once turned a concrete area into a garden. It was better than exercising. I also get energy from knowing people want to read my writing. I like exploring nature, even if it is private land. It feels fun and childlike."

F. **Katherine Monblot** (Therapist): "You need to care about what you do in life. I like to take risks and I get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don’t want to do makes me tired. I used to be on many committees, but I didn’t like it. You have a limited amount of energy, so use it for what is important to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating is a fun activity that people have done for many years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. Later, they started using iron skates. In Scandinavia, skating was very important for rich people. 

In the early 1900s, skating was fancy. But in 1924, a young girl named Sonja Henie made skating more exciting. Now, skating is both beautiful and hard work. 

If you want to learn to skate, you need to balance and control your body. To balance, keep your legs slightly bent and lean a little forward. Your feet should be close together and turned out. When you push with one foot, move the other foot a little. 

It is important to know how to fall safely. Even good skaters fall sometimes. To fall without getting hurt, stay relaxed. When you fall, use your hands to help you get up. First, go to your knees, then stand up.

Once you can skate well, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, or speed skating. It is best to start with figure skating. Many ice rinks have teachers to help you learn.

Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To skate well, you should practice exercises to warm up your body. This helps your legs, back, and shoulders. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid feeling stiff.

Skating helps you balance and move better. It is also good for your heart and lungs. When you skate, swim, or jog, you can be very healthy and fit!

**Trills and Bills**

Seeing a child win a medal can make you very happy. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about their lives.

A. Annika Reeder is 15 years old. She won a gold medal for gymnastics. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the Olympics. Annika says, "I work very hard. I don’t have time to watch TV or go out with friends. I focus on gymnastics and school. Sometimes I feel very tired, and my coach gives me a day off, but I usually keep training. If I take too many days off, I get stiff."

B. Annika's mother says, "Annika has always been very talented. Some parents push their children too much, but Annika wants to do this. It takes a lot of time and energy. People say we give up a lot, but we love the sport and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was shy. Now she has friends from all over the world and is more confident."

C. Sarah Stokes is 10 years old. She started show-jumping when she was 10 and has won the British National Championship. She says, "I am happy my parents like show-jumping. They train me and take me everywhere. The shows can last from one to five days. I love it! My goal this year is to join the British young riders team. I want to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. Sarah's mother says, "Sarah loved horses from the first time she sat on one. When she was 5, she woke up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we travel all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is very organized and happy on a horse. It is wonderful to see your child succeed at something they love."

E. Jane McShane is 10 years old and is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. She says, "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone and it is fun. When I play, I don’t concentrate as much as I should. I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t want to feel embarrassed."

F. Jane's mother says, "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father wanted to see if she liked it. Jane loved chess right away. By 6, she was beating adults. I am happy when she wins, but if she wants to stop playing, I will support her. I want her to use her talent and be happy."

Text: 

Chris Greener was fourteen years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already very tall. Now, he is the tallest man in Britain at 228 cm.

Every ten years, people in Europe get a little taller. More tall people are being born. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were a long time ago. We are getting better food now, which helps us grow.

A scientist named Professor Chris Stringer says we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, who lived 40,000 years ago. Long ago, people ate many different foods. Women picked fruits and herbs, and men hunted animals. They ate from 85 different wild plants.

About 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed things a lot. Now, most of the land is used for farming. Three main plants—wheat, rice, and maize—give most of the food for people today. This simple diet has made many people unhealthy. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Their teeth got worse, and they got more diseases. Farming was not good for health, but it helped feed more people. 

Now, in rich countries like Europe, the US, and Japan, people are eating better again. The average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but there are still problems. 

Beds have not gotten longer since 1860, and there is less room for legs on planes and trains. Clothes companies have to change their sizes often. 

Some scientists think we might stop growing taller soon. They say we could reach a height of 193 cm this century. But, even if some people are taller, as a group, we might be getting smaller. 

A long time ago, during the ice age, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the world is warmer, we might be getting thinner and shorter. So, as the planet gets hotter, we might not grow taller anymore.

**Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. 

Studio audiences are a common part of TV shows, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we see the audience getting excited. We might wonder, "Who are these people?" 

Some people think studio audiences are not important. They say that even TV workers do not care about them. I thought studio audiences were just made up of silly people who want to be on TV. But this is not true. Studio audiences are made up of many different people. TV shows want different types of people to come to watch.

Many people at home do not understand why someone would want to watch a show in a studio. Why would they travel far and wait a long time just to see what they can watch at home? One reason is that some people hope to be on TV for a moment. I did not believe this until I talked to Angela. She said, "I came because it was a chance to be on TV." 

Another reason is that people want to see how a show is made. But many people said, "A friend gave me a ticket." 

Most of us have not been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers, and someone shows signs that say "APPLAUD" or "LAUGH." You clap or laugh when you see these signs. This is true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, "We think a show should be good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting." Charlotte liked being part of live TV. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch at home, you miss a lot." 

I missed seeing the actors because I could only see the back of someone’s head. I ended up watching the show on a monitor. 

Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch TV, but that is not what matters. For most people, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favorite Places**

**Bruce**  
I do not like wild landscapes. I like places with people. When I travel, I like pretty villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I rode my bike to the village of Lastingham. Riding my bike was fun. I loved to explore the hills, valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape felt familiar but also new. I still visit there today. I wrote about my adventures in my diary. This was my first travel writing.

**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. It is run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it is not much more money. The view is not amazing. The train goes over fields with sheep and next to a canal. But I like one part of the trip. The train goes through back gardens. For a moment, I see people making tea, washing dishes, and opening chairs. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a small train, looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape with fields, sheep, and a faraway grey sea. It makes me look closer and find new things.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to get to and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. Some surfers come, but most visitors just enjoy the sea. This coast faces the Atlantic Ocean and has many shipwrecks. You can walk along the coast and visit beautiful valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in a simple place with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a big, open area that is great for hiking. There are not many people living there or visiting. It is quiet and empty, and I like the space. I found this place by chance when I was a student. Since then, I visit every year, sometimes alone, sometimes with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. I feel sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to feel connected to my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka, but when I was twelve, I went to school in Devon, England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and villages. There was a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you would never come back. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We love animals and enjoy having them around. One day, my daughter called me at work. She found a pine snake and asked, "Can we keep him?" I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank for animals like this. 

I got home late. I started to cook when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their room. There was a problem with our cat, Domino, and a white mouse named Bianca. Domino had the mouse in his mouth and was running around the room. 

I tried to help, but I tripped and fell. I saw the snake escaping from the table and onto the floor. The cat, mouse, and kids were all jumping around. The snake was moving fast, and the dog was barking. 

The pot in the kitchen boiled over. I turned it off and went back to help. I caught Domino by the tail and saved the mouse. The mouse was wet but okay. 

I looked at the snake. It seemed strong. I sat on the floor and waited. Slowly, the snake relaxed. I carefully picked it up and took it to the end of the garden. I wanted to let it go near a tree. 

When I let go of the snake, it climbed up my shoulders like a warm scarf. My oldest child, DJ, said, "Mum, you are warm, and the shed is not." I asked the kids to help me move the snake. Slowly, it went up the wall and disappeared over the roof. 

As the snake left, my three-year-old son, Clay, said, "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Simplified Text:**

"Write to me! In our fast world with phones and computers, writing letters is not common anymore. But I love getting letters. It is exciting to see a letter come, to know who it is from, and to read what is inside. I have written letters for a long time. I started by writing little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for gifts. It did not matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.

When I was 18, I moved to London to study to be a doctor. I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. My father sometimes wrote long, funny letters. Most letters were about everyday life. We also called each other, but I remember the letters more.

I also got letters from my boyfriends. They were away for work or school, and we wrote to each other. Writing letters helped our relationships. I could say what I felt better in a letter than by talking. I love letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but letters with news are better! I like getting letters from faraway places, like Sri Lanka, Australia, and Canada. I also have a friend in France. We started talking in a restaurant, and I asked for her address. Now we write to each other. I can practice my French with her.

This summer, my family and I visited my friend in Texas. We had written to each other for 29 years but had never met. People were surprised that we wrote for so long. My children also write letters. Like my mother, I make them write thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas too. I hope everyone keeps writing letters!"

**Simplified Text:**

Tourists are hurting old rock art in the French Alps. There are 36,000 drawings on the rocks at Mont Bego. These drawings are very old, about 4,000 years. They show cows, fields, and gods. Many people visit this place, but some do not care for the art. They write on the rocks and damage the pictures.

Jean Clottes is a leader in rock art. He says, "People think the pictures will always be here. But if they keep getting damaged, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings and hurting them. Some people even take pieces of the rocks home. Others rub the drawings to take better photos.

Some visitors bring sticks to scratch their names on the rocks. Experts have different ideas on how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, from a museum in Paris, thinks the best way is to close the mountain to the public. He says this will help save the art. But Jean Clottes thinks this will make people angry. He wants to save the drawings but keep the area open.

David Lavergne, an architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says it is hard to stop visitors from damaging the art. He thinks they might need to charge money to help pay for guards. 

Annie Echassoux, who studies the site, is worried. She says more tourists will come because it is easier to reach now. She believes they should block off some areas and have guides. She says it is important to find money to protect the drawings because they are a historic site. If they do not act, future generations will lose this art.

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very hard for parents. One mother says, "My kids want everything they see. They want cereal, toys, and videos. I cannot buy all these things. If I say yes, I feel bad because I know it is not good for them. But if I say no, I feel bad too. I try not to take them shopping, but I worry they need to learn how to choose things."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes in a supermarket. A lot of money is spent on ads for children, especially on TV. Children do not always understand why their parents say no to certain things. Parents want to give their children healthy food, but ads can make unhealthy food look very good.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat. They want to teach them about healthy food. But if children only see ads, they get a one-sided view." Parents feel they have to say no to their children a lot because of ads.

The rules for TV ads say that advertisers cannot tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But Susan Dibb says, "The goal of ads is to make people want to buy things." 

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents. One mother says she talks to her son about ads and food. Now, he does not ask for things she does not want to buy. 

Parents sometimes say no to their children but then buy treats for themselves. Mike, a father, says, "We do not buy sweets for our son because they are not good for him, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It is nice to buy good things, and children want to enjoy that too. But sometimes, I feel annoyed by their requests. If I am happy, I say yes more often. It is hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets can help parents by not putting sweets at the checkout or by having play areas for children. If parents can shop without their children asking for things, they might come to the store more often.

**Going Up the Wall**

Climbers used to go to the mountains. Now, people can climb indoors or outdoors. The crowd is quiet. High on the climbing wall, a French climber named Francois Lombard is hanging upside down by two fingers. He is in a big climbing competition in Birmingham.

The place is called the National Indoor Arena. It is famous for a TV show called Gladiators, but it also has climbing competitions. This is possible because of new technology.

Before the 1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather or climb on snow and ice. As climbing became more popular, climbers needed to stay fit. When they could not climb outside, they used walls of buildings to practice. This helped them keep their fingers strong.

Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls. These walls had special bricks to hold on to. A teacher named Don Robinson built a climbing wall in a hallway at Leeds University in the 1960s. He put real rocks in concrete to make climbing walls.

In the 1970s, many climbing walls were built, but they had problems. The walls were straight, but real cliffs have different shapes. Once a wall was built, it could not be changed. Climbers got bored because the walls were the same.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny made a new material. He made shapes like the rocks on cliffs. These shapes could be put on any wall and taken off when climbers wanted something new. French companies also made climbing walls with steel frames. Steel walls were lighter and could be built anywhere. This way, climbers always had new holds to try.

Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone this, they might say it is risky. Acting can be a risky job. There are many actors, but not many jobs for them. When you choose to be an actor, some friends may think you are crazy. People will give you different advice. But it is your choice, and you are responsible for your dreams.

There are no easy ways to become an actor. You do not have to take tests, and there is no guarantee you will get a job after training. Success depends on luck and talent. There is a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and rewarding.

Talent is a special skill. It is a mix of natural ability and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. It also depends on your courage and belief in yourself. 

Why do you want to act? It can be hard to explain. In acting, the important moment is when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what makes actors want to perform.

Actors often do not know how they succeed. They understand some things about their skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they can be out of work one month and then get a chance to audition the next. They may want the job, but they might not get it. 

Actors try to protect themselves from stress and rejection. No one likes to be told "no." From the start, when you want to act, you say you are ready and talented. If you do not care about your acting, others will not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**

We have a special selection of the best cookbooks for you.

A. If you think of a famous TV cook, you might think of Delia Smith. She has recipes from many places in the world. Her recipes are easy to follow and good for everyone. Her famous book is called "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book helps you learn to cook. It has many simple recipes that are not boring. If you want one good cookbook, this is the one!

B. Raymond Blanc is a famous chef in Britain. He worked hard for 15 years to become a great chef. Now, he has a book called "Blanc Mange" to go with his TV show. He wants to help everyone cook better. He explains how ingredients work together. His book has over 80 great recipes. It also tells you why some dishes can go wrong. Raymond loves to cook for others, and he is very good at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a famous cooking school in France. For 100 years, they have taught many students to cook well. To celebrate their anniversary, they made a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook." This book has 100 classic recipes. The recipes are easy to follow and have pictures to help you. Chefs from around the world share their best recipes in this book.

D. Fast food? No way! Many people think good food takes a long time to make. But Nigel Slater, a food editor, thinks differently. His new book is called "The 30-Minute Cook." He believes you can make tasty food quickly. In this book, you will find over 200 recipes that are ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun way, and his recipes are delicious. If you think fast food can’t be good, try his recipes!

Text: 

Chris Greener was fourteen years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already very tall. Now, he is the tallest man in Britain at 228 cm.

Every ten years, people in Europe get a little taller. More tall people are being born. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were a long time ago. We are getting better food now, which helps us grow.

A scientist named Professor Chris Stringer says we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, who lived 40,000 years ago. Long ago, people ate many different foods. Women picked fruits and herbs, and men hunted animals. They ate from 85 different wild plants.

About 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed how people ate. Now, most of our food comes from just three plants: wheat, rice, and maize. This has made many people unhealthy. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Their teeth got worse, and they got more diseases.

Farming helped feed more people, but many are still not healthy. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are people starting to eat better again. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm.

Even though people are getting taller, some things are not changing. Beds are still 190 cm long since 1860. There is less room for legs on planes and trains. Clothes companies have to change their sizes often.

Scientists think we may stop growing taller soon. They believe we could reach a height of 193 cm this century. But, while some people are getting taller, as a group, we might be getting smaller. A long time ago, during the ice age, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the weather is warmer, we are getting thinner and shorter. If the planet gets hotter, we might get even smaller.

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work in an office in London. He sold insurance. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years. He thought it was fun at first, but then it became boring. One day, he lost his job. He did not expect this. He did not get a lot of money, but it was enough to start his farm. He met a chef from a hotel. He started selling meat to the hotel. Now, he also sells meat by mail. He is happy to be outside and not in an office. He still works a lot, about 80 to 90 hours a week.

**The Painter**  
Ron Able was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. He started painting as a hobby. He liked it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. He talked to a career counselor. The counselor was surprised when Ron said he did not want to go back to his old job. Most people want to go back to work for money. Ron and his wife moved to the north of England. They did not know anyone there. They left their friends, but many friends still visit them.

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her flat in London. She liked being a lawyer, but the hours were long. She did not want to work more hours to become a senior partner, so she left. People said she would get bored, but she did not. She has deadlines to keep her busy. She feels happier now and less stressed. She misses talking to her colleagues. She likes being in charge of her work. If she does a bad job, she is the one to blame.

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. He was in financial markets. He liked the excitement, but he did not find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he decided to travel for a year. He wanted to find out what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited gyms and talked to the owners. He knew he needed training, so he took courses in massage. Then, he got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He is happy now. He feels in control of his life.

**A Fun Game for Business**

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are having fun and making money with a game from their childhood. They live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are playing a game called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought this game from Canada to their family.

When they were kids, the family played pichenotte every weekend. They moved to New Mexico, but they still played the game. Their grandfather made the first pichenotte board from old wooden boxes. When friends came to visit, they were curious about the game because it was new to them.

Three years ago, Dave made a new pichenotte board because the old one was broken. His family and friends liked it. One night, the brothers took the new board to a sports bar. At first, people thought it was silly, but soon they wanted to play too!

Dave learned that pichenotte has a long history. It started in India with a game called 'carroms.' Then it became 'squails' in Britain. British people brought it to Canada, where it became pichenotte.

Pichenotte is a game for 2 to 4 players. Each player has 12 pieces called 'pucks.' They flick the pucks across a board to score points. If a puck goes into a small hole, it is worth 20 points. The game is quick and lasts about two minutes.

The brothers saw that many people liked the game at the bar. They made more boards and sold them at markets. People loved the game, and soon there were competitions with a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup.' 

Now, the brothers make pichenotte boards full-time. They have a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board is made of strong wood and costs $595. 

There are no professional pichenotte players yet, but the brothers hope to make their game famous. For now, they enjoy playing pichenotte and working together.

WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE

When you come to the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this place was just empty land with many weeds. People thought it was not useful. One man and his wife worked very hard to change this land into the beautiful village you see now. 

They moved a lot of soil and clay to make the land look nice. They used machines, but many people also worked very hard. They brought in 1,000 tonnes of good soil to make the grass, flowers, and rocks. They planted many trees and bushes that can grow near the sea and can survive strong winds in winter. Some plants came from local shops, but some came from far away places like Canada and New Zealand.

Colin Sims had the idea for the village. He made over 100 models by himself for nine years after the village opened in 1972. The models are made from stone, concrete, wood, and plastic. They are made to last in all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how to make the models strong. Soon, he became an expert too. 

You will see that all the models are made to the same size and have many small details. This took a lot of time and special building methods. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its good work and care. Other model villages in England use the same building methods. 

All the buildings in the village show traditional British styles. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House. It looks like a 13th-century stone house with a brick tower. You will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest part of the village.

Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models. If you touch them, it can take us a long time to fix them. You can take photos from the paths only. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead.

To enjoy the village more, you will see buttons in front of some models. Press these buttons to make the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us make the village better. We also want to know if any models need fixing.

We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Please tell your friends about the Model Village!

Text: 

Every week, British newspapers show pictures of famous people. These pictures often invade their privacy. Sometimes, pop stars take pictures with photographers, but this is not common. Most of the time, these pictures hurt the famous people when they see their private moments in the news. 

There is a group called the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) that helps with these problems, but very few people ask for their help. The pictures are usually not important for the public. For example, does a picture of a famous actress in a hotel help anyone? The actress has complained about these pictures before, but she did not ask the PCC for help. It is surprising that the PCC did not start an investigation. 

The PCC should look into bad stories about pop stars too. Many famous people do not make formal complaints. The PCC could help stop these bad stories. If they did, newspapers would have to change. Other newspapers would report this, and people would not like the bad stories. Photographers would also have a hard time if they could not take sneaky pictures anymore.

But the PCC has a big job. How would they know when to investigate? Should they ask the famous person if they want to complain? If the person does not want to complain, should the PCC still investigate? Famous people might expect the PCC to help them, but they could be upset if they do not. 

Also, it is hard for the PCC to watch all the newspapers in Britain. People might feel embarrassed if their privacy is invaded, and they may not want an investigation. Many just want to forget about it and move on. Some might be scared that if they complain, worse stories will come out. 

One British comedian did not complain when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He was afraid that the newspaper would make fun of him. This fear is common. People think they will be targeted again if they complain. It is difficult to find a simple solution to this problem.

Many people give advice to students who finish college and start their first job. This article talks about getting a second job. We are not talking about people who want a short job while looking for a permanent one. We also do not talk about people who leave a job they do not like after a few weeks. 

This is for people who want to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and know what you want to do. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to focus on one area, move up to a job with more responsibility, or change to a different field. 

You should choose your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. It should help you grow and give you more responsibility. 

If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will see that you have traveled and are ready to work.

Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after finishing St. Aldate's College. It was a good first job because the people were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. But there was no chance to move up. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have learned a lot and my job has grown." Her boss wanted to help her develop. Her job title is the same, but her tasks have changed. She now does most of the letters and budgets. She also answers questions from important people and those who want to start their own business. Brenda includes her in all her work and gives her special projects and events to organize.

**Text: How to Be Confident**

Confident people seem to be born that way, but many learn to be confident. Here are five stories from different people about how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When Jenny left school, she was very shy. She thought she would always be shy. When she was 25, she helped at her daughter’s school. She was scared but did well. Someone told her to take a university course. On her first day, she was very nervous. But over time, she became more confident. Helping at the school changed her life.

**B. Michaela**  
Michaela became confident four years ago when her father got sick. She had to run the family business. At first, she was scared and a bit too aggressive. She learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is too hard, she does not feel guilty if she waits until the next day to finish. When things are tough, she tells herself she has nothing to lose. She talks to herself to feel less afraid.

**C. Lisa**  
People think Lisa is confident, but she often feels scared. She learned to look confident for her job in TV. Interviewing people showed her that many people feel nervous. Her mother gave her good advice: “Who is looking at you? Everyone is busy with their own worries.” Lisa believes you gain confidence by facing your fears. When she took her driving test, she was very nervous but passed. After that, she felt braver.

**D. Barbara**  
Barbara feels confident because she loves her job. She has built her confidence over time. She works hard and is liked by many people, but not everyone. She does not let that bother her. It is important to like yourself. Her company offers training courses that help her feel better about herself. Setting small goals helps her see her progress.

**E. Kim**  
After college, Kim worked as a secretary. She was scared to speak in meetings. One day, she found the courage to share her ideas. When she started working in politics, she was very nervous about speaking in public. She told herself, “People do this every day, so I can too.” She wrote down her thoughts to help her feel more secure. Kim believes everyone feels a little nervous when speaking in public. The secret to confidence is to tell yourself, “Nothing is impossible.”

**Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster goes to a kite festival in Malaysia. He feels nervous at night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiles when Paul gives him his broken kite. "You can keep it," he says. "It is a tradition. If the line breaks, the finder keeps it. I have many more kites." He shows Paul his beautiful kites. They are all the same size, made of paper and bamboo.

They sit in the shade of the trees by the Beach of the Seven Lagoons. They watch the big kite festival. There are 10 platforms on the beach. Helpers hold the kites, and competitors hold the lines. When the whistle blows, the crowd cheers, and the kites fly into the sky. More than 500 men and boys are in the competition. Each person has four kites. The kites are judged on how they look and how well they fly.

"Flying kites is not hard," Adnan says. "But making them is a skill. Come to my house, and I will show you." Paul gets five invitations that day and decides to go to Adnan's house. There, he drinks cold tea and eats fish crackers. Adnan asks him to come back the next day to fix his kite, but Paul cannot.

Instead, Paul drives to Kuala Lumpur. He takes a wrong turn and finds a river. A small boat is there to take people across. He sees a sign that says, "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." He starts walking but does not know it is all uphill and slippery. At the end of the path, he meets Baba, who has a kitchen and some bamboo huts. Paul decides to stay there, even though he worries about insects.

At night, it is very dark, and he hears many sounds. In the morning, he sees a beautiful view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rains. The wind blows, and there is lightning. Paul gets wet. He slides down the hill and thinks about his car. He is happy to find his car at the bottom, covered in mud.

In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, people ask Paul many questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" They are friendly. Kelantan is known for its kites, but Paul remembers it for the kindness of the people.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but we shop in different ways. Here are some people and how they shop:

A. Melanie, 22, dancer  
"I love shopping! I spend a lot of money. When I have money, I go shopping. My boyfriend likes shopping too, so we go together."

B. Brenda, 40, office manager  
"I don’t like shopping. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks. I take my kids shopping for clothes, but I don’t enjoy it. I feel guilty when I spend money on myself."

C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager  
"I only shop for what I need. I don’t like shopping and only go when I have to. I know what I want and I want to get it quickly."

D. Anita, 35, TV producer  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I know what I want. I don’t waste time. I sometimes buy things I don’t need."

E. Lizzie, 41, secretary  
"I really don’t like shopping. I can’t find what I want and the shops are noisy. I usually get my clothes for free. I go food shopping once a week and do it quickly."

F. Lisa, 22, actress  
"I enjoy shopping! I go with my friends and we often buy things. I don’t always have a plan, but if I see something nice, I buy it."

G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant  
"I am a careful shopper. I like to shop, but I don’t buy a lot. I know what I want, but sometimes I shop to feel better, and then I feel bad for spending too much."

H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker  
"I love shopping, but not on Saturdays because it is too busy. I plan what I want and look in many shops to find the best price."

I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager  
"I don’t like shopping. I work in the city, so shopping is not fun for me. When I have to shop, I don’t try on clothes. Sometimes they don’t fit, but I don’t care too much."

NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE

The Open University is a place where you can get a degree. You can study without stopping your job. You can learn many new things. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy learning. You will also meet many new friends. With your degree, you may find new job opportunities.

You do not go to the Open University for classes. You study at home using TV, radio, and computer programs. If you want, you can go to one class a month at an Open University center. There are exams, like in other universities.

If you want to know more, please fill out the form below. This could be the start of something great in your life.

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, children can join a fun quiz about surprises. You can get free quiz sheets at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. The quiz will take you to 14 surprising paintings and ask you different questions about them. The quiz sheets are available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new painting by Jan van Os, a Dutch painter from the 18th century. This big painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings like this in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. The artist waited for different flowers to bloom in different seasons to paint them. This painting was given to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition called "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started on 15 March in the Sunley Room. The Gallery has bought works by three Spanish painters: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. They are the main focus of the exhibition. Other artists in the exhibition are Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
There are lectures every Wednesday to go with the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will discuss Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is happy to say that the restaurant has improved and has more choices. The new kitchens offer many hot and cold dishes at good prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery happen every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours show some of the Gallery's best pictures and important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Little Chefs**

Some children, aged ten to fifteen, spend their Saturdays learning to cook. Many kids want to join, so there is a waiting list of 30 children. Parents pay £280 for the course. The children have fun and learn to make good food.

Bill is ten years old. He says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can cook better than her. The teachers make us laugh when we eat the food we made."

Flora is twelve. She has trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum told me to find a hobby for the weekends. I was happy at home, so I didn't want to come at first. But now, I am very glad I did."

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember better than adults. The kitchen can be messy when they cook! Adults keep learning about food.
