If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, the children will know how to make food for themselves when they grow up."

  - You can try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery.

  - You do not need to be very fit or have experience. Just come and enjoy!

  - It is one of the best parks in the country.

STAMP COLLECTING - A FUN HOBBY

Many people like to collect stamps. It is a fun and interesting hobby. Every year, more people start to collect stamps. You can find stamps on holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends. 

When you collect stamps, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps you get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of stamps. You can get these stamps in three ways: 

1. We can send you a complete set of stamps in an envelope.
2. We can send you the stamps in a colorful pack with fun facts.
3. We can send you single stamps for your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join for just £5 for two years. If you join with friends, you can get a discount. 

When you join, you will get a Starter Pack for free. This pack has 100 stamps and a nice box to keep them in. You will also get a guide with tips on how to collect stamps and where to buy them. 

Every two months, you will receive a magazine with games and competitions. You can also trade stamps with other members around the world. 

Start your adventure in stamp collecting today! You will enjoy looking at your stamps and finding new ones. To join the club, fill out the form and send your payment. You will get your Starter Pack in 28 days.

MONEY

What is money? Money is things like the pound, the dollar, or the franc. Money is different from a gram or a kilometre because you can use it to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note is just a piece of paper that does not cost much to make.

A long time ago, people did not have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, the farmer, gave corn to Mr. Hive for honey. This was a trade between two people who wanted what the other had. 

Over time, many societies made their own types of money, called currencies. Now, most people use a national currency to buy and sell things.

**Write a Winning Story!**

You can win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize! Your story can be in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other people can win £100 each.

We want good stories. The judges are Mary Littlejohn (a writer), Michael Brown (a TV reporter), and Susan Hitchins (the editor of Keep Writing). They want interesting and new stories. Last year, many people wrote detective stories, but the winner wrote a love story.

You can write about anything you like. Here are some tips to help you:

1. **Write About What You Know**: Write about things you understand. Last year, many stories were about love, family, and friends. Make normal situations exciting so people want to read more.

2. **Get Your Facts Right**: If you write about a place or something special, make sure you are correct. Don’t write about things you are not sure about.

3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start your story in an interesting way and end it with a surprise. A bad ending is not good.

4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters real with good words. 

Your story must be your own work. It should be between 2,000 and 2,500 words. Type it, double-spaced, on one side of the paper. We cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must send the application form with your story.

We cannot return your story or talk about our decisions. You cannot have published any fiction in this country. Your story must not be printed anywhere in the world.

You need to pay £5. Write your cheque to Keep Writing and send it with your story and application form to us. 

The closing date is 30 July. We will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must let us print your story in our magazine.

THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. She was the first woman scientist in history. Her father was the head of Alexandria University. He wanted her to have a good education. This was special because most women could not study at that time.

Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome. Then she went back to Alexandria and started teaching math. She became famous for her knowledge. We do not have her books, but we know she wrote important math works. 

Hypatia also liked technology. She made tools to help her with science. Many leaders were afraid of science, and it was dangerous for scientists. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long. It goes from Peterborough to Wansford. There is a 2-kilometer part that goes to Yarwell. 

**Ticket Prices:**  
- Adult: £10.00  
- Child: £5.00  
- Family (up to 2 adults and 3 children): £25.00  
- Special prices may be on holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park has golf courses and a place for caravans. It is a great place for a family day out. There are many areas for picnics, lakes for boating, and a nature reserve. There is also a small train for kids.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has many old trains from Europe. You can see famous trains like the De Glen from France and the Class 52 from Germany. You can visit these trains all year. The buffet, bar, and shop are open only when the train is running. There is a fee to enter Wansford: £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular for movies. It can look like a railway in Europe. The James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. You can come and see where it was filmed.

From May to July, the Railway has special times for school groups. Teachers can bring students to learn. There is a special pack for £1.50 plus postage. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

You can hire a train for special family events or company visits. The Railway can help you plan a fun afternoon or evening. You can have food, drinks, and entertainment. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

**Grass**

Grass is a very successful plant. There are more than 9,000 types of grass. You can find grass everywhere in the world. Grass can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic.

Grasslands are home to many animals. There are small insects and birds, and also big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass to live.

Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or hurt. Unlike other plants, new grass grows from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live in one place. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again. There is always food for them.

Kal Kaur Rai is a young woman who loves fashion. She just won the title of Young Achiever of the Year at the Asian Business Awards. When she was a child, she liked to draw clothes and make designs. She did not tell her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to work in fashion. She thought they wanted her to have a different job, so she went to university to study management.

After university, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising company. She went to many events but could not buy the nice clothes she wanted. So, she started to make skirts and tops for herself. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. 

Kal found a small shop in London that wanted to sell her designs. The clothes were very popular, and none came back. This made her feel good, and she decided to leave her job in advertising. She took a loan of £20,000 to start her own women’s clothing brand. 

Kal's parents were happy and supported her decision. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business makes more than £500,000. Her clothes are in fashion magazines, and she designs for pop stars. She feels very lucky to do what she loves and get paid for it. She says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**Sunningdale Hotel**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913. Princess Louise opened it. Many people from all over the world have stayed here. In 80 years, over 50,000 guests from 174 countries visited Sunningdale.

The hotel is on a main road to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes by bus to get to the center. Buses to other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should not take buses with a blue sign that says "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. There is an underground station less than 100 meters away.

The hotel has 200 single rooms. Each room has hot and cold water. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the hall. The hotel also has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are eight pianos for guests to use. Guests can park their cars in the hotel drive. Daily newspapers are free, and you can buy stamps at the office.

Guests who stay a long time must pay for their room every week in advance. They need to tell the hotel one week before they leave. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get rooms first.

Meal times are: 
- Breakfast: 7 am - 9:30 am 
- Lunch: 1 pm - 2 pm 
- Dinner: 5:30 pm - 7 pm 

If you study or work late, you can ask for dinner until 11 pm. Write your name on the late list or call before 7 pm. There are 10 choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires are allowed in the hotel. Guests should be quiet, especially from 11 pm to 8 am. If you arrive by train, it is best to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main train station.

Tom Cruise

Tom Cruise is a very famous actor. He has many fans. But his life was not always easy. When he was a boy, Tom was shy. He had trouble making friends, but he liked to act in school plays.

After high school, Tom went to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and took acting classes. In 1980, a director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. 

Ten years later, Tom was very successful. He was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood. He made a lot of money for each movie. 

Today, Tom still acts in movies. He is still very popular with many fans around the world.

LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN?

Bo is a little cat. One day, she went into a big van. The van was for furniture. Bo had a big adventure! The driver found her after a long trip. He drove more than 500 kilometres. 

The driver was very tired and hungry. He gave Bo some milk. Then, he tried to find her owner. He called the last people he delivered to, but they did not lose a cat. 

It was late, so the driver took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. 

Bo's owner was looking for her too. He searched everywhere. Then, he remembered the furniture van that came to his neighbour. He called the company. Soon, Bo was back home safe and sound.

**The Ghan Train**

Mark Ottaway took a train from Darwin to Adelaide in Australia. The Ghan train goes from the warm north to the cold south. Many people call it the "famous Ghan," but it is often late.

In the 1920s, there was a plan to connect Darwin and Adelaide by train. They built a line to Alice Springs, but floods made it hard for trains to run. A new train line was finished just before Mark's trip. The Ghan train is not very fast, and it has few stops. Most people on the train are on holiday. The food on the train is very good, but it is not a luxury train like the Orient Express. 

The train was first built to carry goods, not people. It was faster to send goods from Europe to the south of Australia by train than by ship. The Ghan is the first train in the world to go north to south across a continent.

When Mark waited to get on the Ghan, he saw that everyone was excited. Many older Australians were ready to board. The first stop was Katherine, where the train stayed for four hours. Some people got off to take a boat trip. Mark stayed on the train until Alice Springs. There, he went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group. Climbing the rock is not popular now, so they just walked around it and watched the sunset.

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south. Many people stop their journey there. After Alice Springs, the view from the train is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with cattle. But on the third day, they reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. Mark's journey was over. The train may not have done everything the ads said, but it took him to some amazing places in Australia.

**Climbing Ben Nevis**

Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. It is very cold there. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first climb on Ben Nevis. 

It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We climbed up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is 600 meters high, which is very long for a climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the "Carries." These are big bowls in the mountain, halfway up. 

We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow is very hard, like ice. Even though some people in our group were very good climbers, we took safety equipment. This included lights, hard hats, and extra clothes. 

The weather was good, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is hard. The path went up, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest climber, so I had to rest more often. The others stopped to wait for me, but when I caught up, they started again. I promised myself to train better before my next climb. 

After climbing 200 meters, we reached Tower Ridge. It is very narrow, only 1.5 meters wide, and the mountain drops down a lot on both sides. We had to stay calm and focus on every step as we walked slowly. 

After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. But it was misty when we got to the top. 

Going back down to camp can be hard too. You need to read a map well. A wrong turn can be dangerous in winter. I was happy we took turns reading the map. 

When I was safe in the tent, I could finally say I enjoyed the climb. But I was proud that I made it to the top!

Anna's New School

This week is very exciting! We moved to our new school building. It is a great place. The builders used wood to make it, like our old school. This new school is also good for the environment. 

The school took a long time to build. We watched the builders work. It was fun to see them clear the land, but some nice land is now gone. The building was very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of the rain. We thought the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five big classrooms. They are much bigger than the old school next door. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We are excited to use them when the new sports field is ready.

When you come into the school, you will see there are no heaters! The heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps the heat inside. It also keeps the sound inside, so when we sing, it feels like a concert hall!

You will also see a tree on the roof! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We went to see it with our teacher. It spins very fast and is very big!

We are already using the school, but some parts are not finished. We are putting on a play for our parents, but we have to go back to the old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn better here!

A month ago, I did not know that I would be 30 meters above the ground on a Saturday afternoon in November. Now, I look down at the river below me and understand why people like rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place was not very nice, but we had beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air.

On Saturday morning, we met ten other people in our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon. Sisters Carole and Lynn came with their friend Amanda. We all came from different places and did not know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outside, but we were not sure how.

Half of us went caving in the morning, and the others went rock-climbing. Then we switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of pushing, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but happy and excited about what we did.

Letter to the Newport Evening News

On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. My handbag had my cheque book, address book, and my purse. My purse had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized I lost it, it was too late. I was very worried because I am 72 years old and far from home. I stood by the road and cried.

A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. The bus driver said I could keep the fare.

I got home safely. Soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus. He said they found my handbag and would bring it back to me. I got my handbag back, and everything was inside.

I want to say thank you to everyone who helped me that day. I appreciate their kindness and honesty.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

Sharks

Sharks are big and scary animals in the ocean. They can see very well and feel movement in the water. This helps them catch smaller fish for food. 

Sharks are different from other fish. Most fish can stay still, but sharks must swim all the time to breathe. They do not sleep much. If a shark is turned on its back, it can stop moving. This helps scientists study sharks better.

Joining the Kirov Ballet

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I was one of the youngest foreign students at the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I did not know anyone. Everyone came to me and asked questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they spoke English, so we could talk.

Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me. My Russian is much better, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks, my mom stayed with me. When she left, I felt a little sad. One night, I called her because I felt lonely.

The ballet classes in Russia are very hard. I eat a lot to have energy. This helps me do well in class. In the evenings, I watch my favorite movies on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends.

Now, I feel at home here. I like to walk around the city and visit different shops. In December, it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10 degrees Celsius, but the Russians said it was warm for that time!

Right now, we are getting ready for a new show, and there is a competition for young dancers that I will enter. I feel very lucky to be here.

**THE ICEHOTEL**

The Arctic is a cold place. In summer, many people visit to see the midnight sun. In winter, there are not many people. In the late 1980s, some people thought winter could be fun. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit had an exhibition in a special igloo made of snow in Jukkasjarvi, a small town by the frozen Torne River. This building was called Arctic Hall. Many visitors came to see it.

One night, some guests decided to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy. This gave them the idea to make an ice hotel. Now, the ICEHOTEL is famous all over the world.

Every winter, a team of builders, architects, and artists come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They start building in December. Each week, a new part of the hotel opens until it is all finished on January 7th. The hotel is built outside with snow and ice, so the finishing date can change because of the weather.

In spring, when it gets warm, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, it is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, even if it is very cold outside. Guests get warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves when they stay at the hotel. It is also good to bring sweaters, scarves, and thick socks. Guests should wear bigger shoes to fit the thick socks.

If you want to visit the ICEHOTEL, you can buy warm clothes on their website. You can order these things when you book your stay. They will be in your room when you arrive.

The ICEHOTEL is in Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle. It is 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It opened at midnight last Thursday. Many people came to the shop. Up to 6,000 people wanted to buy furniture. There were special offers. A leather sofa cost £45, but only until 3 am. A bed cost £30, but only from 3 am to 8 am. 

The shop usually opens from 9 am to 9 pm every day. But Homestyle said it would stay open for 24 hours. However, it had to close after only half an hour. 

A police officer said there were too many people. The shop was full, so the managers decided to close the doors. People outside were angry. They thought the furniture would be sold out before they could go in. They did not want to wait in line. 

There was also a long line of cars trying to park. Many people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.

One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said, "I waited in line for three hours. I did not have time to buy what I wanted. The staff were calm and explained what was happening. It was not safe. I will come back when they open again, but I do not want to wait in line again."

**Membership**

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain. It started in 1899 and is very active today.

**Society Magazines**

We make good magazines, like the Short Story Review. This magazine has short stories from famous British writers and gives new writers a chance to share their work. Another magazine, Short Story News, has interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, and festivals. You can read some articles from recent issues on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**

We have the National Short Story Competition. It is the biggest competition for short stories. Anyone 18 years or older can enter. Stories can be about any topic and should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Members of the Society do not pay to enter, but non-members pay £5. The competition is open from April to October each year. The ten best stories will be in our annual book. The winner will get a contract to publish their own book of short stories.

**Education**

For almost thirty years, the Society has helped writers in schools. We give children and teachers new ideas and help them feel good about their writing. One project is the Young Writer of the Year, for writers aged 11-18. Winners get book prizes and can join a five-day course with professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is a nice place for members. It has vegetarian food, good coffee, and cold drinks. You can read our magazines there. The Cafe also has exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is in the center of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm on weekdays and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturdays. Members get discounts on some products and events.

**Becoming a Member**

We have members all over the world. Anyone 18 or older can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a form.

**Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter is a free-diver. She has four world records. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on one breath of air. In 2003, Tanya became the first person to dive 120 meters deep and come back up without help. A year before, she went deeper but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for more than three and a half minutes. She was the first woman to break a man’s world record in any sport.

A team of fourteen safety divers watched her dive. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous, but Tanya believes safety and training are very important. Most free-divers focus on one or two events, but Tanya trains the same way for all her events. She spends two-thirds of her training in the gym and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because she does not want to hurt her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit.

When Tanya practices diving, she travels away from home. She tries to do fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day between each dive. It is important for her to not get tired, or it can ruin her training.

When she is not training, Tanya goes to events to talk about sports products. She also helps environmental groups by doing research and making films. Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman. She loved to swim and explore the sea when she was a child. She feels like she is living her childhood dreams now. Because she is famous in some places, people listen to her talk about the environment.

Tanya is now in her thirties. She wants to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving when she was twenty-five, and she does not plan to stop for many years.

CARTOON FILMS

Cartoon films can be very fun. If you can draw, you can make your drawings move on the screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons exciting for everyone. 

In the late 1970s, many people thought cartoons were only for kids. But some directors had new ideas. They showed that both adults and kids can enjoy cartoons together. 

Not all cartoon films were good. For example, The Black Cauldron was not a success. It was too scary for kids and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this. Soon, film companies made a lot of money again.

Caroline Benson is a new TV star. She talks about her first TV role. 

"I did not think I would spend my first year at university making a TV show called The Finnegans. I only acted in school before, but I loved the book since I was eleven years old. My grandmother said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I wanted to play her.

I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me. She said they wanted to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised, but she sent my photo to the director and asked him to meet me. I flew back and got the role.

Filming started a week after university began. I asked the university for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to write my essays. I did not tell my friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I feel very lucky.

After university, I want to be an actor. My family is not in acting, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I have tried for other TV roles, but I have not received any offers yet. I had a busy social life too. When filming finished, I did not know what to do. I have acted in two college plays since then. 

I have not been home much, and now my first year at university is over. I am going to Greece for the summer with my friends."

Title: My Story

In 1976, I opened the first 'Body Shop'. I wanted to make enough money to feed my children. Now, 'The Body Shop' is a big company that is growing all over the world. I have learned many things since we started. I want to share these things in this book. 

This book is not just about business or my life. It is about being different to succeed in business. Business can be fun. It can be run with love and can help people. In business and in life, I want to enjoy myself and feel like I am with family. I want the people who work at 'The Body Shop' to feel this way too.

This book shares my ideas with everyone. I believe there are no limits to our 'family' and what we can do together. I find this very exciting, and I hope you do too.

**A Trip on the Douro River**

Jules Verne has a special ship called the MV Lady Ivy May. This ship is like a hotel and can take 160 guests. All rooms have a view outside and have a shower and toilet. The ship has air-conditioning, a sun-deck, a lounge, a bar, a dining room, a shop, and a library.

**Schedule**

**Day 1:** You will fly from London Heathrow to Oporto in the evening. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May. You will sleep on the ship.

**Day 2:** In the morning, you will see Oporto. After that, you will go back to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the trip takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will keep going up the river. In the evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, where they make port wine. You can try the local food and drink at dinner.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will take a bus to Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum used to be a palace and has many paintings and sculptures. Then, you will go back to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The river gets narrow here. If the water is deep enough, you might take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by bus and see many things on the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a great view of the Douro valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take a train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.

**Day 7:** You will visit Vila Real before going back to the ship for lunch. Then, you will travel down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on the ship.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with time to explore and shop before your flight back to London Heathrow.

HONEY

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugar. Bees can fly very far, up to seventy-five thousand kilometers, and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the flowers the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter honey usually tastes milder than darker honey.

A long time ago, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was hard to find. The ancient Egyptians valued honey a lot and used it as money. Today, people make and eat honey all over the world. Some studies say honey can help with tiredness and make athletes better. Honey is not just food; it can help with sore throats and is used in many skin and hair products.

**Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia in Britain. It has been a place to live for more than 2,000 years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. In 1066, when the Normans came, it became one of the largest towns in England. 

Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095. It celebrated 900 years in 1995. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years of being a city. This meant it could govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than London or Manchester. It has about 150,000 people. In the 16th century, it was the second city of England. It grew for 300 years and became rich. It was famous for having many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs.

In 1964, the University of East Anglia was built in Norwich. The city has many students and is a busy place for business. It has theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts centres. There is also a football team called 'The Canaries'. Their colours are green and yellow.

Norwich has a new shopping centre called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, there was a big hole in the city while builders worked. They moved a lot of earth to make a park on the roof of the Mall. The park has water pools and many trees. 

The old open market is still in the city and is very popular. Both the market and the new shopping centre are busy. This shows that Norwich has a good mix of old and new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky in Albuquerque, a city in the south-western United States, is full of bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival. It happens every year for nine days. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. There were about twelve hot-air balloons that took off from a car park in Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from many countries will come.

**What to See**

The pilots talk to each other on radios. They light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This is called a "balloon glow." It is a great time to take photos. You need to come just after night falls or before 5:30 am to see the "glows" as the balloons go up into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to fly. The balloons are in many sizes and colors. Some look like animals or cartoon characters, and some look like popular drinks and fast food. Kids will love it!

In the afternoon, you can fly in a balloon over the desert with one of the companies that offer rides. You can also take a cable car from the desert to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride, and you can see the festival from above. There are many other fun things to do, like balloon races and fireworks on the first night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a special wind pattern that helps balloon pilots. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. This helps pilots control where their balloons go.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets online before the festival to avoid long waits. Wear several layers of thin clothes because it can be cool at night and in the morning, but during the day, you need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and don’t forget your camera. If you use film, make sure to get high-speed film for night pictures.

The Eden Project

The Eden Project is in the south-west of England. It is a very popular place for tourists. The big 'biospheres' look like something from a science fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate. It shows how important plants are for people.

Many things we use every day come from plants. For example, we get wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate from plants. There are more than 135,000 types of plants here.

Even if it is cold outside, the plants stay warm because of electric heaters. In the Rainforest Zone, it is always wet because of a big waterfall. There is also a zone that looks like the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa. Soon, they will build a desert zone too.

Some people are not happy with this year's book, New Writing 3. I don’t understand why. It has 500 pages of good writing for £6.99. Most of the book has stories. There are short stories and parts of novels. Some famous writers, like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain, have written in this book. 

Some less famous writers write about food. For example, Jane Harris wrote a story called Those Nails. Be careful! Don’t read it after eating. It has some very bad scenes that might make you feel sick. 

There are also poems from nineteen poets, like R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. Jim Crace and Jane Rogers have pieces from their books that are not finished. There is a little non-fiction too. Alan Rusbridger wrote a funny article about newspapers, and Ursula Owen wrote about herself. 

This is a great collection, and I am excited to see what next year’s book will have!

**Learning the Violin**

Margaret Porter is a violin teacher. She says the best age to start learning the violin is between three and six years old. This is when children learn about the world. Margaret lives in London. She likes to teach children who are three or four years old. Sometimes, she teaches five-year-olds who really want to learn.

Margaret started teaching the violin in 1972. Her first class had her children’s friends who were five years old. In her classes, there are about twelve students. They have lessons for one hour, every two weeks. Each student also has one lesson with her every week. 

Parents must come to the lessons too. It is important for parents to be interested in the lessons. 

In the beginning, students learn to play music by listening. They do not read music for a long time. At first, their playing and reading music are very different. Margaret says her way of teaching is not to make great violinists. If a student plays very well, she suggests they learn with other methods.

**Moonshine**

The band Moonshine has a new CD. It is called "Here Again." This is their third CD. The last CD was "The Waves." 

There are some changes in the band. Tom Wilcott plays the bass guitar now. He replaces Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson is the new drummer.

The first song on the CD is a dance song. The band is not making slow songs anymore. The second song is also a dance song and is very loud. Many fans will be surprised by these songs. They are very good and could be popular.

The singer, Rob Letchford, sings very well. He can reach all the notes. Fans are happy he recorded the songs before he had problems with his throat. Because of this, the band had to cancel their next tour. If you bought tickets, do not worry. The concerts will be rescheduled when Rob feels better.

On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles. They have slow songs and dance songs that make you want to move. I think the best songs are at the beginning. The last songs are not as good. 

"Here Again" will be a big hit and help the band become more successful.

San Francisco

San Francisco is a city on the coast of northern California. A Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola found this area in 1769. He saw it first from land, not from the sea. 

In 1849, many people came to San Francisco to find gold. But the people who got rich were not the gold seekers. The rich people owned banks and law firms. They built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill.

Today, many tourists visit San Francisco. They want to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Some people take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

SAMUEL PEPYS

Samuel Pepys wrote a famous diary. This diary talks about life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important events, like sickness, a navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself. He shares his mistakes, like sleeping in church and looking at pretty girls.

Pepys talks about his home life. He had a fight with his wife, but they made up. He worried when she was sick. He liked music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun.

Pepys was a busy man. He had important jobs. He was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He also helped the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

A long time ago, shoes were not very comfortable or stylish. People used animal skins to cover their feet. They tied these skins around their ankles when it was cold. 

Today, we still use leather for shoes, but we also use other materials like silk, plastic, and cotton. This depends on what is popular at the time. 

About 150 years ago, people started to wear different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were the same shape and could be worn on either foot. 

In the past, all shoes were made by hand. Now, many shoes are made by machines in big factories. Sewing machines help make many shoes quickly and at a lower price.

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women enjoy running. I started a running club for women in my area. I was upset because many race organizers say there are not enough women in running, but they do not help by giving women their own changing rooms.

I made posters, and 40 women joined my club. They were young and old, fit and not fit. They wanted to lose weight, but many had not thought about running before. They thought running was hard and painful. They did not think about having fun, talking, and smiling while running in nice places, like by a river.

At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes! They also learned about healthy eating and staying fit. I wanted to help women with running, and I am very happy to see how much they have improved. They are happy too!

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - A SPECIAL DOG SLED RACE**

In the 1880s, people found gold in Alaska, the northern state of the USA. Many people came to find gold and get rich. New towns were built quickly. One town was called Iditarod, which means "far place." In 1909, Iditarod became the biggest city in Alaska for a short time.

In summer, boats brought supplies to the towns. But in winter, rivers and the ocean froze, and boats could not come. So, in 1910, a winter path was made for dog teams pulling sleds. They took mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for the dog teams to travel across Alaska. They stopped at places called "roadhouses" to sleep and eat.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when planes became the main way to travel. But in 1925, there was a big problem. A sickness called diphtheria was in the city of Nome. The medicine was far away in Anchorage. Planes were new, and no one knew if they could fly in the cold. So, they decided to use dog teams to bring the medicine.

The trip was over 1,000 kilometers along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty dog teams just six days to finish. Leonhard Seppala, a man from Norway, traveled the first 400 kilometers with his dog Togo. Togo was very good at finding the way in the snow. The last part of the trip was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, stopped the team from falling into icy water. 

The medicine arrived, and the sickness was stopped. Balto became a hero. Now, every year, there is a dog sled race from Anchorage to Nome. It is called the Iditarod and is known as "The Last Great Race on Earth."

**Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Sweden. In winter, it can be very cold, up to -40 degrees Celsius. Many people visit this place every year. They come to see a special hotel made of ice. 

In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in ice rooms. You can even have a wedding there! The bar is made of ice too, so you should not put hot drinks on it. 

The bedrooms are about -4 degrees Celsius. But don’t worry! Guests get special sleeping bags to keep warm. You can also get warm clothes if you need them. 

The hotel is only open for six months. In summer, it melts. Every winter, workers build it again. They use 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow to make the hotel.

Maria Mutola

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl on a boys' football team in Mozambique. They played in a local competition and won. Maria said, "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the other team complained."

A man named Jose Craveirinha read about Maria in a newspaper. He helped many African athletes. He went to see Maria and saw her playing football. He noticed she was very fast. Jose talked to her about athletics, but Maria did not understand. She only knew about football. Then, he bought her running shoes and took her to train. It was hard work, and her legs hurt.

Jose spoke to Maria's parents. He told them she could be successful and help the family. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, Maria went to train in the United States. She was scared to go because she would miss her family. 

In the US, Maria met other girls who were good athletes. But they worried about different things, like dresses and make-up. Maria worried about her family having enough food. She felt lucky to be there. The trainers were very good, and she learned a lot.

Today, Maria still runs. She lives happily in South Africa with her mother for most of the year.

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon is in the United States. It was made by the Colorado River. Many people visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and see the view. The view is very beautiful, and the Skywalk makes it even better. 

The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform made of glass. You can see the pretty rocks below you. Up to 120 people can stand on the Skywalk at the same time. It opened in 2007, and many people have visited it since then. 

You must wear special covers on your shoes to protect the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying high in the air.

THE ROCKIES

The Rocky Mountains are in North America. They start in the North-west and go down south. The Rockies are not as tall as the Alps, but they are very beautiful. There are many roads in the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. 

You can start your trip in Vancouver. Vancouver is a nice city in Canada. You can see the water and the mountains there. People can ski just 15 minutes by car from the city. 

Before, thirty trains left Vancouver every day to go across the country. Now, there are only three trains a week. But the train ride is still very exciting. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you see the beautiful mountains at night.

**ZOOS**

People have kept animals in zoos for a long time. This started over 3,000 years ago in China. The rulers there made a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the past, animals did tricks for visitors, but now this does not happen. Now, zoos are places where people can see animals acting like they do in nature.

Today, many cities have zoos or wildlife parks. Some people think zoos are good. They say zoos help us learn about animals and nature. We can see wild animals up close because of zoos.

But not everyone likes zoos. Some people think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They say that in some zoos, animals do not have good living conditions. They may live in dirty places and eat bad food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, age 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from other high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes. My band wore black school uniforms, and other bands wore bright T-shirts. We did not look like professional adult bands, but we played very well. Everyone was young, but we were good at performing. Each band even made new songs on stage. It was fun to watch, and it was even better when my band played!  

My school has a great jazz band, but not everyone can join. Only about half of the people who want to play can be in the band. But anyone who wants to play can go to jazz practice before school. We also spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. We go on trips to jazz summer camps in different places. I have been to a few and learned a lot.  

Many adults are surprised that young people like jazz. My music teacher thinks it is because pop music is not hard enough for serious music lovers like me. I find jazz exciting because it is both new and old. You can make your own music, but you also feel part of its history. You play on stage like great jazz musicians did before.  

My school is lucky because we have great teachers and parents who help us. Without them, we could not do well with our music!

**Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain from November to March. It does not rain often. When it rains, the water pipes cannot handle it, and the streets become like rivers. Many winters are dry, so when it rains, the people are happy.

Marrakesh has parks and gardens. These are not only because of the rain. There are underground channels that bring water from the mountains. These channels were made a long time ago, in the 11th century. Places that are mostly dry but have water from channels are called oases.

If you go south from Marrakesh, you will find Skoura. In Skoura, people use all the land to grow food. There are small squares made by the water channels. The Atlas mountains, which have snow in winter, look beautiful in the background.

**Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has two older brothers. They work in banking and computers. But Gareth wants to be a clown.

Three years ago, Gareth and his family joined a circus. Kath says, "People laugh when we tell them, but it is true. Gareth wanted to be a clown since he was three years old." When Alan lost his job, they looked for jobs in the circus. They both got jobs, and Gareth started to train to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo.

In the summer, they travel with the circus. In the winter, they go home. Gareth's brothers can take care of the house while they are away. Kath says, "It was not easy. We had to think about many things. We only had a small car and a tiny caravan to sleep in. We left our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long baths."

Gareth talks about school. He says, "People ask about my education. But wherever we go, someone teaches me. I use the same books as my friends at school, and I have a computer. I have not fallen behind."

What about the future? Kath says, "It was a hard choice, but this is the best way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I am happy, and we enjoy it." Gareth says, "One day, I will be the main clown in a circus, maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news group for young people. You can join if you are between 8 and 18 years old. We collect news and write stories. We send these stories to newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites. You can read or listen to the stories on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three places in the country where young people can meet and work on projects. We want to open more places soon. Since we started in 1994, over 2,500 young people have joined us. Sophie is one of them. She says: "I heard about Eight-eighteen when they asked me about hip hop music. I met young journalists and saw what they could do. Age did not matter. I went to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me do more than I thought I could. I got a job at 19 and now I check articles for a big news website."

**Join Us!**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will get training. You will also have meetings every month to decide who will write each news story. Older members, called "peer trainers," help new members learn basic journalism skills. Some of these trainers talk to groups of young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen, like in youth clubs and summer camps. They always have support from older staff.

We have training for new members three times a year. The next training will be in February. If you or someone you know wants to join, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. You can join Eight-eighteen if you can read and write at any level. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here is what you need to know before you book a flight.

In the summer, we take tourists on a big plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, to see Antarctica and then back. The flight dates for next year are not ready yet, but if you book now, you can change your date if needed.

**Questions**

**How long is the flight?**  
The flight is about 12 hours. After about 4 hours, we see sea ice and icebergs. We spend 4 hours over Antarctica and then fly back home. During the flight, experts talk about Antarctica and answer questions. There is a camera next to the pilot, so you can see what the pilot sees from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers get two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you will move to the seat on your second pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight. While we are over Antarctica, you can get up and move around the plane to see better. The pilot flies in big circles so everyone can see the sights.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different flight plans. The captain will check the weather on the morning of the flight and choose the best way to see.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most wildlife is far below the plane, so we cannot see them well. We do not land in Antarctica because it is not good for the environment. If you want to see wildlife, you need to go on a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! You can bring your camera. We also have some fun photo spots on the plane where you can wear cold weather clothes from Antarctica.

**Little Chefs**

Some children, aged ten to fifteen, spend their Saturdays learning to cook. Many kids want to join, so there is a waiting list of 30 children. Parents pay £280 for the course. The children have fun and learn to make good food.

Bill is ten years old. He says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can cook better than her. The teachers make us laugh when we eat the food we made."

Flora is twelve. She has trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum told me to find a hobby for the weekends. I was happy at home, so I didn't want to go at first. But now, I am very glad I came."

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's a lot of fun. Children pay attention and remember better than adults. The kitchen can be messy when they cook! Adults keep learning about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, the children will know how to make food for themselves when they grow up."

**Winter Driving**

Winter can be dangerous for driving. It is hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can be on the road, and ice can be under the snow. A car coming towards you might slide on the road.

**Rule Number One:** Drive smoothly. If you move the car too fast or too suddenly, it can be hard to control. When you turn the wheel, touch the brakes, or go faster, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive carefully so you do not spill it.

**Rule Number Two:** Pay attention to the road. Look far ahead, especially if there is ice. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. You might be going faster than you think. 

When the road is wet, allow double the time to stop. On snow, allow three times the time. On ice, allow even more time. Try to keep control of your car, and you will be safe.

Craigie Aitchison

Craigie Aitchison is a painter. He was born in Scotland. He went to London to study law, but he went to art school instead. In art school, he found drawing hard, but he kept painting.

When he was in his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art. He liked early Italian artists, and this is seen in his paintings. He loved the green and brown colors of the Italian fields and the bright light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. He paints colors one on top of another, from light to dark. He says, "It's a secret - I don’t know what will happen." He does not start with a plan for the colors.

Aitchison thinks painting is easy. He says, "Anyone can use colors - you can buy them. I just see how colors look next to each other." He does not make drawings before he paints because he thinks he might get bored. He changes his paintings many times before they are done. He likes to paint people who do not want to see their picture while he is painting. He says, "If they are worried and want to look, I can’t paint."

Since he moved to London, he does not feel part of the Scottish art scene. He does not want to follow any tradition. He just paints in his own way. His work still inspires young British painters.

**Rock Band**

Two years ago, our son Ben, who is 14 years old, asked us for drums for his birthday. At first, we did not want to buy them because of the noise. Ben said, "It is better than watching TV or playing computer games. It will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you must think about the family and the neighbors when you play."

This was just the start. The other boys in Ben's band came to our house with their guitars and other music things. Now, for many hours each week, our house is loud with their music and singing. 

When the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. I must say, even if their music is a little strange, they are nice and polite boys. I cannot say if they are good musicians, but they play at local clubs for young people.

We worry that they will not do enough school work because of music, but this has not happened yet. I always tell Ben that his studies are very important. But one thing is sure: Ben was right. Playing music keeps him out of trouble and he is never bored.

**Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College. It is a good private college in Wales. The college helps young people learn about life outside the classroom and study for their exams.

The students are between 16 and 18 years old. They come from many countries. In the morning, they study. In the afternoon, they do helpful activities. They might help on a farm, care for people with learning difficulties, or check rivers for pollution.

Atlantic College has students from different backgrounds. Many students cannot pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, so there are grants to help them. About 25% of the students are British, and many get help from the government.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I admire the college for helping young people understand each other. You learn to live with people and respect them, even if you don’t like them. My mother said I argued less with my sister during the summer."

In short, Atlantic College gives students a great education with methods that work well.

Text: 'Being an older student

I am 32 years old. I just finished my first year at university. I go to classes and I read books quickly. I also write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. 

Before, I worked as a secretary. I earned good money, but I was bored. I did not have to think much at my job. I felt sad because I thought I was stuck in that job. I saw students at the local university. They looked happy and full of hope. I wanted to be like them.

Now that I am a student, I find it hard to make friends with younger students. They often think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers. Even if we are the same age, I know less than they do. 

But I am happy to study. I know I need a good qualification to get a good job. This is very important to me. I like to spend my weekends reading books instead of going to parties. 

I also enjoy the benefits of being a student, like long holidays and discounts for the theatre and cinema. Sometimes I worry about what I will do after university, but I hope going back to school is a good choice.'

Henry Ford

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863. He did not like farming. When he was fifteen years old, he started to work as a mechanic. In 1893, he made his first car. He drove it for 1,500 kilometers, then he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong and light steel to make cars that were cheap for regular people to buy. 

In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T'. It cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this meant there were not many choices. Henry Ford said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it is black."

**Rebecca Stevens**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the mountain, she was a journalist. She lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family. She traveled to Asia with other climbers.

Life on Everest is hard. Rebecca said, "You must carry everything on your back." This means you can only take what you need. There is no water to wash, only snow. She did not even take a toothbrush. She usually likes to be clean, but there is no water. Water is heavy, so you only take enough to drink.

On May 17, 1993, Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest. It was the best moment of her life. After that, she became famous. Now, she has written a book about her trip. People often ask her to talk about it. She has a new job on a science program on television.

Rebecca is well known today. She has more money, but she still lives in her small flat in south London with her pictures and books about mountains.

**CANADA GEESE**

Canada Geese are big birds. They are blue and white. When autumn comes, they fly south to find warm weather. In Canada, the winters are very cold. The birds can die if they stay there.

Last spring, a man named Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. The young birds lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds will not know what to do in autumn." 

Bill had a small plane. He decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he flew short trips in his plane, and the young geese followed him.

When autumn came and it got cold, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States. Virginia is 600 miles south of Canada. The geese followed him all the way.

Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill waited for the birds to come back. They did not come, so he flew to Virginia to find them. He looked for two weeks but could not find them.

When Bill got back home, he saw the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home by themselves!

ESTHER'S STORY

Esther finished school when she was sixteen years old. For her birthday, her aunt Flory gave her £500. Most of Esther's friends went to college, but Esther used the money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon had £1,000.

At first, her parents did not want her to make jam. They wanted her to study and become a teacher or a doctor. But Esther did not listen. She kept making jam. After a few months, she sold her jam at the local market. Then, she started making orange juice and sold it to a school where her friend worked.

After two years, her business grew a lot, and her parents were happy. She made many kinds of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She was very busy, so she hired some people to help her.

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens. They sell milk and eggs. But most of their money comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep. Each sheep has enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen cuts the wool from the sheep. This helps the sheep not to get too warm.

Five years ago, Jenny made sweaters with the wool. She tried to sell them at country markets. But it was summer and hot, so people did not want to buy sweaters. Then, she made socks. Everyone loved the socks because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business started.

At first, Jenny made the socks at home. Soon, she had many customers. So, she sent the wool to a factory. Now, the socks are made on machines. There are six colors and five sizes for all ages. There are different socks for walking, sports, and skiing.

Jenny is very busy at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In her office, there are many letters from happy customers from all over the world.

**BURGLARS LIKE THE AFTERNOON**

Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told us that house burglaries have gone up by more than 30% from last year. He said that 67% of burglaries happen when people go out and forget to close a door or a window. 

Night-time burglaries are not common because families are usually at home then. But winter afternoons are good for burglars because it is dark and they can hide easily. Many houses are empty at this time because people are still at work.

Inspector Saunders said it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This can help keep burglars away. He also asked neighbors to watch other houses when people are not home. They should call the police if they see something strange.

"We will also tell you how to make your house safe," Inspector Saunders said. "This help costs nothing."

Thank you for the two nights I stayed in your nice home. It was good to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you wanted. They are nice photos, right? I hope you like them. I love my new camera. I will visit my sister in New York next week. I will take many photos there, too. I have not seen my sister for a long time.

Thanks again.

Love, Roy

**The History of Farming**

Before farming, people looked for plants and fruit in the forest to eat. They moved a lot to find food. About 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people started to grow food. These people were the first farmers. 

Farming helped people stay in one place. Their villages became bigger. Some people in the villages could do other jobs, like making clothes, because farmers grew food for everyone. 

But farming was hard when the weather was bad. Sometimes, people did not have enough food to eat. 

Today, farmers can grow more food. The food travels a long way to reach our homes.

**WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE**

Nicola Peet finished school when she was eighteen. Then, she went to college. After that, she worked at a local airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines. Later, she joined British Airways as an air hostess. Four years later, she became a manager.

This is what she said about her job: "My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time in the air. I teach air hostesses and help them with problems. I also go to many meetings. I usually work from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. 

At work, the first thing I do is check plane times on my computer. Then, I talk with some air hostesses. Sometimes, I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That is my favorite part of the job, but I like office work, too. 

Travelling can be hard. When I come back from a long trip, I just want to eat and go to bed! I don’t earn a lot of money, but I am happy with British Airways. I want to stay there and keep travelling."

Dear Maria, 

I am happy to be back home in my country. But I still think about my friends in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study more. How are you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon. 

Love, Sophie

The Weather People care about the weather for many reasons. The weather is important for many jobs. For example, farmers need to know about the weather. Many years ago, farmers looked at the sky, animals, and flowers to understand the weather. Now, we have computers that help us learn about the weather. People can also get weather information on their mobile phones. 

Today, many people still believe old ideas about the weather. They say if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people think that if cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.

Frazer and Peter are 14-year-old boys. They live in a small town in Canada. They are good friends and go to the same school. On weekends, they like to go fishing or swimming. But for the last few months, they have stayed in Peter's room. They are working on a computer game.

This game is not for homework. They made a new word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin. Kevin has trouble reading. He learns better with pictures and sounds. Frazer wanted to help him.

Frazer and Peter worked together for a long time to make this game. Now it is ready to use. It is a game with pictures and sounds. For example, when you see the word "hat," you also see a picture of a hat. You can hear Peter say, "Hat! Hat!" at the same time.

Frazer and Peter have won many prizes for their game. Soon, it will be sold all over the world. Many schools want to buy it.

HOW DOES THE IRISH POP GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE?

Sleeping well is very important. When I go home to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. But after a concert, I find it hard to sleep because my head is full of music. 

Sport is also important. Before my car accident, I went to the sports center for two and a half hours every day, five days a week. Now, I cannot do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups every day. I do not drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat healthy food. I drink a lot of water because it is good for health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I do not always drink that much.

People should not work all the time. I love my job, but I also like to do other things. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It is good to relax sometimes. 

I do not feel tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now, I eat many healthy foods like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!

**Bollywood**

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It makes about 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made more than 29,000 films. This is more than the USA, so it is the biggest film industry in the world. 

Many Indians like to watch films. Ten million people go to the cinema every day. Bollywood films often tell love stories. They have a lot of singing and dancing. People outside India also like Indian films. Last year, Bollywood made over $500 million by selling films to other countries.

Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. Most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make. A Hollywood film usually costs more than $5 million.

Most Bollywood actors are young. They work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan is a famous actor in India. He has been in more than 140 films and has acted for almost 40 years.

Bill Bryson

I was born in the United States. I have written many travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. Now, we live in the United States for the last three years. Our children are learning about life in the United States. I think they will be happy because they have lived in two countries.

I like Britain and want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon. So, I cannot go back for four years. I just went to England for six weeks. I worked on a radio show about the English language and talked about my new book.

Most writers do not like to travel and sell their books. I do not mind it. I like to visit new places and meet new people. It is very different from my life in the United States when I write. In England, people drove me in big cars and I stayed in nice hotels. It was good because I did not have to pay for anything. Everyone was nice to me and it was fun.

Schnauzer Dogs

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England more than 50 years ago. The Giant Schnauzer is bigger and has not been in England for long. The Giant Schnauzer is 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair, and they need haircuts often. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, but the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. 

Schnauzers come from Germany. Farmers use these dogs to help with sheep. The police also use Schnauzers because they are very smart. Schnauzers are good family dogs. They are friendly and great with young children.

The Ruwenzori Mountains

Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help make a road through a forest between two big towns.

Mary said, "It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food." It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. The Ruwenzori Mountains are one of the wettest places in the world.

Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to go back next year to help again.

Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me. She showed me the classrooms. She is very nice. I will visit her this weekend. 

My favorite lesson today was Maths. I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time. I really liked it. Most teachers are friendly, but I am scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot.

The Long Night  
This is David Reilly's first book. David was a teacher before he became a writer. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick. Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to a big city. They have many problems on the way.

Hard Work  
This is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat. He works with his father, who is a carpenter, in Thailand. They make tables and chairs, but they do not have money. One day, a man in black buys a beautiful table from their shop.

**The History of Horse Racing**

Horse racing is an important sport. It started a long time ago, about 4,500 years ago, in Central Asia. People in Greece and Rome liked horse racing too. 

Modern horse racing began in Europe in the 12th century when Arab horses came to Europe. At first, there were long races with only two horses. But in the 18th century, races became shorter and had many horses running together.

Today, many people watch horse racing in the USA. It is the second most popular sport after baseball. Horse racing is also popular in other countries.

Nick Barlow is a world traveller. He is a British actor. He travels to many countries to make TV shows. "People are nice to me everywhere," he says. "When I go home, I remember all the good things from each country."

Nick has been to many places, but he wants to visit South America and go back to Australia one day. He travels with a team. They bring cameras and other things to make the show. Nick does not take many things for himself. He takes a few shirts and trousers, but he always brings books in his suitcase.

Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him travelling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When Nick comes back, she likes to hear his travel stories. 

Sometimes, there are problems. When Nick was in the Malaysian rain forest, he heard that Helen was sick in the hospital. "I felt very bad because I could not help her, but she did not want me to come home. I was very happy when I heard she was better."

**Parrots**

Parrots are beautiful birds. They have nice colors and long tails. You can see them in forests or zoos. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They like to live in big groups. Parrots eat a lot of fruit, so they can be a problem for farmers.

There are many types of parrots. All parrots have strong beaks and feet. They use their beaks and feet to climb and hold food. Some parrots can live for 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart. You can teach them to talk. Some zoos have shows with parrots. You can watch the parrots do tricks they have learned.

HOWARD BONNIER

Bray is a pretty village. It is about fifty kilometers from London. A young man named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know his name yet, but he is already famous in France. He has written about many good restaurants in French magazines. Howard is 29 years old.

When Howard was a teenager, he went to restaurants with his parents. He liked this a lot. He did not buy many clothes or CDs. Instead, he used his money to go to France and eat in good restaurants. He also has many cookbooks. He says he has more than two hundred and fifty!

Why did he open a restaurant? He loves cooking. Is it easy to do? He says it costs a lot of money to start a restaurant. It is also harder to cook for fifty people than for his family. But he believes he made the right choice.

John Pickering

In a small park in England, John Pickering cuts the grass and waters the flowers. Last week, he was in Tokyo. Many people in Japan watched him on TV because he is a famous singer there. John is 35 years old.

A few months ago, John sang in clubs in Osaka and Nagoya, Japan. A radio DJ heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people called the DJ to hear the songs again. In Japan, John uses the name Jon Otis when he sings.

John will still work in the park in England. He does not know how much money he will make from singing. He says, "I must keep my job in the park. I still have to pay my bills!" 

The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan. They have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, works in a hospital. She says, "This will not change our life. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"
