**Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have a new hobby. It is called line dancing. In almost every town, there are clubs and classes for line dancing.

Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it! Fiona Lever, a teacher, says, "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It is a good way to make new friends." In her classes, there are young and old people. The boys like it because they can make noise with their feet when they dance!

When did line dancing start? Most people think it started about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

The Rhino

There are five types of rhinos in the world. The Black and White rhinos live in Africa. The other types live in forests in Asia. Rhinos are big and heavy. Their skin is hard and they have little hair. Rhinos have four short legs. Each foot has three toes. They walk slowly, but they can run fast, up to 50 kilometers an hour. Rhinos are usually quiet and calm. They eat grass and plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born. It stays in its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs more than 200 kilos and can live for 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

A long time ago, in 1700, there were no policemen in London. Only a few old men walked the streets at night to help keep people safe. They did not get paid much money. 

London was getting bigger and very dirty. Many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money, so people stayed at home a lot. 

In 1750, a man named Henry Fielding paid some people to stop the thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. 

Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London was much bigger and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first London Police Force started with 3,000 officers. Most of them walked, but some rode horses. 

Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police get paid well, and the few who ride horses get paid even more.

Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people go to Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, for the Edinburgh Festival. This festival happens for three weeks in August and September. The city is full of actors and artists from many countries. They come to Edinburgh for the biggest arts festival in Britain. 

During the festival, the streets are full of music and dance from morning to night. You can see artists painting pictures on the streets. One fun part of the Festival is the 'Fringe'. Here, students do funny shows in small places like cafes. Many tourists come to see new films, plays, and listen to famous musicians.

This year, there are more than five hundred shows with actors from over forty countries. The tickets for these shows are not very expensive. It is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, come to Edinburgh next summer! But remember, it can be hard to find a room. It is a good idea to book your hotel now!

ICE-FISHING

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will find Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake is covered with ice. Many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. They sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice.

Bob Marvisch has come here for twenty-five years. He says, "You need light but warm clothes: two pairs of socks, gloves, thin sweaters, and a snow suit." 

Catching fish is easy. First, you break the ice and make a small hole. Then, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. You put the line through the hole and into the water. When the fish eat the bread, you pull the line up. The fish are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but Bob prefers chocolate or snacks after he catches three or four fish. 

Today, Bob has caught twenty-five fish! He says, "It's a great sport, and you can meet nice people here!"

Madame Tussaud's

Madame Tussaud's is a famous museum in London. Many tourists visit this place. In the museum, people can see wax figures of famous people. 

Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle was a doctor. He made wax figures of people and opened a museum in Paris. Marie helped her uncle. 

In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie went to prison. In prison, she had to make wax heads of famous people who were dead, like Queen Marie Antoinette. 

In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud. In 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum in London. You can still see her figures today.

BICYCLES

A bicycle is a cheap and clean way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. At first, bicycles were very expensive. Only rich people could buy them. These early bicycles looked very different from today’s bicycles. Later, bicycles became cheaper, and many people bought them. People started riding bicycles to work and for fun. 

Today, many people use cars more than bicycles. Cars are faster, and you don’t get wet when it rains! But some people still like to ride bicycles to work. They say there are too many cars in the city, and it is hard to find a place to park!

The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand with my family. We had a beach holiday. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had nice flower gardens, but we wanted to see the elephant show.

We went to a big area with seats. Three elephants came in with their trainers. They stood in front of a big white card. Each elephant had a paintbrush. They started to paint on the card. The trainers gave them new brushes with paint and took the old ones away. The elephants followed the trainers' instructions and made pictures. 

I was surprised! One picture was of a river, one was of a tree, and the last one was of flowers. When the trainers showed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We also gave the elephants bananas we brought for lunch.

Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore. The smartest elephants live in special places where people can watch them.

**Big Cats**

There are many kinds of cats. They are different in size and look. Tigers are the biggest cats. They can be 3.7 meters long from head to tail. Most cats do not like water, but tigers like to lie in water when it is hot!

Lions are the only cats that live in big family groups. Many lions work together to find food for the group. They usually live in flat, open places where they can see far and follow other animals easily.

All cats need good eyes to catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

THE OSTRICH

The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world. An adult ostrich can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. 

Ostriches have wings like all birds, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn when they run. Ostriches can run very fast, up to 90 kilometres an hour. This makes it hard for other animals to catch them. 

Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens. They take about 3 years to grow up. Ostriches eat plants and can live many days without water.

Text: 'Victoria Jamieson is a snowboarder from Britain. She started snowboarding when she was 20 years old. Now she is 23 and has won many competitions. We talked to her at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland last week. We asked her why she started snowboarding. She said, "I have always liked sports, especially skiing. It was easy to start snowboarding. You can learn fast and get good in a few months." 

We asked her if she practices a lot. She said, "In winter, I snowboard every day in the mountains from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and ride my bike. I love it all! I like the competitions and being in the mountains. It is very beautiful. But free-riding, which is when you do what you want, is the best for me." 

We asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn fast, but you need lessons. It is also important to have the right clothes so you don’t get wet because you will fall down a lot at first!"'

**Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people climb Kilimanjaro. They can be very young, like a seven-year-old boy, or very old, like an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to the top. The Marangu path is five kilometers long and is the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and many tourists like it.

Only half of the people who try to climb Kilimanjaro reach the top. This is because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it can be hot and rainy. But at the top, there is ice and snow, and it can be very cold, below 20 degrees. Climbers need to bring sunglasses and warm clothes!

Otters

Not many people have seen an otter. Otters live near rivers. They make their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are very good swimmers. They can swim faster than 10 kilometres an hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose. This helps them stay under water for a long time.

Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very dirty. Many fish and insects died, so otters had no food. But now, the rivers are clean, and there is a lot of food for otters.

Buildings

People have always made buildings. We need houses to stay warm and dry. We build stadiums to watch football games and concerts. We have museums to keep beautiful things.

Many people work together to build a building. The architect is the person who decides how the building will look. They draw pictures to show their ideas. Engineers make sure the building is strong and safe. Then, workers build it carefully.

The Sydney Opera House is a famous building. It has a beautiful roof. The building looks nice from all sides, not just the top. The Olympic Stadium in Munich is also famous. It looks like a tent made of glass.

The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England. They are close to each other. Between these towns, there are many green hills and fields. On one hill, there is a big picture of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant. The village next to him is called Cerne. 

We do not know when the Cerne Giant was made, but it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to see the picture. If you go on May 1st when the sun comes up, you will see many people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.

Gail Rollins

Gail Rollins is a great runner from Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to run 10,000 metres and maybe 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail often came second in big races. She always smiled and laughed, and people in her city love her for this.

In 2004, everything changed. Gail ran her first half-marathon, which is a long race. She won and had the best time of the year for a British woman runner. 

Gail's husband, Mike Rollins, was also a runner when he was younger. But he hurt his right leg and cannot run in races anymore. He can still run a little and sometimes practices with Gail. But it is not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him.

Gail practices a lot. She runs long in the morning and fast in the afternoon. She always rests from running on Sundays. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should eat that?' It is usually cake, but she can eat almost everything."

**Piano Players - When They Were Young**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. When he was twelve, he studied music in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano, but she taught him and his sister songs. His mother taught him to play the piano when he was six. At ten, he wanted to write music and started his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father taught him some Russian music. At six, he had lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg won prizes for his piano playing. When he was fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years. Then, he came back to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two. A year later, he started playing the piano. He had his first concert when he was six. At ten, he gave fifty-two concerts in two months in England! Josef liked music, but he also liked physics and languages. He is busy now, but one day he wants to write his own music.

Bill Prince-Smith

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist. He became a writer of children's books when he was 60 years old. Now, he is 73 and has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. She tells him if she likes it or not. Bill's ten grandchildren do not live close, but they also read his stories and tell him if they are good or bad. 

Bill writes about life in his village and on the farms nearby. His favorite book is called "The Sheepdog." It is about a farmer and his dog that helps him. Bill loves animals and thinks dogs are very smart. 

Last year, they made a film of his book with real animals and actors. The people who made the film used special technology to make it look like the animals are talking. Bill was very happy with the film. He said, "Sometimes they change books for the film, but they did not change mine, and I love the film."

POSTCARDS

Today, people like to send postcards to friends and family. Postcards have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles. You can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday. Postcards are cheap, and the pictures are often nice.

The first postcard was sent a long time ago, at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards showed news, like an accident or a visit from an important person. People liked these postcards because newspapers did not have pictures then.

Dinosaurs

No one has seen a dinosaur. The last dinosaur died about 60 million years ago. This was a long time before people were on Earth. We do not know why they all died. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds.

Dinosaurs did not all look the same. There were more than 5000 kinds of dinosaurs. Some were very small, but others were very big. The biggest dinosaurs were larger than any other land animals. 

For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long. It ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat. It could run fast because it had long back legs.

Bears

Bears can be dangerous. An adult bear is very strong and can hurt a person. Bears can climb trees and run fast. But they do not see well. They find food with their noses.

There are seven types of bears. The biggest is the white polar bear. It can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears. One lives in North America, and the other lives in South-East Asia. Not all black bears are black. They can be dark brown or reddish brown.

Many people love the black and white panda bear. Pandas come from China. There are not many pandas in the forest now because it is hard for them to find food.

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in warm places like Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They like to stay in slow water, but they can swim fast and run fast on land. You can see many crocodiles together in groups. They eat fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they can eat big animals or even people.

There are more than ten kinds of crocodiles. All crocodiles have sharp teeth. They can lose their teeth, but they grow new ones. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some are bigger. They can live a long time. The oldest crocodile in a zoo was 66 years old.

A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL

In 1783, two brothers from France made the first balloon for people to fly in. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, two brothers named Wright made the first plane with an engine. They flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service.

Aeroplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. In the 1950s, aeroplanes became faster because they had jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was made in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world. It can fly at 2500 kilometres an hour, so the trip from London to New York takes only four hours.

Today, many people travel by aeroplane. It is hard to imagine a world without them.

The Globe Theatre

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different. The building was round and had no roof. If it rained, people got cold and wet. The queen liked to go to the Globe Theatre by the River Thames to see plays by William Shakespeare. All the actors were men. Visitors ate food, talked to friends, and walked around during the show. Some people even threw things at the actors!

Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place by the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play or learn about life in the 1600s.
